With intimate setting and satisfying French fare, we would recommend this restaurant to anyone spending time in the city.
author: Giselle R.

description: I was curious about this French bistro located near the Hyatt. A tiny little box of a restaurant, with a modern and appealing look. They were only a few tables available inside the restaurant, which turns it into an intimate romantic setting. The menu was very limited, with perhaps four or five entrees, not even ten appetizers and a short but fine wine list. We started with the cheese special, followed by the marinated flat iron steak, summer squash and potato gratin, shaved grilled asparagus, red corn and seared duck breast, cherries duck confit croquette, farro, lightly sautéed haricots verts, squash and bell pepper risotto. Everything was cooked to perfection, giving each one of the menu items a very unique flavor. We were impressed by the way each plate was presented and the wait stuff demeanor as they were delivering the dishes. Truly, one of the best meals and experiences in a while.
author: Ania S.

description:
Deliciousness to the max! Every party of the meal was very well executed.

This nice little restaurant is in an interesting part of town, near the bridge overpass and close to a parking garage. The only main issues was waiting for a long time even with a reservation, but they promptly served us some champagne to keep calm during the wait.

We got a few of the dishes including a halibut crusted with chorizo and pistachio, and the pappardelle pasta with seafood, potato beignets, and the polenta and fougasse (bread with bacon--so delicious).

Everything was spot on. Despite having a ridiculously small kitchen space, they manage to whip out amazing dishes that are sure to please your palate. Bring a date, or come with the girls--it's a great place!
author: Natalie M.

description:
This place was casual, yet fancy at the same time.
We walked in for a few drinks-the place was crowded and the guy at the bar was sassy. I couldn't tell if he was being rude or sarcastic half the time. I had one good glasses of wine and one ok beer. For a while the bottom area with the bar was quite packed. Once a big group left we were able to sit down. It was just hard to enjoy our drinks while it was so hot and crowded, but it was nice sitting there by the window.

The chickpea fries and sauce were good.
I wish we could have come back for dinner, but it did seem pretty pricey for small plates. 

The place wasn't exactly my style in the end.
author: Vicky S.

description: My boyfriend and I came here for dinner last night with another couple.  We made a reservation on opentable (easily accommodated).  They were very nice upon arrival and gave us the most amazing table upstairs by the open windows.  The whole restaurant looks like a little french cottage (both inside and out).  The staff were nice and friendly and made excellent recommendations.  They gave us a wine list with a million different types of wine, I didn't know which one to choose, so I said white, sparkling, and not sweet.  The waiter brought out a bottle that was imported from France and I must say it was the best wine I have ever had in my life.  The food was to die for, every plate had a burst of different flavors.  We ended the night with a chocolate cake which was served with a type of white foam that looked like ice cream.  I mixed my bite with that and a piece of chocolate cake, which came out to be a combination of sweet chocolate and white vanilla rosemary.  It was incredible.  Side note, the decor and pottery in the restaurant was just gorgeous.  Beautiful authentic plates with gold imprinted dandelions, created by the owner's wife.  The whole experience was truly amazing.  I will definitely be coming back and possibly have a small party upstairs in the future.  Highly recommended.
author: Greta K.

description: We found this restaurant in a roadtrip vacation on Yelp and it didn't disappoint. We were walking ins on a Saturday late night, we figured there wouldn't be tables. Medy the server/host from Marseille (I think that's how it's spell) was amazing. He sat us on the bar and recommended a great house wine and beer. He also picked out appetizers for us. We had foie gras, which is not our cup of tea but it was good. Best part was that the chef was right next to us and we got to see her in action. The couscous was beyond awesome and my husband had the sea bass, he was very happy. For dessert the chocolate truffles w chili.. So yummy
author: Jessica S.

description:
Definitely get in here soon to try the Foie Gras before they change their menu. Flawless flavor and textures! The confit pork belly had a nice balance of acidity from the vinaigrette cut with the richness of the pork and slow cooked egg  yolk. 

Had the sea bass and hanger steak mains. Loved the smoke potato/steak combination. Fish was cooked perfectly. All the food paired well with a Frank Family Zin.
author: Elliott M.

description:
Absolutely LOVED this little gem. 

A colleague and I were looking for a late dinner after a couple holiday parties. I called to be sure they were still open...a (French) restaurant open late night, 11pm during the week?! & they were, perfect!

The space is so intimate & warmly lit. We passed the tiniest kitchen on our way through the restaurant & up the stairs. Our (French) waiter was fantastic. Attentive, confident service. He recommended a beautiful bottle of wine & did a fantastic job making recommendations. We. Loved. Everything. 

Our appetizers were amazing, salad was perfect, and entrees were beyond. Complex flavors. I'm into it.

Also the setting is fantastic, I truly felt like I was back in Europe.

Living in Los Angeles, I'm not in San Francisco all that often, but I've already shared a similar review with family & friends.

The chef was actually kind enough to speak with us as we left. We thanked her for our outstanding meal & hope to go back next year. Enjoy!
author: Delaney O.

description:
Stumbled upon this place (thanks to Yelp and the close proximity to our hotel) and I couldn't be more pleased to have found It!

The atmosphere/decor/music - amazing. Perfect setting for your time spent here

The staff - lovely!! We had such great service and they helped us navigate the menu 

The food - DELICIOUS. We had the Pork Belly appetizer, the hanger steak and salmon for our mains and the custard for dessert. Every piece of each dish was so good. It's fresh and seasoned perfectly. 

Hands down recommend this restaurant if you want a cozy night eating amazing food.
author: Miriah R.

description:
Bouche is one of those spots that Yelp makes you excited for, but ends up failing to live up to the expectation. Maybe I went on an off night? Maybe my expectation was to high? However, in the end I think the food and service was good but not anything special that would make me want to come back for more. 

While the menu can largely be called French, I would venture to make the argument that it is French-inspired California cuisine. Certainly check out the appetizers as they are small bites that are good to share and showcase a variety of their cuisine. The salmon, poached egg, and creme fraiche was certainly a star with a balance of texture from the crispy noodles and the delicate raw salmon and flavor with from the saltiness of the egg and salmon complemented nicely from the sweetness in the creme fraiche. The sardine, grapefruit, and mint salad was a refreshing dish, however I personally like fish and even this was a lot of fish flavor to take in. The Octopus salad could use a little acid to combat the natural saltiness of octupi.

The lamb with onion marmalade was nothing to sneer at, however was just a tad overcooked for me. While it was very tender, the flavors were somewhat muddled by the onion and fresh parsley which took over as star of the show.

Dessert made me go "meh..." It clearly wasn't their forte, however the creme fraiche custard was ok and the pear tart with vanilla ice cream nothing to sneer at either. 

The small quaint feel and rustic charm of Bouche is its clear selling point. Its seating area is primarily upstairs overlooking the kitchen which adds to the intimate nature of the establishment. The service is good and reasonably attentive and helpful.

Overall, it was an ok meal. Nothing truly stellar or wow-ing. The food was good, service decent, and ambiance lovely. Short story: If you ever need a nice date night spot, Bouche is a great choice.
author: Chad Y.

description: Arrived late in San Francisco for business on a Wednesday night. So many restaurants closed at 10pm which was not going to help me. Found this restaurant by searching late night eats and they showed open until midnight. At this point I would have eaten anything, I was starving and needed a glass of wine to relax from travel. From the start of being welcomed by name when I arrived to the suggestion of wine, perfect. We order the chick pea fries with aioli OMG! Delicious. Then the crispy tussle spouts, phenomenal. And the main course Atlantic salmon over black lentils which was cooked to perfection.  This is a must go!!!   Small in size but cozy with great atmosphere. Thank you for a memorable meal.
author: Barb P.

description:
If you want to get seated, make a reservation. They have about 10 tables! There is also seating at the bar, which is the entire downstairs area, but people like to hangout and chill there and have a nice conversation and some wine, so it may be a long wait.

The people that own this tiny little place are very friendly and REALLY care about their restaurant, the food, and their customers. All I can say is, make a reservation or you're screwed!!! 

Wine here is good, bread is good... the FOOD. Oh my.. where do I begin??

HOUSE SMOKED SALMON POACHED EGG AND CREME FRAICHE- to die for. They give you a hefty amount of salmon, and the poached egg.. it's genius. All this on a bed of crispies.

We ordered from their entree menu. The serving size here is not big, but the flavors are impeccable and so delicate that you're easily satisfied with just that little bit of food. Both the salmon and lamb dishes were delicious, had their own distinct flavors, but the flavors are so intricate, similar to those of Michelin rated restaurants like Jean George.... The purees here are by FAR the best I've ever had. They have this interesting almost fluffy texture that's AMAZING.

I can't wait to come back time after time until I try everything on their menu!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Had a lamb dish that was great. Very well cooked, beautifully spiced and I would certainly eat again. 

A fantastic place if you want tasty food at a reasonable price point. 

Very homey and cozy. Great place for a nice bite to eat with a friend.
author: Steven W.

description: Took my girl out for her birthday. Could not have picked a better spot. Being from San Diego, I took a gamble and won. The setting was perfect. There are three people cranking out some of the best food I've had in a long time and their line is the size of my closet. I laughed at how well the bread crumbs worked on the hangar steak (fuckin genius) and the smashed red potatoes tasted like what I wish chicken nuggets tasted like. The confit pork belly app got the evening started right and we never looked back. The menu is small, which I prefer), yet the flavor achieved in each dish will blow you away. Bright, but homey. The service is amazing as well. The complete package
author: Sean S.

description: Came here for my birthday, which is also Bastille Day, and everything was absolutely out of this world. We were given an amuse, and tried the scallops (divine), and had a bottle of rose and dessert, all very reasonably priced. We got to sit upstairs and watch the Bastille Day festivities, and I would go back in a heartbeat. I want to try everything on the menu!!
author: Nicole P.

description: Only thing i liked was the wine. The service is ok, but he forgot our bread. The hanger steak was not tender. Pretty rubbery ($28).
author: Ellen K.

description:
4.5 STARS 

I don't trust food critics. 

When Chron's Michael Bauer called Zero Zero: "The French Laundry of Pizzas", I wanted to take a hit from the same pipe he was smoking because their limp Neapolitan pizzas with soggy centers were anything but. I guess he's use to limp things. I'm not. 

Opening in December 2011, Bouche is a tiny two-story restaurant with a small, tapas style Provencal menu. Formerly a chef at the two Michelin starred Coi, Chef Nicolas Borzee's dishes were foodgasmic from start to finish despite the naysayers of Bauer and the likes. Plating could have been better for some dishes but nonetheless the execution was near perfection and the flavors didn't disappoint.

F O O D
Keeping in mind that portions are tapas sized, order at least 2 dishes per a person if you want to leave satisfied. Sorry, it's very dimly in Bouche hence the poor quality food pictures. 

*OCTOPUS w/ Summer Squash Salad, Dandelion Salsa Verde & Sesame Crumbs ($12) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bouche-san-francisco?select=GLvujAqgziKmu4221IyWhg#UjwQ9BM7lgDBcW0NqkYsMw
Refreshing and light, the crispness of the squash, the tenderness of the octopus and crunch from the sesame crumbs gave me mouth a nice play on various yet similar textures. The salsa verde gave the octopus a nice acidic punch. 

*MARINATED SALMON w/ Poached Egg & Crème Fraiche ($15) - 5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bouche-san-francisco?select=GLvujAqgziKmu4221IyWhg#GLvujAqgziKmu4221IyWhg
A dish you will not want to share, the smoked salmon along with the creamy egg yolk, and crispy strips of phyllo dough was absolutely genius and insanely delicious. 

*LAMB SHOULDER w/ Almond & Onion Marmalade and Carrot & Coriander Puree ($22) - 4.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bouche-san-francisco?select=GLvujAqgziKmu4221IyWhg#UuimEL2EopTit1WefAF3Rw
What the dish lacked in the presentation, it made up in taste. The lamb shoulder was incredibly soft and tender with the marmalade adding a delectable nutty sweetness to the lamb. 

*ROASTED BERKSHIRE PORK BELLY w/ Confit Pork Shoulder, Potato Puree & Yellow Chanterelles ($25) - 5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bouche-san-francisco?select=GLvujAqgziKmu4221IyWhg#PSlqvEv8Lu6tjFS7rYQV0A
Spruce's Pork Belly dish was my favorite of all time until Bouche's stole my heart, rather my stomach. The way pork belly should be eaten every time, the skin was sinfully crunchy and the meat was like butter as if it was sous-vide for hours. The confit was as tender as slow cooked pulled pork. Completing this phenomenal epicurean dish were the chanterelles giving an earthy comfort. 

*CRÈME FRAICHE CUSTARD w/ Sea Salted Caramel Sauce ($7) - 5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bouche-san-francisco?select=GLvujAqgziKmu4221IyWhg#YwaQHoYOzOrqhWVw6AaBVg
A dessert that will appease sweet and salty addicts, the milky custard was velvety smooth with a salty sweet decadence from the caramel sauce that took this over the top. Simple yet oh so good. 

S E R V I C E
Service was timely and attentive though could use a bit more warmth. It would have been nice to been checked on more often to ensure the food was to our liking; it was but being more personable is a big plus for me. 

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Country rustic with creaking wooden stairway and faded brown walls, Bouche is a small two-story restaurant with counter seating in front of an open kitchen and just 5 cramped tables in the loft area.

P A R K I N G
Sutter-Stockton garage is just half a block away at the back Bush street entrance. 

Bauer and company gave Bouche just two out of four stars. They must have never had a foodgasm before or any "gasms" for that matter. Poor baby. *SAD POUTY LIP*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This stands out as the most authentic French restaurant experience I've had outside of France, ever.  

There are a few drawbacks: The space is tiny.  The dining area has really, really low light (they could do with about double the amount of light output).  The tables are pretty close together.  I realize they're doing what they can with the space they have, but these things still take away from the overall experience, albeit in a small way.

But aside from that, you're looking at an amazing meal.  I started with the charcuterie plate which was almost exactly what you'd get in France; various types of pate beautifully presented.  Not all of it was to my liking, but that's not the restaurant's fault.  My companion had the lamb and bacon crepinette which was declared wonderful.

The mains arrived; I had the duck breast.  It was in the top three duck dishes I've ever had, ever.  My companion's rock cod was amazing...I'm not a huge cooked fish fan but I would have been elated with ordering that dish.  Truly great.

Dessert time rolls around and I order the creme fraiche custard (with a side of homemade caramel) and my friend has the toasted fig leaf ice cream.  Neither dish sounds particularly great, but they tasted otherworldly.  The custard stands as one of the best desserts I've eaten in years, and my friend's ice cream was also extremely good.  

The prices were very reasonable considering the quality of the food,  The service was good, albeit a tad on the slow side (but very French in that respect).

The food warrants a full five stars, but the drawbacks mentioned above do warrant an adjustment to the score on the overall experience.
author: Ben G.

description:
Exactly what you'd expect from a small French restaurant with less than 10 tables: Exceptional atmosphere, great service and good food. Here's the rundown:
 - Scallop Carpaccio: (A-) simple but good
 - Pork Belly: (B+) I generally despise Pork Belly but surprising enjoyed their crispy version
 - Braised Pork Shoulder: (B) bit of a miss
 - Seared Duck Breast: (B+) worth trying

Generally, I only give 4 stars to places I really want to come back to, which isn't the case here. If only Yelp would let me throw a 3.5 down. 

I'd file this as worth trying once if you're a local, but not on the shortlist if you're from out of town.
author: Jeff F.

description:
After a day of looking around for a nice place to have dinner we got the tip about Bouche from a waiter at another French restaurant, so it must be good we thought.

It was awesome!!! The waiter was so nice, helpful and courteous. The food was so awesome I felt bad when I was finished because I knew it was over. The wine recommendation from the waiter was a great wine matching exactly what we were looking for, and still being one of the cheaper wines which was great because it showed us that the waiter really cared about being helpful and not just about selling the most.

I would totally recommend this place. For the price of what you would pay on a nice chain restaurant you get a personalized experience and awesome food.
author: Juan O.

description:
Oh my God...this place must be authentic since the employees speak like, French and stuff.

After arriving promptly for what we thought was our 6:00 PM dinner reservation, we realized that we didn't book a table after all (not my fault...duh!). I was seething at my dinner date until the host told us he would try to seat us even though the restaurant was fully booked that night. The power of bitch face is amazing.

At our upstairs table, I tried the duck confit croquants, scallop and custard with salted caramel sauce. Every dish tasted rich and flavorful, and the experience was reminiscent of my time in France. I only wish I had concluded my meal with doing something super French...like douching.
author: Suany W.

description: I landed in San Francisco at around 11 and my boyfriend and I were trying to find a place that was still open! I didn't know San Fran closed so early but Bouche was there! They closed at 1 so we walked over from our hotel to this place. The place was basically empty except for another couple drinking some wine but we decided to sit at the bar. The server was very nice and gave us complimentary glass of wine! What a great way to start our vacation! We ordered a few more glasses of their red wine. They had a good selection of by the glass wines. The food was quick and it was an open kitchen concept. I loved how intimate and dark it was it definitely made it more romantic. I'm so happy I came here and I would recommend this to anyone in the area! They also take reservations so I'm assuming they get pretty crowded for normal humans hours and not at around midnight the time we came in so make sure to make a reservation!
author: Ashley N.

description: This was a hidden gem we stumbled on. We sat at the bar and got to watch the chefs in action, such a treat! I can't say enough how superb the whole experience was... One of the best meals I've had in a while- everything was so fresh and the taste combinations were inventive and delightful! Felt like we were in a Paris bistro, small place with lots going on, selective menu with just a few dishes, but every selection was superb- the menu changes constantly with the seasons, begging you to return over and over...
author: Amy W.

description:
My friend and I had the most amazing dinner here! Bouche is a very cute restaurant on Bush and Stockton. The first floor has counter seats but the 2nd floor has tables.

The menu is small - just 5-6 appetizers, 4 entrees, and a few sides.

Since it was our first time here, we went with the salmon and pork belly, with a side of polenta, at the suggestion of our waiter.

The salmon is marinated and comes on a bed of fried stringy things, poached egg, and creme fraiche. The mix of textures was great. The creme fraiche was light and didn't overpower the light marinade of the salmon.

The pork belly came with caramelized mushrooms and a puree of some kind. The pork belly had both lean and fat, and the flavors of the mushrooms balanced the puree.

The polenta was creamy and rich. It's a really big portion, so it's best to split it.

Our dinner was really filling and delicious, and neither of us could eat much more, but we got the plum tart... and it was AMAZING! It wasn't like a traditional tart with a thick crust and fruit filling. It had some kind of marscapone filling with a thin layer of plum plum jelly. One of the best desserts I've ever had!

Definitely coming back to try the cod and the sardine appetizer.
author: Sherry L.

description:
From the tiny kitchen the chef and her two associates create wonderful food! This place overall is small or cozy depending on your perspective. The hostess seated me at the bar, just fine for one person. The server was great recommending wine. I opted for the pork belly appetizer and the beef entree and he asked if I would be having more than one glass when I said no he recommended a wine that would work with both and it did! I savored every bite of both dishes! So tasty! I decided to order dessert and chose the Cotton Candy Grapes and Melon. It was not only beautiful, but also refreshing and complex for a fruit dessert. 

This restaurant is going on my list for my next visit!
author: W B.

description: I took my wife here for our Anniversary dinner. We ordered the chick pea fries and crispy sweetbreads for starters. For the main dish, I ordered the swordfish and my wife ordered the hangar steak. We also ordered the custard for dessert. We both ordered a glass of wine. The food was excellent! All of it! The different flavors and textures in the food blended so well that it left you wanting more. The service was great. The waiter was very knowledgable about the food and took the time to answer our questions. The place is small and menu is limited, but the food made it worth it. Make sure to make a reservation. I highly recommend this place!
author: Joe R.

description: This chef is insane. The food is soooooo good, down to every single last plating detail, obvious or seemingly strange. The atmosphere is quaint and intimate, perfect for a romantic date nite. The prices are a little on the higher side, but for the amount and quality you get, it's well worth the splurge. Treat yo'self. Nom nom nom nom
author: Alexis V.

description:
Overpriced.  For a city with amazing food, pass this one up.

Just for kicks we tried dessert. Seriously; awful, not even remotely good. Their version of rice pudding is a scoop of under cooked rice in a bowl a grape syrup. 

Keep looking, this place looks charming, but the overpriced shit on a plate leaves me feeling like I got robbed.
author: Shane B.

description: Charming, delicious, and open late. The highlight of dinner was the beef main course; the poached chicken just didn't compare. I will certainly be back.
author: David S.

description:
Food was good.

Atmosphere not so good, very small cramped place. Loud rock music.

Service was terrible. I was not allowed to sit at the bar even though there were two empty places.
I had to sit at a cramped  counter, elbow to elbow
with the stranger next time.
Five minutes later there were four seats open at the bar and they stayed that way until I finished eating 
half hour later.

The wait person asked if I wanted bread and butter. 
I said yes. It never arrived.
author: Ken C.

description:
Two visits now.  The first was frightening, one of my party and myself having an acute session of driving the porcelain bus about one hour after the check.  The second visit, no technicolor yawn, but the fare remains forgettable. 

One reviewer nailed it on the wine - after our first bottle of marginally passable Vin de pays something from Bordeaux?, my naive host asked for a recommendation for something reasonable from Burgundy and, surprise! we got a bottle of sh!tty chilled Beaulojais!!  And of course as the temperature rose, it was Cold Duck at it's worst (made me think of the fictitious Algerian red Ian Fleming's character called "the Infuriator"; [v. subtle hint]).

In summary, when there are so many offerings in a destination city with a sophisticated resident population, a choice like or Sociale or Chapeau is a much better bet.  I'm so jaded with the cheap strategy of screwing the tourists who must pretend that they've had the most awesome meal in San Francisco evah! (see my Facebook posting!!).  That's how I rate Bouche, they give you the illusion of the experience and dare you to call out the mediocrity of their performance.
author: PeterDragon D.

description:
We had a great experience at the tiny Bouche that we've walked by before and didn't even know was there.  My co-worker ate here recently and loved it so it solidified our decision to try it out.

Our waiter was friendly but unfortunately very forgetful as we had to ask about certain dishes that we had ordered.  But the food made up for it.  We started with the chickpea fries which were great and the sauce really made it.  We also had the fried pork belly to start and it was delicious.  

For our main meal I had the rock cod and it was prepared perfectly.  Sitting on potatoes and with some sausage made the meal.  My wife had the duck breast with duck confit and green beans and farro. I had a few tastes and it was great.  

We ended with a cheese plate which we typically never do and for dessert we got the chocolate tarte which was rich and good.

Great date spot!
author: Blake B.

description:
When I walked in I thought to myself "Damn this place is small."  But there is seating upstairs. 

Menu had 5 apps and 4 entrees.     
That tells me this place is legit 
And it was.
author: John R.

description:
Absolutely amazeballs. The space is very well designed and laid-out for being so tiny and the food delivers on all sides: flavor, texture, quality and uniqueness. It's French operated and so by far one of the best French meals I've had in a long time.

Duck breast with duck confit - confit was to die for - and the flat iron steak with gratin and sauteed veggies had so many different layers to it, it kept the tastebuds engaged! Crispy pork belly is a must order item! and the poached egg broken into the greens and dressing with strawberries was perfectly balanced. Our wine recommendation was also spot on and the service was just the right amount of timing between dishes and check-ins. Great spot and I love that it's relatively hidden.
author: Alita M.

description: A bigger bunch of arrogant assholes have never graced the face of this earth, I went as a single diner, well dressed in a shirt and coat and was treated with disdain from the minute I walked in, offered only a table at the bar although the place was, now unsurprising nearly empty. Shortly after ordering a beer I was pressed to order my dinner, not having been given a menu, I asked for one, eye roll was the response, so, after ordering dry bread and frozen butter is offered, when I complained about the rock hard butter the hands on hips retort of "it's not frozen mate" was enough for me to walk out.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Super cute late night spot. Seating is tight and the kitchen is even tighter. The food Quality is by far the best you can get for late night cuisine,  very fresh. 

The salad was superb, very lively and colorful.  The hand made plates added a nice charm and the steak was excellent. The pricing is also very reasonable in my opinion.
author: Caitlin S.

description:
The boyfriend made a surprise reservation here to celebrate my big move to SF. We had a 7:45pm reservation, but when we arrived, we didn't get seated until 8:20pm. They kept apologizing for the wait, but made no effort to make it up to us (I'll get to that later). The place itself is really small, dark and cozy. It would make a great first date spot. They have large windows that overlook Bush St for people watching as well.

Prior to the entrees, the waiter gave us some complimentary cold bread and butter. After we devoured the initial bread, the waiter came around and gave us some fresh warm bread with bits of bacon in it. This was delicious! We thought it was complimentary because of the long wait, but when the check came, they charged us $5 for the "fougasse" aka bacon bread. I'm deducting one star for making us wait half an hour past our reservation and another star for trying to charge us for something we didn't order! 

There are only 4 entree options on the menu. We ordered the salmon and wagyu beef. The salmon was delicious, and the portion was very generous. The wagyu was basically 5 thin slices of beef on top of some veggies. This was rather disappointing, not to mention, super salty. Also, I noticed people around me were cutting off the outer parts of the beef because it was fatty. I thought of doing that too, but at $30 for a few slabs of meat, I would have ended up with almost nothing to eat. To be fair, I've never been a fan of French food. I was hoping this place would change that for me, but unfortunately, I left unsatisfied. 

Overall, this was a mediocre introduction to SF dining. However, I applaud the boyfriend for putting in the effort to plan a romantic evening.
author: Joyce S.

description:
How this place has 21 reviews and had 4.5 Stars BAFFLES me.
* the first several 5 star reviews on this page are all from people who have under 5 reviews & no picture. if you're a true Yelper, you already know wassup. 

I rarely write bad reviews for places but this is one of them.

It's a very tiny spot and easy to miss. Bar style seating downstairs and a tiny dining area upstairs (overlooking the teenssy kitchen and all the piping) Sorry but for a place that tries to make itself seem fancy, that's just a big no-no. I don't want to see your blackened stove and the grease in your fryer. Carol L (see review below) was one the girlfriends I came here with for our Christmas dinner. 

The server took us upstairs to be seated and there was already a party of 3 sitting by the wall, so any normal person would assume since the place is basically empty, he would seat you AWAY from them by the windows. You know, the common sense thing where you don't cram 7 people into one corner of this tiny deck? NOPEE. He makes us seat directly next to the other table overlooking the ledge of the deck. The chairs are so wide we had difficulty getting into our seats and by anyone's standards, we're pretty skinny. Plus there was the whole inconvenience of the guy who looked like a twig taking up 3/4 of our shared space with his chair. To add insult to injury, the waiter told us that the other tables were being reserved for couples who were coming. He said reserved, as in implied pre-bookings, not their delusional thoughts that 8 random couples would walk in to fill up the rest of the deck.

Food: MEHHH !!! For a fancy meal, you know some of that cost just goes purely into the fact that you're eating there like buying something designer. Tiny portions that could not be justified by price or taste. Their only salvation was the desserts which were unique. The Milk Chocolate & Caramelized Hazelnut was very good. 

Service was mediocre. I felt like we paid tip, because he had to bring our lukewarm food up a flight of stairs. So honestly, there are at least 100 places more worth your time and money in the Union Square/Downtown/FiDi area.
author: Jenn Y.

description: We like the pork belly and scallop appetizers. The hanger steak was also cooked perfectly. Great vibes and a good place to dine and hang out with friends and family.
author: Elly G.

description:
My wife and I went here for our anniversary. Being so close to the financial district worried me about tourists skewing the reviews. 4 stars is too much credit for the great restaurants of SF. 

As other reviewers noted, this is not "traditional" french food...But I don't want your opinion if you expect hamburger and fries from every "American" restaurant. I want creativity and good food. Bouche does this well with their apps, like the bacon bread. What is disappointing is not the portions of the main course, but the effort that the portions reflect. My wife ordered chicken and I ordered steak. They were cooked well, but that's all they were; just a couple strands of broccoli and meat. Not creative like the apps and if we had not ordered apps, the portions would be extremely disappointing. 

What threw us off was when I ordered a Bordeaux, which they ran out of. I asked for a similar wine and was served a chilled red wine. Some people may serve wine cooler, but an honest winemaker will tell you this is because you'll taste less of this bad wine. The wine was sour by the time it warmed up. The waiter let us down. I am satisfied with the restaurant, but this should not be on your bucket list. They need to think about how to spice up their main course.
author: Djjr R.

description:
We just finished eating here and it was fantastic! We sat at the "chef's table" (pretty much a bar looking into the tiny kitchen) which gives you a perfect view of your food being prepared.

The atmosphere is energetic while the service is friendly and professional.

I'd definitely recommend checking out Bouche if you enjoy outstanding food in a hole-in-the-wall (but professional) environment!

Bon appétit!
author: Blair G.

description: Bouche never fails me when I need a tasty, quality dinner later in the evening. The seating can be limited sometimes but the service and menu make it worth the wait. Definitely one of my bf's and my favorites.
author: Lyn D.

description: Very nouveau-French and very very good. Attentive service, fine wine list (all French), and a limited but wonderfully prepared menu. Tried the chick pea fries as an appetizer, the citrus salad, the hanger steak, and sword fish entrees with chocolate truffle dessert to send us on our way - all delicious and to be remembered. Take a walk from your Unions Square hotel. You will not be disappointed.
author: Alan S.

description:
Excellent food in a small, romantic, intimate restaurant. The menu is short but intriguing, the wine list complete without being overly long.

Best dish we had: an appetizer of Tartare.

We were served efficiently and gently.

Not a cheap place at all, but in the end we were satisfied with our choice.
author: Stefano Z.

description:
Bouche is my favorite restaurant in the entire San Francisco! 
Don't make any assumptions about dishes you see on the menu!!! 
You have never tried anything like it!!!
Every dish has its own special flavor  and is VERY different from common  perception of a similar dish. 

You just have to try it here to understand, and I hope you do :)
author: Sandy K.

description: The Panisses (chick pea fries) make me want to become a vegitarian. Such a quaint place, great atmosphere, awesome food and staff make you feel welcome. The Wagyu beef culotte makes me want to come back. Found this place on Open Table.
author: Jodi P.

description:
New Favorite to add in SF!

Though I admit my expertise is Italian I really enjoyed this place.

The fries are amazing, and are a must try! Never had anything quite like them, very unique.  The bacon bread is as good as can be expected.  The pork belly was yummmmm..

The entrees of the steak and pork were great. The different sides of b sprouts and other grilled veggies went perfect.

The place was a little tight, but comfortable decor.

The service was good.  Not over the top friendly at all times, but not even close to being as bad as some reviews had mentioned.  Remember they speak French as their first language. Which I prefer for a French restaurant :)

Ciao!
author: Mike M.

description:
Are you looking for a pretty good dinner to start your fun evening in San Francisco? Are also looking for a worthwhile place to spend a good amount of money on some tasty and good quality food? Well, this place has your answer. I am giving this place a really high rating out of some mercy because I thought I had one of the most tastiest dinners at an excellent location along with some great service that actually exceeded my expectations. If you are looking for a big dinner, this may not be the right place, but you should have a big lunch or be prepared to have a tasty late evening meal later in the evening. 

Bouche is the French word for mouth, and when I left, I thought my mouth was very happy after that dinner, as if you got a second chance to encounter that kind but gorgeous lady you really wanted to talk to after a really long period of time and the encounter was a stunning and thrilling success, leading you to think: "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"

I had the Citrus and Honey Confit Lamb Shank. To be honest, it was probably the second best lamb dish that I have ever eaten within the past six years. That was how good it was. The flavor had the right amount of sweetness and it was still savory, and at the same time, the tenderness was just right. The ratatouille and couscous had an amazing blend of flavor that made this dish delicious and tasted very well with the lamb. The dish was not too expensive, probably at about $30. It should be enough for a light dinner, but an excellent one. 

The dessert was also pretty good, and if you need to get your stomach fuller, the Creme Fraiche Custard is a good option. The creaminess and the texture was excellent. The flavor was not too sweet. 

As for the service, the waiters were very friendly and knowledgeable. I was able to have a great conversation with Guillaume, the owner and he was very friendly and very committed to listening to any concerns you have. You don't really have to dress nice at this place, but you still can dress a little casual, and you still need to look fine at the same time. The interior is not very upscale, but not very casual with the wooden chairs, but overall, the interior still looks nice. It is also small, so at the most, you can have six people. It is a nice atmosphere for a dinner appointment with your companion or a couple cool buddies and a few great companions. 

You may need to get a reservation, but coming later in the evenings at 9:00 PM should be fine. They are open late until 1 AM, so you could get a lot of drinks from their wine bar and also a tasty dinner after a night out in the city. It is at a great location, not too far from Union Square. 

Overall, I thought I had one of the tastiest and possibly memorable fine dinners in San Francisco so far. If you are looking to "kick start" an ideal, great and adventurous evening with your friends in a fun city like San Francisco, wine from the wine bar at this place and a great dinner is not a bad choice. After that, hopefully your evening will get better and better.
author: Ambrose C.

description:
I agree with fellow yelpers.  YUM.
the duck is great / I will order it again and again.  
the bone marrow was extremely flavorful, already scooped out for you.  the crispy pork was alright, but well presented.

my gf and I sat upstairs and by the looks of it we were the only ones not on a date.

as much as I love the tiny place and intimate setting, it isn't for everyone.

don't come if you are in a rush or have a large group or have loud people in your party.  otherwise everyone will hear your convo.

if you have to wait for a table, go next door to tunnel top bar for some fresh fruit cocktails.. they are really good!
author: Mabel F.

description: Romantic, friendly, and great food. You can only reserve tables upstairs where what appears cramped becomes cozy upon being seated. Bouche takes advantage of every inch of space, including one of the smallest exhibition kitchens I've seen, which uses ninth pans and shelves to maximize what looked like 100 sf of usable area. No wonder the menu is so limited, there's no room for ingredients! But each of the selections we had was exquisite (pork belly app, spinach salad and pork loin) and authentic to the atmosphere and service. All of it charming and fun. We felt transported to a rustic, timeless French inn.
author: Todd L.

description: My girlfriend and I were in San Francisco for a few days to see the San Francisco Ballet and when we were looking for relatively fine dining and everywhere we found was closed really early. We happened to come across Bouche as an option. So after the ballet we arrived at Bouche and were immediately greeted by a welcoming gentleman who asked us where we were coming from and seated us promptly in the front which was very nice. Then within a couple minutes another kind gentleman asked us if we knew what we wanted to drink or eat. We were still looking over the wine menu but we knew what we wanted to eat (Hangar steak for me and Salmon for my girlfriend, both were amazing) when we told him what we wanted to eat he asked us a couple questions to give us a wine which paired well with what we were eating. Came promptly with the wine which was paired just as well as the food tasted. After we ate we ordered dessert and some dessert wine which were both delicious as well! When we received the check he told us that one of the dessert wines was on the house! And for the money it is worth every penny. If you have a chance to stop in here it is definitely worth it!!!
author: Austin M.

description:
Recommend to us, my wife and I, by our concierge. 

Cute building with maybe 7 tables on the second floor. Friendly wait staff. 

Started with the porkbelly and bacon bread. Both were outstanding. 

We shared the halibut and a steak entree and we were both very impressed. Not too much sauce and cooked perfectly. 

Ended the meal sharing a raspberry tart. Almost like a cheesecake texture but not too rich. 

The meal with two glasses of wine was around $125. We splurged but it was the first meal on our honeymoon. 

Was well worth the money and we would highly recommend for a date night!
author: Dan F.

description:
What an idiot I am... I thought I was lucky to catch the last open spot at Sons & Daughters for Valentine's day, but it turns out I booked a month later (3/14). Disappointed, yet patient gf checks yelp for near by restaurants. After each of us called a few restaurant, Bouche at 0.2 mils away told us they can seat us at the counter. So we said "BE THERE IN ONE MINUTES!" and we did.

The server welcomed us with a big smile and seated us at the counter overseeing the kitchen. Very nice modern industrial decors with nice and warm ambient.

The fixed vday menu was a 3 course meal and dessert with two options for each course so we opted to try each one. We tasted a few wines and settled for two glasses of whites since the set menu was centered around oceanic ingredients.

Amuse Bouche Imperial Oyster, Uni and Caviar - Honestly the uni and caviar was too little that they did not come alive. I like the concept of mixing the creaminess of uni with oyster though.

1st: Truffle Poached Quail Egg, Chicory Salad - nice warm salad with fresh ingredients. quail egg added a good creaminess to the refreshing and subtle dressing.

1st; Lobster and prawn creamy bisque, crab salad - very creamy lobster bisque, but the flavor was much heavier on the smoky prawn side. Prawn is cooked to perfection. Crispy shell and tender tail.

2nd: Smoked duck Carpaccio - nicely smoked. I liked the slightly chewy texture and the just right amount of savoriness cured in.

2nd: Avocado and Crab Napoleon - This one was alright. the crab was very nicely flavored and the portion was generous. However avocado over powered the rest of the flavors. Avocado is hard to control though.

3rd: Seared Scallop, parnip puree and tarragon sauce - Best dish of the night. You can't beat a good scallop seared to perfection with the right green herbal sauce. Crispy outside and tender and moist inside.

3rd: Venison Loin, black truffle, wild cherry jus - Venison wasn't too gamy and the cherry sauce was well done, deglazing the jus of venison into a hearty sauce that is not overly sweet nor bitter.

Dessert: Chai tiramisu - I love tiramisu, but this one was not the best. Still it was nice.

Dessert: Foundant au chocolat - I'm not a dessert person, but the warm foundant was good. My gf loved it.

Bouche saved my v-day and gave us a very warm and nice French dinner with local twist. Also a rose from the owner was a nice touch. 

Merci Beaucoup, a la Bouche
author: Lance C.

description:
This place is adorable. Delicious french food without the pretentiousness, very SF without the...pretentiousness. haha.  

Nestled above the stockton tunnel, the facade is small and homey.  Definitely get a table upstairs - overlooks the street and is very romantic. Perfect for a date. The restaurant is dim and the tables are close together - you can definitely hear other people's conversations (not great, but kind of funny).

We didn't get the shoulder of lamb as many diners suggested (neither my bf and I are huge fans of lamb). But we did go crazy on the appetizers and he got the snapper (it was ok).

Hits: bacon fougasse. Best bread you'll ever try.  Huge too. The loaf was probably enough for 4. Except we got 1 between the two of us. And I think the restaurant made a mistake and gave us a second loaf.  We couldn't help ourselves and ate 50% of the second loaf as well. The food coma that ensued was neither slight nor painless. 

dungeness crab mash was delicious.  Scallop appetizer was good but not a good value. 1 giant scallop for $15. Beef tartare was surprisingly fantastic - I'm surprised more people haven't mentioned it in their reviews.  It's the best seasoning I've had in a beef tartare.  Definitely recommended.

Wine pours are as big as they come and service was impeccable - laid back and authentic without "bothering" you.
author: Alice Z.

description: This is the best restaurant in San Francisco. Seriously. Had dinner here with Alton brown and literally heard him moan with pleasure at the hanger steak. Unbelievable...
author: Matt K.

description: We holidayed in SF for a week, and enjoyed my partner's birthday diner at Bouche.Our hotel was up the road, we walked past one day and loved the look and ambience of the restaurant, I checked the reviews, and immediately booked on line. We wanted a "fine" dining experience without all the pretence, and a more casual atmosphere, Bouche lived up to the expectation, excellent food, well presented, and fun to eat/share. The only disappointment was it was a bit "squashy" and tables too close to each other, we also selected a Brouilly wine, and it wasn't good, it shouldn't have been on the wine list.
author: Anja A.

description: We came to Bouche recommended by a local friend to dine before Hamilton. (We parked 50 feet away in a public garage and then walked 20 min to and from the theatre, how convenient is that.) I would describe Bouche as a shabby chic and groovy french bistro. Upstairs has tables and the downstairs has bar seating only which is where we preferred to dine. The menu is limited but absolutely enough with fantastic offerings that I assume change all the time. The brussel sprouts were to die for and my hangar steak was cooked to perfection with smoked, petite potatoes out of this world. My husband's salmon was cooked perfectly. (Salmon is easy to overcook. The chocolate truffle type dessert was out of this world. My description of the food doesn't imply unique, but it was. Service was spot on. We'll be back for sure....
author: Irene C.

description: Took my mom here to celebrate her birthday. Food was yummy. Our waiter suggested a perfect wine to go with my meal.
author: Jane W.

description:
tiny, intimate French restaurant. easy to walk right by if you aren't looking for it. there are only a few tables so reservations are highly recommended, but they take walkins and there are some (less than 20 by my estimate) counter seating with the full menu service.  no full-service liquor, but nice selection of french wines. I forgot to look at the beer menu. a small open kitchen on the ground floor. the tables are upstairs.

the menu is small, but has enough choices (at least for us). we started with a beet salad which was perfect for sharing. we shared two mains, chicken breast and waygu beef. normally I wouldn't order chicken in a nice restaurant but the French really do chicken well. I wasn't disappointed. the breast was perfectly cooked, moist and with plenty of flavor. the beef was excellent, thin sliced and delicious!

service was very good. since we were having both fowl and beef, I figured a glass of red burgundy would be okay and took the waiter's suggestion, but I didn't like it. he described it as peppery but I found it too metallic. I wasn't going to make a big deal of it, but he asked if I liked it and I was honest and said "not really, but it's fine" and he took the glass and said he would like to buy another one for me and suggested a rhone which was much more to my liking. service (to me) is almost as important as the food. bad service can ruin a good meal and this is the type of experience that will have me returning.
author: Bob U.

description:
Wow a fantastic french restaurant.  We have been to a number of nice french places in SF and the Valley and Bouche is one of the best we have been too.

Started with the Bone Marrow.  We have had Bone Marrow dishes all over the world and this was the most flavorful delicious we had.

We then had the Duck and Fish.  Both were wonderful great tastes and wonderful texture.   This is clearly a go to place in San Francisco.  

Park in the Sutter Garage.
author: Amber L.

description:
I checked this place out on a recent business trip to San Fran. I have to say, the experience was as if a bunch of little kids were trying to run a high-end restaurant. The host (very nice guy) ran around like a chicken without a head performing damn-near acrobatics up and down the stairway from the bar area I was seated at, to the upstairs dining area. It was busy, but Manhattan restaurants get even busier and I usually don't witness such theatrics in comparable NYC restaurants. Also, the host and staff seemed to be torn between servicing patrons and greeting/ hanging out with their friends. A little bit too pricey for that lack of professionalism. 

Onto the food. Fresh, yes and prepared by a gregarious chef behind the bar. But a tad over-salted and certainly nothing remarkable. I had a nice salad and some risotto-like grain dish that was a little over-cooked to the point it tasted on the gummy side. 

San Fran, you are a beautiful city and certainly cleaner than Manhattan. But the food of your "buzzed" about restaurants is not quite up to NYC standards yet. Nice people, though.
author: Samara L.

description:
Ambience - 4 stars. Small and intimate. Very simple

Service - 3.5 stars. They did their job, but didn't go out of their way in any way. 

Food - 3 stars. Everything was beyond salty. The scallops, the sole and even the steak! The vegetables were inedible salty.

Portion - 2 stars. $16 for two scallops. Steak and fish were both very small. 

In summary, it was very expensive for the quality and portion. We were so hungry we had to go eat a second dinner.
author: Fanny C.

description: Bouche is a tiny bistro that sits on top of the stockton tunnel and is perhaps one of the best French American restaurants ive ever eaten. I had actually not had a whole lot of French cuisine lately, San Francisco has steadily been moving away from that flavor and ive been moving with the crowd. However i had the priviledge to walk in with four friends at about 1 am after we had left work and were fortunate enough to be guided to a table at a time when the rest of that neighborhoods kitchens are already asleep. Good hospitality counts for a lot, right, and ive worked that late night shift before and know how much it sucks to be closing up and have 5 a-holes walk in yelling for food. So kudos, guys! Service was excellent, the staff knowledgable about the entire menu, all questions answered perfectly. The food was were I was certainly impressed. We had the luck to also have our rich doctor friend with us who in, show off cause i can, fashion, had to order about two of everything on the menu (Thanks for reminding me im poor, dick.). But back to the food. The chef at bouche has to be some sort of mad scientist or somwthing because the hot line at bouche is despicably tiny, and the kitchen staff cramped, and almost in the dark, but the quality and volune of the menu is equal to that found in restaurants with 2-3 times the space. Then of course since we had two of everything coming i got to taste the second plate of every dish one more time, and, it was all the same, to every detail, so to the kitchen staff and chef at bouche, thanks for an awesome meal i think only another former chef can appreciate, I really hope you guys keep it up!
author: Cameron Y.

description:
There's just something charming about a San Francisco rained upon, or perhaps its simply in my imagination, one charmed by the rain and fog in general.  But in either case a certain mood is set in the soul sitting upstairs in a dimly lit cafe, the soft rain pattering outside while warmth and food is brought to you.

Bouche has an older-time feel to it, almost cinematic in its setup, dark and moody but French and charming, in that French way if you can believe.  The waiter is a tad imposing, large and a bit frequent in trying to force an order, but pleasantly rare after.  I made reservations (though I needn't have for this rainy Sunday morning), and even parking proved not too challenging, quiet feat on its own.  But in any case the menu was small enough to be a right-of-passage, us eventually settling on three items while mentally nothing that we'd probably, like any good hobbit, require a second breakfast.  Translation: expected tiny portions.

Fresh Fruit Bellini 10
Charming, simple, light.  It would take fifty of these for me to feel a buzz, though I would sadly grow tired of it long before then.  But one?  Sweet and supple, water on the side much appreciated.

Roasted Banana and Peanut Butter Beignets, Preserved Straberries 12
The first plate to arrive, the beignets, were visually obviously handmade and pleasantly light, too.  They're a bit like donuts, the peanut butter not too strong at all much to my pleasure, while the banana flavor proved subtle but more notable.  Despite its lightness, it's a tad strong as a sole opener, though probably too subtle as a dessert.

Scallop Crudo, Pomelo and Grapefruit, Prawns, Apple Slaw 15
Indeed the scallops are fresh though thinly sliced, the rest of the dish dwarfing it in comparison; this doesn't say much as the portioning itself is on the small side, but it is overall good and balanced to some degree, lighter in taste than the others presented, as would be hoped for in a seafood dish.

Hand Cut Beef Tenderloin Tartar, Basil and Parmesan Pesto, Fingerling Chips 15
There's always a bit of an odd feeling when green is combined with a meat of any kind, especially one that leans more to the rare side than well done.  Unless of course it's dragon.  But moving past that major aesthetic flaw, this dish proved to be my favorite in taste, perhaps the most balanced in flavor profile altogether.  The chips are housemade and remind of me Zanzibar Cafe in San Diego; the basil and parmesan make an excellent accompaniment to the finger food.

The soft conversation, helped by there being only three or four occupied tables throughout, provides a nice atmosphere of peace.  There isn't much space in the restaurant or on the tables, or to be honest much on the plates anyway, but we managed to walk out of the restaurant full enough not to get that second breakfast, as marginal as the first was.  But the food was overall well prepared, so I can't quite give the restaurant a stark 'no', only a slight warning that you'll perhaps have a small bite beforehand, or easily spend upwards of $50 a head...on breakfast.
author: Christopher P.

description:
I don't usually write reviews but this restaurant deserves it. My boyf and I were looking for a nice place for some unique food. Noting crazy unique but, oh, the flavors. From the looks of it the menu changes pretty often but I got:

SALMON- lightly seared with quinoa, bruzzel sprouts + a tiny bit of bacon, and thin curls of sweet potato. I was never really sure what people meant when they said "this pairs so well with this other flavor" but there's no doubt I knew what those people meant after tasting the salmon with the sweet potato. The quinoa was done in such a way I didn't know quinoa could be done with so much taste; warm, full, and engulfing. All sorts of different savory and sweet flavors, all working in perfect harmony.  

he got:

VENISON-  with potato, beets, and mushrooms. Usually meat dishes have some sort of "splash" of herbs and flavoring but this dish was doused with a rosemary flavoring, and in such a great way. 

Waiters- so lovely, actually french, gave us great wine suggestions. 

All in all a great experience.
author: Alina L.

description: Service was good. The food was amazing but the only thing I didn't like was the number of items they had on the menu.
author: Annie J.

description:
We had a wonderful dinner here on a Sunday evening. We booked ahead and got a table upstairs. The waiter was helpful, attentive, and authentically aloof -- it's a French restaurant after all. We had the pork shoulder and sole. The meats were perfectly cooked and seasoned, and the vegetables, pomme puree, and polenta were excellent accompaniment. 

The waiter helped us choose from the French wines on their list, and we both loved the results. 

We so enjoyed the main courses we almost didn't leave room for dessert. The chocolate mousse with pistachios and mint made us glad we did, though.

Throw in the ambiance of a table full of "Brides of March" and the cozy seating, and we thought the evening could not have been better.
author: Dale E.

description: I'm a food snob from NYC. Visiting SF. I was recommended Bouche from the host at Gitane because the closed the kitchen for the evening. Went to Bouche. Its cozy and charming with candle lighting. Perfect for a date. Everything we ordered was Delish. The Salad was delightful.  The chicken was to die for. Salmon was cooked to perfection and the Dessert was out of the world! One of my best meals in SF. Defiantly will go back!
author: Jasmine P.

description: I relied on Yelp and Trip Advisor to steer me to a good restaurant tonight that was open at 10:00 pm and was looking forward to my meal at Bouche. I thought it odd when the host insisted that I walk up the stairs first as he "led" me to my table. Our server recommended the seared scallops, and the smell when they hit our table made my companion nauseous. They smelled very fishy. Neither my server or the 2nd person who waited on our table noticed or cared that I didn't finish the scallops, which we had placed on an empty table next to us so we didn't have to smell them. We paid $49 for a glass of Sancerre, beet salad and scallops. The first two items were worth it. Maybe this is a good restaurant, but I wouldn't recommend eating here late night.
author: Maggie P.

description:
My friend found this place through yelp and our minds were blown.
I used to live fairly close to this restaurant and I can't believe I haven't discovered it sooner!

We ordered our own individual dishes and shared with each other. There wasn't one dish that was slightly disappointing. Every dish, left us hungry for more! Argula salad, seared steelhead, roasted veal blade, kale stuffed bread risotto, and wild boar was amazing!

The steelhead was cooked to perfection and fresh. The wild boar meat was surprisingly sweet and tender. The veal blade was not gamey and the meat was fall off the bone good. The risotto was crispy and creamy.

For dessert, we had the creme fraiche custard and goat cheesecake.
Both was very unique and not overly sweet. 

5 STARS
author: Karen L.

description: This was the best find all day...we only had dessert, and it was great. The ambiance, the food,  chef and the owner are really approachable and will guide you to through the menu.
author: Adan R.

description:
Don't get me wrong - the quality of food was perfect, nothing was over or under cooked, and portions were, of course, on the smaller side, as expected.

I may have over hyped this place in my head, going in with high expectations - or it may just be a mediocre restaurant in the heart of the city.

We started with their house made bacon bread, ordered up halibut tartare, which was amazing, and had the creamy farro verde, and the petral sole. We followed it up with caramelized white chocolate and pears... no wow factor, and the caramelized white chocolate tasted like white mousse.

There is something about the flow of the menu that didn't sit well with me - there was no one apero/app that really complimented another, making it a little difficult to choose, and the restaurant is quite small. 

Again, aside from dessert, taste and quality were very good.
author: Jennifer A.

description: What a gem! Fantastic food, the fois gras is not be missed. Loved it, will definitely be back.
author: Natasha Z.

description:
I'll admit I didn't want to eat when I came here.  I was killing time with a friend who was a regular here. That was the plan. 3 glasses of wine later and we were having a couple appetizers and I was sold on the place. It's a small but stylish restaurant with tons of character. I can't say I'll ever go to a little restaurant in Paris in my lifetime but if I do I hope it's a lot like going to Bouche. 

I'm really big on service and ambiance and this place nailed it on both. Everyone who works there greets you at one point or another.  From the chefs to the servers. It's a small place and the people working there give that at home feel that you want in a restaurant this intimate. If I ever get to have another date in my lifetime this would be on of the first places I'd take her. 

Though I only had a couple dishes I was blown away by them both. Salt Cod brandade and a side of baked beans with some sort of stewed meat. They were both killer.  If that wasn't enough to convince me this place was good the stranger on my left had ordered what I think was braised lamb and he devoured it in less than 5 minutes. By the time I looked back at his dish it was wiped clean, literally. I thought I could stop there but I got suckered into dessert. I was stuffed from going to a sports bar earlier in the evening and the dishes I had but everyone around me raved about this creme fraiche custard. I broke down and agreed to try a bite of my friends order but it was just like a lays commercial. I couldn't just have one. One bite became six.

I can't wait to try this place again with a full appetite for food and wine.
author: Joco F.

description:
The atmosphere was cool. I was impressed the maitre gave me a hug, and we spoke French. Really made me feel welcome!

Food needs some improvement for the prices. 

I would like to see bone marrow on the dish. I felt like the food needed to be sourced from a farm to meet the prices we were paying.
author: Paul C.

description: We drove in late to the city from south Orange County and we were starved when we arrived at our hotel. It was our 1 year wedding anniversary and wanted to go and celebrate with a late night bite. We stumbled upon this quaint French restaurant and was so pleasantly surprised by how amazing the food was here. Bacon bread was eye opening. We had the chicken & the halibut, both were cooked to perfection, we ended up grabbing off each others plates because we loved both equally! The service was wonderful & ambience was perfection for us to celebrate our special day. Another reason why we love this city & the little gems you can discover! We'll be back!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
My boyfriend made my first round of birthday dinner reservations at Bouche and all the reviews here have been outstanding so I was really excited to try! We ordered the scallops, beef tenderloin tarar, and sauteed sweetbreads for appys. The sweetbreads were balanced well with mushrooms and cream but was unfortunately heavy handed with the salt. The scallops (2) were cooked perfectly and paired with a tarragon risotto which just as nice. 
  
My favorite appy out of the three was the beef tenderloin tartar. The plate itself was comprised  of the beef, lemon, chili powder, pesto and onions which were all placed separately from one another. None of the ingredients would have worked individually, but collectively, a dab and sprinkle of each in one bite was quite wonderful! 

As for the entrees, I ordered the pan seared petrole sole while the bf ordered the tomahawk porkchop. My sole was rather good with a well balanced puree and perfectly deep fried risotto balls. I only had a bite of the porkchop and my bf seemed pleased with it. 

Moving onto the venue... the bathroom must have been 2' x 1' with half a foot between the smallest sink in life and the little black toilet. It was literally the most logistically focused and highly coordinated restroom visit I have ever endured. I had my celine luggage tote in one hand and had only the other to handle logistics.. needless to say, it was uncomfortable. 

Overall the food was definitely solid but nothing outstanding. It was nothing short of what was expected but my mind was not blown and there wasn't anything I'd rave about. The venue itself was really small with about 5 tables upstairs and a little bar area down below. From the food to the decor and setting, it screamed authentic french across the board. Despite it all, the bf and I both left a bit disappointed and expected more from a $150 dinner.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Went here because of the great yelp rating and although I wasn't disappointed I was underwhelmed. 

Service was good, ambiance is casual and cozy since the upstairs dining area is so small.

The food though was good but not great. Had the bacon bread, sunchokes, wagyu sirloin and sole. Although well cooked, the fish was bland and the beef and potatoes were drenched in butter.

This place would get 4 stars in most cities but in San Francisco this place is forgettable.
author: thomas p.

description: I took my mom there for her birthday and we were blown away with amazing food and attentive service! The pickled poached egg with bean purée arugula and crispy onions was mind blowing along with the lamb and cherry tart our meal was complete! Oh and you MUST try the Dungeness crab mash potatoes! It is sinful and goes wonderfully with the lamb. Bon appetite!
author: Kelley W.

description:
Had a wonderful dining experience at Bouche!  Firstly, they really do serve food late and it's great.  I didn't get there until probably after 10:00pm and it was not an issue.

So the food there is inspired, I had the following:

Mix Squash Soup, Goat Cheese and Chive Cream, Bacon Croutons.  This is just mouth-watering and perfectly balanced, the first taste and I knew it was going to be a great meal.

Pan Seared Petrale Sole, Crispy Porcini Risotto, Espelette and Carrot Pure, Lobster Cream Sauce.  The flavors in this dish were simply perfect.  The Sole was perfectly cooked, and the Risotto were in two balls, accenting very well.  I cleaned the plate of all food, even the excess sauce (not that there was much excess, nor was it lacking).

Wild Mushroom Medley, Spicy Apple Sauce.  You can taste the right amount of apples, it's not overpowering but again wonderfully balanced with the mushrooms.  This complemented the Sole quite well.

Creme Fraiche Custard.  You Must Get This.  I cannot stress how simple and awesome this was.  The counter-balance of flavors and textures was artful.  This was also complimented by the Rivesaltes Ambre 2005, very sweet.

I can't remember which wine I had with dinner, just that it was a lighter red and fit the meal well.  It was recommended by the server, and he knew what he was doing.

The staff were also quite friendly, made sure I was enjoying my meal, and helpful when asking pairing questions.

If you want excellent French food in SF, this is the place to go.  The value for the food was excellent as well, I'd have gladly paid more for the quality they delivered here without question.
author: Mark G.

description: Perfect food, perfect portions, and perfect service. If you like French food this is the place to be. Love the host and hostesses, all very friendly and very cosy place. Get the steak and halibut with the special dessert, you won't regret it or feel guilty afterwards ;)
author: Jason W.

description: Food is delicious, and service is wonderful. My wife can be picky about the courses and  the server was very solicitous.
author: Ed P.

description:
I really wanted to like this place especially since I live right around the corner from it. The servers were nice and the small space was charming, but the food was really underwhelming! We were seated a half hour or so past our reservation which already was kind of a bummer, but nevertheless were excited to try the food. We had the duck confit, salad, red snapper, and the pork chop. Neither of us finished our entrees...barely half of it if any. 

Sad to say I won't be back. Wish we went to Gitane that night instead. Le sigh.
author: Natassia S.

description:
I brought my wife here for our anniversary and we both agreed that this was one of our favorite restaurants we've ever been to. Bouche can be found in a narrow, hole in the wall just above the tunnel on Bush Street. It's quite cozy and intimate with limited seating, so be sure to make reservations or come early...perfect for a date or diner for four.

We were greeted promptly and seated on time for our reservations. The waiters were friendly, accessible, and happy to answer all the questions we had...very knowledgeable crew.

We started off with Duck Confit (with Japanese and Watermelon Radishes and Cherry Sauce) and Potato Beignets (with Roasted Pork and morel Sauce). Presentation was impeccable and each bite was an explosion of flavors masterfully measured and blended to perfection! Pure heaven!!!

Our entrees were Seared Steelhead (with Cauliflower Creme, Nettle and Nut Pesto) and Roasted Veal Blade (with Pomme Duchease, Cipollini Onions and Creme). WOW!!! Simply delicious!!! Each ingredient enhanced/complimented the main dish superbly and left us wanting more.

The owner was so kind as to offer us complimentary dessert and coffee considering it was our anniversary. We were served the most delectable slice of chocolate pie I've ever tasted. The filling was rich chocolate topped with whipped cream on a thin flaky crust. What a wonderful way to end a most memorable meal!

THANK YOU BOUCHE for such an amazing and special dinning experience! We will be sure to come again!
author: John S.

description: Delicious foie gras! Buttery and rich... MmmMm. Seriously; order it. My steak and my friends halibut were also on point. The profiteroles (cream puffs) we're also yummy!The resultant has a nice quaint atmosphere. Also, service was swell. Overall just a lovely experience.
author: Awesomeness S.

description: Very nice and simple French food. Unique and not too complicated. Food speaks all... Very nice place for casual not too dressy place to dine in. Love it...
author: Unyo N.

description:
My husband is French and we stumbled upon this restaurant last year while looking for a decent late night meal near our hotel. Needless to say it was much more than decent!!! According to him it is also very authentic (I believe most, if not all, of the people that work there are French as well).

In fact, we loved it so much that it was our restaurant of choice when we came back to the city on a trip last week. We had talked about the goat cheese pie and beet ice cream dessert for over a year and it was just as delicious as we remembered! 

Amazing ambiance, wonderful food and love that they stay open late! Definitely a must try if you love authentic French cuisine and atmosphere.
author: Haley W.

description: First when I came in, I though it's a great place to have a dinner with my girlfriend. The waiter is so nice to greet us. After we took the orders. Then the waitress never have any conversations with us, also no greeting. She just focused on one of the "big table", which was order a lot more ?. Every small table were not have any services.   She put on every single dishes on our table , she just put it on. Even not telling us what the dish was. What the heck, what a waitress with attitude.  No smile no greet. Honestly, she ruin my dinner with my girlfriend. I won't come here anymore. Not for the food, just because for that horrible waitress.  Very very bad service!!!!!!
author: Silence H.

description:
Solid place for dinner. Cute ambience. Small place upstairs and small intimate bar downstairs. the kitchen is tiny but they serve 100 covers a night. everything was solid french fare but loved the charcuterie and fougasse (soft hot foccaccia-like bread with bacon bits). 

great wine selection, really like the wine by the glass rose and pouilly fuisse.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Awesome steak and salmon. You cannot go wrong with any choices~ my favorite restaurant at sf~
author: Lijin Z.

description:
I was considering turning vegetarian, but not after this dish.. Most amazing meal I've had in a long time. 

Fougasse
Monkfish
Pork Belly

I higly recommend both the fougasse (which had bits of bacon baked in it! BACON!!!) and the Pork Belly.. Get an order of prok belly each since you will not want to share after you have your first bite.
author: Anne T.

description: Went with my daughter. While we had a reservation, there was still a wait. Wait staff was attentive. We eat more vegetarian and there was one choice. We had beet gnocchi and the chickpea fries. It was good. Probably not something I would make. Pricey which is on yelp. This dinner was good. Parking is very convenient.
author: Leone M.

description: Excellent meal!  The pork and steak were fantastic. Felt like we were in Provence but we were in SF!  Bottle of wine and watching the passer byes. OK hold it my wife is in love with the waiter!?  We're outta here '-)
author: Doug H.

description: Hanger steak was fabulous. Restaurant is very intimate. Fantastic wine choices. Highly recommend!
author: Ford S.

description: Charming, tiny French restaurant! Definitely make reservations as it's very small, but cute. The food was delicious and actually small enough portion sizes that we could enjoy a starter and main and still have room for dessert. We tried the bacon bread (a mini loaf of fresh bread with bacon chunks baked in - YUM!) and chickpea fries which were deliciously crispy and light, and the wagyu steak with potatoes, which was small (maybe 4oz) but delicious and still enough to satisfy. The chocolate mousse dessert was pretty good too although probably my least favourite of the courses. Service was attentive and very knowledgeable with wine recommendations. Great place to eat if you like delicious food, intimate atmosphere, and dislike being served ridiculously, waste fully large portions.
author: Emily T.

description:
Fantastic cuisine. Sat us immedeately. 
Quality food and perfect service. 

Dive bar next door.
author: Steven R.

description: Just go. It's so French and so good. Really, if you know French places and you've been to Paris, you'll get this and love it.
author: Ron S.

description:
I stayed at a hotel nearby so thought I'd give this place a try. Cute little two story restaurant that sits several tables upstairs and a little bar area downstairs.

As for the food, their braised pork shoulder was bland and the scallop was SO fishy that I had to ask for extra lemon which didn't make it any better. Excellent red wine though. 

Maybe it was the dish or that day but meh, not a big fan.
author: Grace K.

description:
Bouche is akin to a small Country French Bistro - intimate, homey, rustic, genuinely Provincal, with convivial staff and simple but excellent fare; locally sourced and incredibly fresh. 

We ate here last night and enjoyed a host of dishes, including the Cheese plate (to start) which offered 2 semi soft goat cheese; 1 akin to Morbier and the other like a fine Blue.  The hard cow's milk was like a raclette.    Served with apricot and blackberry compote it was excellent.   Like having dessert as a first course which is never a bad thing IMHO. 

Next course were the marinated sardines with grapefruit.   Excellent.   I can't recall fresher tasting sardines...they still had their full color and tasted like they had been caught in the past hour.    We also had the stewed and oiled peppers with burrata.   Simple, but tasty.   

We also had the King Trumpet and Maitake mushrooms with greens, which were a disappointment, hence the loss of a star.   Interestingly, the King Trumpets tasted exactly like stale biscuits that they sometimes served us in school when I was a child.   A somewhat odd but poignant memory sparked by the flavour of the mushrooms. 

For Entrees we had Smoked Salmon with Creme Fraiche, and the Pork Belly & Shoulder.   The pork was mind-boggling good...two different cuts of pork - shoulder, confit, and the belly, which was unctuous and delicious.   The confit was topped with a tangy pickled onion which set it off nicely.    The salmon is their signature dish (see business photo - that's it), and while it was tasty, I found it plain and far eclipsed by the Pork.    I wished I had tried the Cod instead. 

The Wine List is noteworthy - they have an excellent selection of small vintages from Provence and Languedoc Rousillon, among others.    I had a glass of the Jurancon and the Beaupre Coteaux.  The former was alive with fruit, not too snappy, and had a slight finish of Lynchee.  The latter was crisp and dry with elements of lemon and apple.   Both were excellent.
