Bouche has been likened to a "Cozy French Home" on Bush street....I would have to agree, and will be back.
author: Max K.

description: Fries, pork belly, bread are excellent.  They take great pride in their food! Quaint little joint offering friendly staff and great poutine!
author: Michael M.

description:
My husband and I were really disappointed with our experience last night. While the service downstairs was great and the wine was delicious, it all fell apart upstairs. 

There is no excuse for bad service when there are only 8 tables. And from my viewpoint I could see our server look at our table, make the decision to not check on us even when I was trying to get his attention, walk down the stairs, go in the kitchen empty handed and come out empty handed. This occurred several times during our meal. 

The food was delicious and we even planned on dessert, but changed our mind because we could not take the terrible service anymore. It's important to note that there were only 3 tables at this point. If only the quality of service matched the quality of food.
author: Amanda M.

description: The chick pea fritters are unparalleled. Wish I could take the staff and food back to the east coast with me!  Awesome.
author: Marie P.

description:
The best restaurant my sister and I visited on our trip. The food was superb. We had the bone marrow, I had the duck and my sister had the steak. The waiter Gael was very helpful and very friendly. He chose the perfect wine to pair with our food. Will most definitely come back the next time I'm in SF.

ADDENDUM:
Uh. I have to change my rating to 10 stars. To tell you all the truth, I just couldn't wait to get home that I wrote the previous review while I was still at the table at Bouche. The awesome waiter Gael brought out a complimentary dessert while I was writing it without knowing! The service at this restaurant is better than the food, which is quite difficult since the food is amazing. Agh! Definitely, definitely coming back! Thanks, Bouche! Thanks, Gael!!
author: Mi K.

description:
Can't do half stars here, but I would give it a 3.5, not 4.

Like others mentioned, very small and intimate atmosphere. The storefront was so small that we actually walked right by it!

We showed up for a 6pm reservation on a Monday night. There were a few people down in the bar area, but we were the only party in the dining area upstairs. Not sure if we were forgotten about because of that, but after we were seated, we didn't see anyone, nor get served any water for another 15-20 minutes. I think we were finally remembered when the next party arrived, because we were finally approached by a waiter right before the second party got seated. When the server arrived with some water, he seem apologetic. Service was faster after that as the dining area started to get filled with other people.

The boyfriend and I ordered the bacon bread, the salmon entree, and the pork shoulder entree. The bacon bread was okay, nothing too spectacular. I liked the bread by itself. Maybe there was too much bacon in the bread because the first couple of bites were pretty salty. But I think we got used to it after a while so we did finish the whole loaf of bacon bread.

The boyfriend's pork shoulder entree started off good. The flavors were there and the meat was pretty tender. However, after a while, the meat started to get a little dry. He really liked the polenta though.

Saved the best for last! My salmon entree was DELICIOUS. The salmon was cooked perfectly all the way through. The boyfriend kept trying to exchange some of his pork shoulder for some of my salmon. All the textures on the plate were perfectly mixed with each other. The ingredients too (crunch carrot strips, brussel sprouts, bacon, and quinoa)! Definitely the dish to order when you go to Bouche for dinner. Highly recommend it!

Not sure if I would come back again simply because going to the city for a meal is a pain, but I definitely don't regret coming here! :)
author: Pam W.

description:
(See pics) Review #1213. 3.8 stars for the food, 5 stars for opening late until 2am and great service. 4+ stars!!

Have been here for the previous 2 places and while the physical layout is almost identical and served a boutique style cuisine at a cozy atmosphere, each restaurant spun a different feel and finesse.

This place was fairly busy and especially in the evening when we popped by they reserved upstairs for 1 big party, so it just left all the bar seating for everyone else.

We had a beer (4 on tap plus others in bottles) while waiting for some people to leave. The server was excellent as he served us in smaller wine glasses for tasting before we actually ordered. This was the same when we were ready to do wine pairing later on too.

A smaller menu and so we were able to try out a few of them. Fougase (house made bread topped with bacon and halved olives inside) was just okay and would have been better if the bread was warm. The soup was buttery and was okay. The beet salad with duck confit was good greased taste.

So we were a bit underwhelmed at this point, but then the salmon on top of a deep fried tiny noodles wrapping a poached egg wrapped was absolutely a phenomena! This requires skills and we were awed big time. The suggested Alycastre Rose pairing which had a bit of smokey flavor was great.

Roasted Brussel sprouts were excellent and was a trending dish. It was crisp with layers happily falling like chips as I took a bite to it.

Both stuffed chicken and lamb shoulder were good solid, juicy. The recommended pairing Vinsobres, Corbieres were both matching and brought out the flavors of the dishes.

For Dessert we had panna cotta and white chocolate with caramelized pear (poached style) and brown butter sable were delicate and not too sweet.

Service was fantastic and attentive and the fact that they let us try a few wines before deciding which ones to pair was a very nice touch.

As usual, we closed out the place way after their closing time and they were nice to let us enjoy food, drinks and company without interruptions!
author: T L.

description:
Amazing hidden gem!

French, affordable and open late! I'm glad I found this place by chance on Yelp. 

The restaurant is incredibly small. You definitely need reservations if you're planning on eating during normal dinner hours. 

The hubby and I shared an appetizer made with Roasted King Trumpets And Maitakes, Dill Pesto & Fresh Pluots. Such a great salad to start with. The mushrooms had oodles of flavor. I almost licked the plate clean. 

The hubby had a Marinated Salmon, Poached Egg And Crême Fraiche as his entree. The salmon was so melt in your mouth. It was lightly smoked. It was almost sashimi-like. There was a bed of crunchy noodles or rice under the salmon. It was a nice play of textures.

I went for the Roasted Berkshire Pork Belly, Confit Pork Shoulder, Potato Purée, And Summer Truffle. SO. AMAZING. The pork belly was everything you would want it to be: tender, flavorful, awesome. The potato purée was like a delicious sauce for the pork. And the plate was LOADED with slices of black truffle. For only $25, it was a steal!

We finished our night with a Crême Fraiche Custard. It was a crême fraiche panna cotta with separate side of custard. It was like having your crême brulée without the heaviness. Surprisingly refreshing. 

Love this place! Can't wait to come back again!
author: Daisy T.

description:
As I sit in my room with my Suzie purring in the bed slowly falling asleep, I can only say, this was an amazing end to a wonderful day in San Fran.  I was curious about this French bistro just a minute walk away from the Hyatt.  What could be in store if we cruised on by, without a reservation.  It's a Sunday night, in a bustling, energized city.  Could we get in?

Yup, they were happy to see us and had a table upstairs.  A tiny little box of a restaurant which reminded me of a wonderful French meal we had in New York City at La Boite En Bois.  As we entered the first gentleman we encountered asked us if we would like to sit at the bar, usually a go to hang out for us.  However, I asked about sitting at table and he immediately found us a place upstairs.  A quaint two facing out to the street overlooking a tattoo parlor and self service laundromat.  They only had few tables in the main dining area, which meant for an intimate romantic setting.

The menu was very limited, with perhaps 4 entrees, 9 appetizers and a nice wine list.  We started with the Cheese Special, followed by the Marinated Flat Iron Steak, Summer Squash And Potato Gratin, Shaved Asparagus, Red Corn and Seared Muscovy Duck Breast, Duck Confit Croquette, Burnt Honey Farro, Sautéed Haricots Verts with the Tomates Farcies, Squash And Bell Pepper Risotto side.  Their wine list was nicely rounded and upon the servers choice we received the Château De Cazeneuve Les Calcaires Pic Saint Loup 2011.  A lovely red BTW.

The Duck.. ah hell, I'm not going to go through all that.  Let me put it simply.. this was da merde!  Heck, everything about this place was la bomba.  The quaint tiny restaurant was full of love and soul.  We were laughing with our neighbors, two gals from Vancouver, as well as the waiters.  Each of us would pause after having the first bite and just take it in.  We were punch drunk on the wonderful plate presentations and the service when presenting them to us.  We would finish our bites and look at each other with approval nodding heads.  Photo's were taken of food, servers and new friends.  Laughter and smiles were a bound as we finished our wonderful wine and dinner.  At the end of our entree's, we did something we generally never do, order desert.  A chocolate Tart of the day.  When the server returned with it, he quietly told us that this was on the house for us being some much fun to have in the restaurant.... I thought we were being way to loud.  Once dinner was over, we came down the stairs to see the chefs looking and smiling at us.. all we could do was applaud them and thank them for such a great meal and they in turn told us that they wished they could of joined us for a glass of wine since we were having such a fun time they wanted to join in.  Truly, one of the best meals and experiences in our lives..  To only live in San Francisco to make this a weekly destination.
author: Jens B.

description: Came here late night after the symphony. Kitchen open until 1 AM. All French cuisine. We had pork lion, flat iron steak, and eggplant. All dishes were top notch. Great wine list. Excellent stop for a late supper.
author: Steven K.

description:
Pork and beans with gently poached egg were fantastic! Phenomenal place for great brunch!

One of the best brunch meals I had I a while. Well executed and delicious. 

Everything was perfectly seasoned as well. 

Could easily be one of the most popular and one of the best brunch places in San Francisco if more people would know about it. 
Now it's in my bookmarks!
author: Xela H.

description:
Amazing dinner from start to finish. I haven't been this excited about a restaurant in a while. 

I went here for a girls' night out and was intrigued with the ambiance from the moment I stepped in... it's rustic, intimate, cozy and classy at the same time. There are two levels - bottom one is a bit more casual with a nice bar scene and the top one is intimate and romantic. We were seated in the corner of the top level. Our waiter was friendly and helpful and his French accent certainly didn't hurt either! 

Now to the good stuff... the food. Please listen carefully and I mean very carefully. Order the same order I made and you're guaranteed to love it. One of my friends ordered the fish and it was a bit too raw for our tastes. But everything else fully made up for this. 

Start with the Marinated Salmon, Poached Egg And Creme Fraiche appetizer to really open up your palette. We were all impressed with the perfectly smooth texture and the subtlety of the dish. This creme fraiche and salmon combo should be almost as famous as the peanut butter and jelly one. 

Follow this with the Roasted Berkshire Pork Belly entree. I'm not a hundred percent certain but I'm pretty sure I cried a few tears of gluttonous happiness while consuming this. It's tender, juicy, moist, flavorful, buttery without butter even being an ingredient and everything good in mankind. Bouche is now one of my favorite restaurants in SF and this dish is solely the reason why! 

Lastly, conclude this explosion of foodie pleasure with the Creme Fraiche Custard. It takes simplicity and purity to the next level by maintaining the true flavor and taste of milk. The custard is served along with a chocolate sauce and the combination of the two is painfully powerful. 

Pair all of this with a bottle of French wine and you've got a fabulous dining experience. Please make reservations in advance as the restaurant is quite small and seems to always be busy. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
I'm glad I rediscovered Bouche, having completely forgotten about it after a friend recommended it to me several months back. Stopping in for dinner early last week with a friend, we were greeted with some accessibility issues that the waitstaff handled immediately, without us even requesting anything (more on that later). So, off to a good start, my friend and I ordered their:

* Marinated Salmon, Poached Egg & Creme Fraiche [ http://flic.kr/p/dp6fgy ] - I've mentioned time and again my slight aversion to raw fish, but oh dear god this was an amazing dish. Every component of the dish blended together just so, to create a tasty, well-balanced burst of flavors and texture. We never quite figured out what the crispy noodle-like things were (strips of phyllo dough, according to Cherylynn N), but they certainly helped make the dish was it was.

* Roasted Berkshire Pork Belly, Confit Pork Shoulder, Potato Puree, & Yellow Chanterelles - A dual presentation of pork, with my personal preference going towards the oh-so-tender-and-crispy pork belly, over the pork confit. Definitely something to be eaten alongside the rest of the dish for the proper balance of flavors, so make sure you get a mouthful of potatoes and mushrooms alongside that pork!

* Lamb Shoulder, Onion And Almond Marmalade, Carrot & Coriander Puree [ http://flic.kr/p/dp6fuY ] - While still rather enjoyable, this was probably the most lackluster part of the meal, due completely to the fact that the sauce actually made the dish a bit too sweet. Though that aside, the lamb shoulder was prepared wonderfully, to the point of being melt-in-your-mouth tender.

We also had a white (to go with the salmon) and red (for the pork and lamb) wine suggested to us by our waitress, both of which went perfectly with the food - and this is coming from someone who still doesn't completely appreciate wine yet. Of noteworthy mention is that they let us split a glass of wine by actually pouring two very generous servings into separate glasses for us.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - So, as mentioned when I started this review, Bouche is not incredibly wheelchair accessible. Their actual tables are all upstairs, with the downstairs area being limited to high bar seating. However, they apparently have a fold out table stored away somewhere, that they can bring out for these types of situations: just be sure to let them know when making your reservation.

Bathroom - I didn't use them, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Wonderful dinner in a cute little restaurant.
Couple of tips:  The main (only) dining room upstairs is tiny.  Nine tables that should really be seven.  If you have an early dinner, you may have the place to yourself and then it's wonderful.  At peak crowd, you'll be sitting cheek to jowl.

The foie gras is amazing.  The bacon bread is not worth it (and note they'll serve you regular bread on request).    I had the hanger steak and it was a LOT of food. 

We'd definitely go again.
author: Bill W.

description:
Very intimate French dining. Kitchen and bar downstairs and a small and comfy upstairs dining room with windows on the street. A very upscale bistro feel. All three people servicing our table were very French, a good sign.

Everything was delicious. A green salad with egg yolk in dressing, yum. Followed by a squash soup with splendid rich broth and cream base. Followed by raviolo with duck and boar, and a most delicious sauce. Then perfect salmon with a delicious sauce, essence of French cuisine, none of that watered down CA variety. Dessert was a pudding with caramel sauce, and a warm tart. Delicious!! 

They had a very interesting wine list! I am a dedicated Pinot/burgundy drinker, and they only had one pretty expensive (and delicious) per glass option.
author: Philip K.

description:
A good meal. The portions were small, but tasty. 

Personal pet peeve: I find it a tad gauche for the sommelier, when asked for a wine pairing, to point to the most expensive bottle on the menu. Regrettably, that happened. 

Not quite worth the trip. Won't return to Bouche.
author: Brett J.

description:
Review for dinner:

Pros (+): 
(+) Ambiance - super quaint romantic intimate place
(+) People - the servers were great, the chefs in the kitchen really friendly and don't mind that you gawk at them from above
(+) Wine selection, great french wines
(+) Bone marrow - really good
(+) Pork belly appetizer
(+) Rock Cod, yummy, although the spicy crawfish jus wasn't spicy at all and seemed to lack a bit of a punch.
(+) Duck - really good
(+) Creme Fraiche custard w/caramel. Really good
(+) Goat cheese cake with beet ice cream. 

Cons (-):
(-) Bacon bread was a bit dry

This place was good - bring a date! It'll be impressive.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Simply put, fantastic place! Great customer service and the food is sooooooo good! I highly recommend the steak from the dinner menu! Definitely will come back!
author: K H.

description: Small, cute, and a little fancy shhhmancy :) Ordered 4 delicious entrees. Flavors were definitely amazing!!! It did not fill me up though. I was still a bit hungry. I think this place is more of a quick bite but taste the different wines kind of place. Over all I enjoyed it!
author: Sharmaine M.

description:
This is just the most darling little place in a very lively part of San Francisco. Right when you walk in, you feel this intimate feeling of being welcomed into a friend's house for dinner, but with dim romantic lighting instead. 

The place is really small so you'll feel as if everyone's in the same party. I don't recommend it for groups over 4 because once again, it is an extremely intimate spot. The service is fantastic and the staff their is friendly and funny!

My fiance and I ordered 2 appetizers, the charcuterrie and the pork belly, a well as the flatiron steak and the cod dish. Right after I ordered, I of course went on my phone to check in on Yelp. While doing so,  I accidenally  drop my phone which lands on my lap, slides down onto the floor, and riccochets past the ledge and lands under the top floor into the kitchen! I start freaking out thinking I hit a chef or worse... hit them while they were using a knife resulting in a huge accident!

I run over and look below to see a smiling chef looking back up at me. Thank God it landed next to him and not on him! He makes a joke about getting a "long distance call" and runs up the stairs to hand me my phone. Thankfully, he was such a good sport about it all. Teaches me to play with my phone during dinner time huh?

Anyhoo... the part of the food.

The charcutterie selection was delicious! The pork belly was surprisingly different due to it's leaner cut. Usually when I order pork belling, it's kind of fatty, which makes for a more sinful little treat. But I didn't feel too guilty with this dish. My fiance cleary enjoyed his steak because after I tried a bite, he cleaned off the rest of his plate before I  got through a third of my fish! Now... I normally don't like cooked fish unless it's sea bass. I'm just extremely particular on how it is cooked. This cod however... did not disappoint. Seared to perfection! And the accoutrements that it came with paired perfectly to bring out the natural sweetness of the fish!

Although there were only four choices to choose from for the main course, they change their menu every so often, so I'll definltely make another trip out when they do!
author: amelia g.

description:
Service and atmosphere was good, but the food was disappointing.  For a $100 meal for 2, I expect food to be excellent.

Scallop Carpaccio - extremely fishy
Seared Duck Breast - my friend said it was just ok and have had better.  I don't like french duck, so I can't rate this.
Salmon - mediocre.  There was nothing special about it.
Tart of the Day: Pumpkin - not good.  It had some mexican flavor that I can't pinpoint.
author: Mindy K.

description: Enjoyed a fantastic dinner at Bouche Friday night. Attire is casual, but the service and quality of the food is more like you would expect at high end formal restaurant. Space is tight in a more European style and quite noisy, but that's no deal breaker.
author: Adam C.

description: I'm sayin this was a lost excellent meal. The service was impeccable and the food was prepared to the specifications requested.  Beautiful service and preparation in a small venue.  Thank you!!
author: Tom W.

description:
Bless the Bouche for being open til 1 AM and still being delectably classy. 

A friend whom I hadn't seen in 8 years was in town and we set up an impromptu dinner date--our only search criteria was that it be French. 

Bouche is right next to a bar I've enjoyed in the past, Tunnel Top, and I remember hearing from the bartender there that the two were somehow affiliated. Well, everybody who works at Bouche really is French--as is the Tunnel Top crew-- and many of the customers also answer to the name of Francois so we really found the epitome of what we sought with this spot.  Don't be fooled by the fact that the guys working here can pronounce their "r"s without discernible foreignness: they are authentic.  Plus it is comfortably close to public transport (Union Square/Powell St.) which worked out perfectly as a meeting point.

I enjoyed a great creamy soup with charred garlic and mushrooms, as well as a beautiful piece of perfectly cooked Halibut. My friend liked the carpaccio and the sardine salad he was given accidentally (and invited to enjoy for free). The salmon looks like a bird's nest with baby bird fetuses on it, which was both artistic and gothic. I didn't taste it but the customers next to us at the bar, who were copying everything we ordered, said it was incredible.

Do make reservations because there is no way you'll get as lucky as we were, just sauntering in even at 10 PM. 

I hear good things about the polenta which I will try on my next visit.
author: Lara W.

description:
The restaurant is very small with mostly counter service. The wine list was quite extensive and reasonably priced.

Shared the wild greens salad with soft egg.  Dressing was very tasty and the greens very fresh.

The roast pork stew over polenta was over the top. Generous portion, lots of flavor, and well plated.

The pan fried salmon over roasted Brussel sprouts and quinoa was very flavorful.

The wait staff were very friendly and provided excellent service.

I would return again, but call for a reservation.
author: Bill H.

description:
I like that Bouche is simple and flavorful. 

That doesn't sound like a glowing description; however, if you've been to SF restaurants that are either loud, a little snooty, creative to the point of gimmicky, and beyond-logical-pricey, Bouche is a respite and a palate pleaser. 

The only deduction for me was the placement of the upstairs tables, while intimate, they leave no privacy in conversation. The next table's topic is as audible as joining the two tables together and I wonder if presenting them as separate may be a wrinkle. I had a nice time interacting with others, Bouche might want to make this a part of the venue a bit more than having it feel unexpected. I did not listen to conversations beyond one table in either direction, the overall room audio was fine.

I will definitely return for the food, service and the overall atmosphere. Not my first pick for a private conversation; however, there's plenty of places to walk nearby.
author: Kelly C.

description: An incredible laid back atmosphere with very pleasant and attentive staff....aaaaaand, to the food.  I started with a small lettuce appetizer and picked out a little salmon for my main dish.  Incredible.  Flavor was fantastic was fantastic and portions just right.  A decent price for SF.  Tip included,  $50, but we'll worth it.  I would recommend it if you are in the Union Square area.
author: Eric B.

description:
Love the coziness of this place. The upstairs has about 8-9 tables so when the place is full, it can get quite warm. Especially if you sit by the stairs over looking the kitchen.

No complaints about the service. Friendly and attentive. Food, however, not as authentic French and tasty as other Yelpers have claimed.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Just remarkable!  Like many of us, I'm into fine dining and this tiny beautiful restaurant continually delivers. Pork belly with pickled beech mushrooms?  Sure why not. Goodness, their whole menu is a delight. Great wine selections too!  And service with a smile and hearty French accent. This place has it going on.
author: Jay H.

description: Good food and cozy place to get together. I had their special octopus appetizer and the lamb shank for dinner. Both were delicious. Environment is dim so it makes it cozy but it also makes it difficult to read the menu. Tables were closed together. You can dine downstairs (street level) or upstairs. Upstairs space is cute and quiet. I recommend making reservations, sit upstairs and ask for their specials. As for wine pairing, if you like sweet and fruity wines, you are out of luck. Waiter said, "...as they say in France, the French brings sweetness to the wine. " Enjoy. I will definitely be back.
author: Khiang S.

description:
This place is amazing.

They are open and serving their glorious menu past midnight for all you night owls like myself, and they have the best steak I've had yet in this city, all for under $30, and you can order that at 12:30am!

Great cocktails, fantastic service, and a truly intimate and charming setting.  

Skip the diners and come here for a real culinary experience when the rest of the city has gone to bed.
author: Super L.

description:
A must try location only possible in the beauty that is San Francisco.

Bouche is my French home away from home in SF. I have had dinner here maybe a dozen times and never once regret it. The food, atmosphere, and service are top notch. Julie, the hostess, is delightful in exactly the way a French woman should be: forceful, elegant, and graceful. Every dish is made to perfection and the wine only adds to it.
author: George S.

description: Very romantic, perfect date place. We were on the upper section, very intimate if a bit snug. Food was Mediterranean French style, and was awesome. Highly recommended!
author: Simon C.

description:
This charming place is perched at the top of the stockton tunnel. There's great bar and counter seating for people watching but also a few tables upstairs. It's supposed to be "California-French" which basically means fresh, seasonal ingredients prepared in fancy ways with small but satiating portions.

The sardines with citrus is tasty, if not refreshing. The duck confit is a pretty safe appetizer too.

The salmon with poached egg and creme fraiche was good though not as large as I expected. It felt like a very large appetizer but it given the egg and creme fraiche, it felt filling and any more of that and it would be disgustingly heavy. The salmon was well prepared though.

It's definitely not a place for a large group but perfect for a light bite with a friend or date. Service is impeccable and very friendly.
author: Victor W.

description:
The place has some great ambiance.  Something about it just screams "hole in the wall," although that may partially be because it feels kinda perpetually cramped, even if it's not actually that full.  Ah, San Francisco real estate.  But they make do with what they have, and they luckily turned what could have easily been a suffocating environment into a pretty intimate one.

Being a fine dining experience, or something close enough to it, I enjoyed the food that I had, but even with the typical (I don't actually know if this is true) French richness to the meat, I still felt a bit of a hankering afterwards.  I can't really blame this place for having caused my growing up with an American appetite and its accompanying portions, but it's something to note.  But the meat that I had (lamb shoulder, I believe) was really savory and tender and just right in flavor.
author: Norman S.

description:
small, crowded, but also quaint.  The menu changes regularly and is VERY LIMITED in size. My choices sounded great but the preparation was average. I has scallop carpaccio - Yummy but tiny, the bacon bread (was reheated to be served and was still cold on the inside (almost like it was frozen and thawed out).  My salmon also was an amazing preparation,BUT it was raw on the inside.

Overall, a great idea but not great execution.  My gut says give it 3 stars, but I really like the idea of this place so I gave it four.
author: Jay K.

description: Utterly lovely. Small. Quaint. Charming. Complete with actual French waitors. Wine list is all French so just have the waitor suggest your wines of you don't know. They're honest. The salmon was literally the best I've ever had. And the mixed greens was some mixed of mushroom magic. No clue what it was but it was lovely. I can't wait to go back and try everything else.
author: Sandy B.

description: Translated to "Stuffy". Love it. Very cozy two story spot. Nice wine selection, fabulous service. Hunt it down and enjoy!
author: Levi T.

description:
I really like Bouche!  It is a quaint restaurant with charming service and cozy decor.  My friend and I immediately felt at home.  We weren't sure which glass of red wine we wanted so the server sweetly took the time to ask what kind of red wine we were looking for and gave us recommendations, even letting us taste a couple to decide.  :)

After reading Yelp reviews, I knew I wanted to try the chestnut soup, which was hot, comforting and just right.  The chestnuts were meaty, warm and slightly crunchy.  Loved it!  Anytime there is pork belly on the menu, I cannot resist.  It was lovely, tasty, tender with potatoes and vegetables.  Yum! 

We were both so full, but when the waiter mentioned the tart of the day was a huckleberry tart, we had to get it.  It was so fresh with a dollop of vanilla ice cream on top....mmmm!

We completely enjoyed our meal at Bouche while we caught up on girly chat.  I would definitely come back in a heartbeat.  Make a reservation though.  Merci beau coup, Bouche!!
author: Maile N.

description: Desserts are not too sweet and a perfect size. Very French restaurant wth a great wine list and cheese platter.
author: Rey R.

description:
Wow.

There is a reason that UNESCO has placed La Gastronomie Francaise on it's list of the world's "intangible cultural heritage" and Bouche pays fine tribute as to why.

Another reviewer of this establishment described it as "foodgasmic from start to finish". I read her review AFTER eating there and had to laugh, because I had the same reaction. As I was eating my roasted Berkshire pork belly with confit shoulder and chanterelles I leaned over to my wife and told her that my toes literally were curling with delight. Her marinated salmon with poached egg and creme fraiche was absolute perfection of taste, texture and visual appeal. 

This is a truly French experience. The respect for fine ingredients, the purposeful inclusion of each flavor in the dish, the balance of portions; all work together to celebrate food and celebrate what it is that makes us love to dine out. 

Bouche transports you to Paris. You will be in close proximity to other people, you should expect to take your time and eat your meal in courses and savor each bite and sip. Relax, slow down, enjoy. Bouche should be on your "must go" list.
author: A K.

description: Wonderfully authentic modern french bistro.  Menu, though limited, changes daily to highlight the freshest ingredients and the chef's whimsy.  We loved watching the work going on in the open kitchen from our table in the balcony.  I'm so glad we found this gem.
author: Melissa K.

description:
love the tasty & explosive dishes that just satisfies my palate so completely.  Terrific wine selections too.  So yummmmmmmmmmy!!!!

Verrrrrrrry authentic like the dishes in Lyon/France!!
author: Jeene L.

description: Every time my fiancée and I come to San Francisco, we come to bouche. The menu changes often, but every single thing we get is always amazing. We always get the caramel dessert and we are never disappointed. I definitely suggest trying it next time you come to San Francisco. We always make a reservation, just in case, and always get a seat. We also love that they are open late!!
author: Ashley S.

description:
This place was simply amazing! Everyone that works here is so nice, and French :)
What a cozy place to enjoy a fantastic meal! Be sure to get the bone marrow as it is absolutely life changing!! All the food was delicious and we will be back for sure.
It is not big so be prepared to be close to others in an intimate setting but everything here just works!!
author: Luciana R.

description: I won't repeat what others have already said in praise of Bouche, all I will say is that as the comet is blazing its way to Earth to destroy all inhabitants and everything in its path, I will be at Bouche enjoying my final bottle of wine accompanied by the charcuterie plate, cheese polenta, English pea soup and duck confit croquants. I can think of no better way to go out than this.
author: Steven T.

description: Small portions, overcooked halibut and meat, bad service. I seldom leave negative reviews but this place is overrated.
author: Ben K.

description: Sweet and friendly staff! Came here for dinner and drinks. We were seated up top which was quaint and intimate. The food was just as good!
author: Olivia Y.

description:
Stopped in for a little holiday cheer away from the madness of Union Square.  Well, let's face it, draw a 1 mile diameter circle around Union Square this time of year and it's a little nuts with all the holiday shoppers, holiday partiers, and all the other "holiday" reasons for being annoying.

Glad we stopped in.  it was calm, warm, and tasteful.

The Baron deSeillac Brut Rose was fine example of a tasty rose bubbly from Provence.
The Chimères Saint-Roch Cotes du Roussillon was a little tannic and tight., but Bouche doesn't make the wine, just pours it.

What they did make that we tried was just right for a chilly SF night.  The Roasted carrots were perfectly done - a little crunch to the butter roasted glaze.  The chestnut soup was warm and hearty.

Prices are standard for San Francisco. Dare I even say, reasonable?

Walking outside we felt warm and content for the drive home.


Yes, I will return.  Next time I'll make sure I have the time, and the hunger, for a full dinner.
author: Jeff H.

description:
What a surprise - this restaurant focuses on California-French small plates but it's far far away from your typical french bistro food.

Dishes were beautifully presented, and at the very least were surprising and challenging flavor-wise. The sardines and the halibut weren't quite as successful as the carpaccio and the pork loin, but we really appreciated the risks they were taking with the food. The fougasse (bacon bread!) was fantastic. The wines by the glass were also quite good.

Overall, highly recommended for something affordable, yet surprising and very tasty.
author: Amy D.

description:
Nice feel, great service but just so so on the food. Wines by the glass at $15 seemed out of whack but had I loved wither of them, I might have been singing a different tune. Duck confit appetizer should have been amazing considering the textures and ingredients but the meat itself fell flat. 

Amusing moment was watching the staff smile attentively at the three girlies who all sounded as if they did the voice-over for the Selfie song.  "Oh my gawd, I am sooooo going back to Europe, the guys there, they like totally like me!"  

They were so rachet! I had to call my girl and let her listen to them talk. .
author: MandM P.

description:
My wife and I found Bouche on Yelp and were very excited to try some French cuisine on our last night in SF--sadly, we left feeling underwhelmed, particularly after reading so many positive reviews.  To their credit, the staff was friendly and even accommodated a last-minute addition to our party (three people instead of the initial two-person reservation.)  Once seated, however, the surprises were mostly unpleasant:

1.  The tasty bacon bread isn't complimentary, which although it may only cost five bucks, pales in comparison to many other restaurants we'd sampled during our trip--all of which offered delicious free bread courses (Nob Hill Cafe in particular.)  It was accompanied by a minuscule pat of ice cold butter.

2.  The appetizer we had (pickle plate) was extremely small and qualified more as an hors-douevre than anything else.  Four bites, max.

3.  Only four entrees and four apps on the menu; while I'm a big believer in not having TOO big of a menu--this was just too small.  We ended up going with the pork loin and the sole.  Both were very tasty, BUT each cost roughly thirty bucks and were almost comically small.  The pork loin couldn't have been more than 3-4 ounces, while the fish came with "potatoes and grilled Brussel sprouts", which while technically correct, yielded about three tiny sprouts cut in half, and an identical amount of potatoes.

4.  For dessert we tried the "Compressed cotton candy grapes and melons."  For the uninitiated, cotton candy has nothing to do with the dessert--it's the type of psychotically overpriced grape they put on the plate.  In essence, you pay nine bucks for 8-10 small bites of fruit.

In summary, none of the food at Bouche was bad--to the contrary, it was good (although not spectacular)...the problem was that Bouche is simply not a good value for the money spent.  For two of us (WITHOUT any wine/beer--water only) our total was almost $110.  And we walked out hungry.

There are half-a-dozen restaurants in the Nob Hill area that will take less of your money and absolutely impress you more.  Unless you're seriously addicted to French food and small portions, I'd look elsewhere.
author: Trey D.

description: Oenophiles heaven! Fabulous and reasonably priced wines from small French producers. Lovely food to match and expert service. My table enjoyed the entrees (swordfish, hanger steak, pork loin) and raved about the desserts (cheese board, blood orange tart, dulce de leche creme caramel). Two menu appetizers were less interesting (chick pea fries, bacon bread) - but the off menu app (fois gras) was killer.
author: Joe B.

description:
The sort of place that makes San Francisco famous.

I ate here twice during a recent visit to SF, one for a business dinner with a couple of colleagues, then a few days later with my wife.  The place sort of defines intimate, but we enjoyed that.

Food was amazing, great service, and loved the Claypool Cellars pinot (Bouche is one of only a handful of restaurants with this great Russian River wine).
author: Lucian H.

description:
Bouche actually makes me feel like I'm in a quaint family-run restaurant in France, except the service is exceptional without any pretentiousness!!  Our waiter was the warmest French man I think I have ever met.  He was incredibly attentive and gave us fantastic wine recommendations.  

My Canadian boyfriend had a delicious steak with a heavenly butter sauce and exclaimed at the end of the meal "this is the BEST meal I have ever had in the US...better than any Michelin starred restaurant we have ever been to."  We ordered two desserts (one a custard and an ice cream) and they were nothing like we expected: they weren't super sweet like American desserts and almost had a savory cheesy taste to them.  Delightful!  I'm going to come back every week when we move next month!
author: Jane M.

description:
my gf and i had a great late dinner here on 11.28.2013 . however both of us got food poisoning. She started to vomit a couple hours later and i the next morning. followed by flu symptoms for a whole next day.  and we are just now better a day after.

i cant really prove that it was the food. however if someone else got sick the same night then thats that. apart from getting sick the food was amazing. we shared everything. starting with the poached egg+salad, scallop, snapper. all very good. we ended the night by sharing the goat cheese +beet ice cream. i couldn't taste the beet flavor but still a WOW. the portions are on the small side. so get a main dish per person and an a couple appetizers to share. i was a little hungry when i left. 

b/c we didnt make prior reservations we were seated at the counter next to the door. we noticed that the cooks would regularly come in/out of the restaurant bringing in pre-cooked food. i think their fridge is outside the restaurant. IDK but that might be a possible source of contamination.  

the service was great and the staff was very friendly. try it! we might have gotten very unlucky. however i would think twice about coming here next time just because i got sick the last time. but thats just me.
author: Filya B.

description:
All I can say is A-FREAKING-MAZING!!! After a lovely evening of drinks around SF, my boyfriend and I were pretty hungry, but didn't want just pizza or burgers. We found Bouche and I am so glad we did! 

The place is super tiny, but that sliver of restaurant creates a very intimate, laid back atmosphere - perfect vibe to cap off a night. 

The food is rich, so I'd suggest an appetizer or soup and maybe splitting your main dish?Each dish really showcases the ingredients without being too French-fussy. The white corn soup was wonderful! Pork was tender and fell off the bone.  Dessert was equally yummy and not overly sweet. 

Now when we have guests in, we'll hit The Tunnel Top for a few drinks and grab dinner at Bouche next door.  It's a bit pricey, but I don't mind considering it's more of an event than just dinner.
author: Jen N.

description:
What a delightful little French restaurant.  So easy to miss that you will go past it without knowing it is even a restaurant. The downstairs is a bar and waiting area.  People obviously also eat there.  The upstairs are several tables holding no less than 20 people.

All foods are delicious and creatively made.  My "green onion soup" was creamy yet with the grassy green onions.  The crusted halibut and duck confit were both excellent.  The duck is not the standard "breast and leg," but torn meats mixed in with a collection of veggie and stuff.  So it was less meaty.

The chestnut tart is really a piece of pie.  The crust was very thin and filling very rich.  Share it with someone.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Great place, I loved the atmosphere and the food was excellent. I would definitely go back. It's a cozy and romantic place.
author: Elodie D.

description:
Stumbled in here for a very late dinner after flying in from new york. Immediately felt like we got an attitude from the staff since we arrived so late. Our waitress definitely made a snide comment when we asked for a wine recommendation. 

You have to ask for bread and it was very lackluster for a French restaurant. The octopus salad was the highlight of my meal. The pork belly was too fatty for my taste. My dad thought he could cook a better cod.

Love the ambiance and decor of this place. Also has an open kitchen so you can watch the chefs cook! Would have enjoyed this place much more if the service had been nicer.
author: Melissa C.

description: Second time visitor here.  First time had the duck and wow!  This time has the scallops, pork tenderloin, and finished with the dulche de leche.   Both times I took the recommendation of the staff on wine.  Great people, great business and obviously great food.   Will be a regular! !
author: Steven B.

description:
Excellent food and wine pairing.
I had duck breast and the meat is tender and has wonderful flavor. Best duck dish i have ever tried. Duck confit that comes with the dish is ok. Wine are great tasting. The wait was quite long and they forgot to bring us bread that we requested.
author: Julia G.

description: If you like an intimate, low lit, 10 table restaurant that feels like europe and has great food and servers that dont hover over you... then this is your spot. Great menu and service, even on a no-reservation walk in. .
author: Nathan E.

description:
Bouche! It's fun to say.

I had dinner with two of my dude-friends a few weeks back. This place is intimate! The majority of the tables are built for two; unfortunately, three of us were crammed into one of these tables, and we bumped knees all night.

The wine list was a bunch of French stuff that I didn't really recognize, but the server recommended a great pinot noir that complemented everyone's dishes.

The food itself was a bit of a letdown; I ordered a lamb and apricot puree dish. The puree was great, but the lamb itself wasn't particularly memorable. My friends were similarly unimpressed with their dishes (salmon and the lamb again, with a salad side).

I'd probably go back once more on a one-on-one or a date. The setting's nice enough that if I found a good dish I could make this place a more frequent stop, but my first experience really wasn't super-positive.
author: Bill H.

description:
Service- The host and waiters were prompt and attentive.  

Ambiance- It is  a quaint restaurant that is very tiny.  You sit quite close to other tables, but I don't mind that.  All the tables are up stairs while downstairs contains kitchen and bar seating (also available for dining).  

Food- I was in an off mood so everything that evening was a little off for me.  But, even with that the food was very good.  The food also came out very fast.

Appetizers- We order three to share which was a little much for two people.  But all three were very tasty.  I especially like the salt cod, and I don't especially like salt cod.  The soup and pork belly were also tasty but the fish won me over.  The salt cod came as a baked cheese spread with toasted bread which were topped with a spicy blend of herbs and vegetables.

Entree- My partner ordered the salmon which I ate half and was very good.  cooked just right, slightly raw in the middle.  The glaze did not over power the taste of the fish.

I ordered the venison which was done very well.  The sauce and herbs made it really tasty.  It wasn't gamy (I was hoping for a gamy taste) but still very good.  The meat was also very tender.

Dessert- We ordered the Creme Fraiche which came as two little bowls.  One of the Creme Fraiche and another with slated caramel.  That was her choice as I am not big on desserts.  It was sweet enough to fulfill her sweet tooth but not too heavy or large as to make us feel bloated.

Criticism-  the only thing I really didn't like were the potatoes that were served with the venison.  I felt it made the dish have a slightly mushy consistency.  (this is being a little critical, but as my only complaint I thought you might want to know)

Overall- I would definitely go back hands down.  I would like to go back and try their other meals for sure.  Make a reservation as it is small people don't rush through their meals.

FYI- I spent about $100 on 3 appetizers, 2 entrees, 1 dessert, 1 coke and not alcohol.
author: Eron L.

description:
Good food, very charming and quaint little place.  The servers are very personable and accommodating.  Overall a really good experience.  Best dish i tried was the duck confit and beet appetizer.  Couldnt get enough of this stuff.  The duck was rich and flavorful and well matched with the sweetness of the beets.  The dish was topped with wild greens which offered a little bitterness to match the other flavors.

The halibut was good as well, but lacked textural complexity. The dish was a bit too mushy.  I didnt like the brussel sprouts.  They fried the leaves which takes away the textural crunch of eating the whole or half sprout.  Couldnt taste enough bacon as well.

Lastly the portions were tiny, more like tapas, so order a little bit extra if you are hungry.
author: Scott C.

description: I've been here three times, every time the food is perfectly portioned and super tasty, but not the average "American" tasty with heavy salt or sugar- this French restaurant has the perfect healthy combination of sugars and spices. The meat is perfectly cooked, the vegetables perfectly seared. The raw aspect of this French restaurant is perfect, and the atmosphere is that of a "hole in the wall" French restaurant. I love this place and took my girlfriend here whom I care about very much. Take someone here you care about, they will be amazed. The wine is perfect, and all of it is priced very French. You pay for what you get here and it's just super cozy. You'll know when you get here...Bon appetite!
author: Charlie M.

description: Excellent food and excellent service. . . We managed to get a seat at the little kitchen bar which turned out to be a fun choice.  The entire staff is such a good time, everything is cooked fresh and tastes exceptional! Can't name the items we ordered but I know it was delicious!
author: Brenda D.

description: Awesome food and reasonable prices!  A friend of mine who went with me said it was a very Parisian type cuisine...  good stuff!  We had the steak and it melted in my mouth.  The Pork belly was also very yummy.
author: Michael N.

description:
Hi all i just find the diamond in san francisco.... Well first i am french second i am on restaurant business for 27 years..
Ok so this place is an authentic french place with french food french waiters french chef french  .. The provence is where the boss coming ..
First appetizer i had the tartar ... Very good my girlfriend had the arugula salad with poached egg .. Very yummy .
Main course i ha the lamb shank.. Omg was a beast.....dessert cheese special and my gf goat cheese cake with beet ice cream .. Fantastic..
Well if you want a real french experience  in san francisco,  go see guillaume  the boss and his crew for an unique dinner
Frenchy.
author: Frenchy G.

description:
I love Bouche! Hands down one of the favorite restaurants in this city. It's small and intimate, the food is delicious, the waiters have French accents! It's also not extremely popular so you don't have to wait 2+ hours to get a table. 

If you sit upstairs, you get the bird's eye view of the action in the kitchen.
author: Tatyana K.

description: A closed kitchen at the Burritt Room resulted in the helpful bartender recommended this place so we walked around the corner for a bit of dessert and wine. It totally reminded me of being in France, down to the diminutive size and our amusing waiter being half Italian & French. Sitting at the chef's table--the bar overlooking the kitchen on the ground level--we enjoyed a simple yet decadent pannacotta with sea-salted dulche de leche and two lovely wines while we watched the chef prepare excellent looking dishes. What a find!
author: Liz K.

description:
This is a five star restaurant in downtown San Francisco.

Although I have never been to Paris, I know the look, feel, and atmosphere of Bouche mirrors that of France. From when you walk in until you leave, you will be greeted and treated with French accents, and polite and helfpul service.

My colleague and I made a reservation for 8 PM on a Wednesday evening and were promptly greeted and seated by our host.  We were offered sparkling water and support in selecting any wine for the evening.  Luckily my colleague has a good understanding of wines and with a little bit of guidance, we were off.

As far as food is concerned, this was spectacular.  Duck confit, cheese plate, bacon fougasse (DO NOT LEAVE WITHOUT TRYING THIS).  The arrangement of appetizers and French-made butter was amazing.  While I could have stopped there, I needed an entree - so I got the lamb.

They will tell you that the lamb is cooked medium rare, and it is, and it is so flavorful.  Deliciously and beautifully plated, this dish cannot be passed up. My only regret is indulging entirely too much in the bacon fougasse that I was pretty full by the time our entrees arrived.

Overall, this was a spectacular meal in a cozy location.  I absolutely loved Bouche, and you will too.  But as I mentioned before, GET THE BACON FOUGASSE.
author: Anjali K.

description:
Wow.  Authentic French cuisine.  No shortcut taken.  That's the thing with French food done well.  At the surface, some things may seem simple and easy and short, but it never is.  Their dishes offer very complex combinations of tastes, that deserve the time to be savored.
This is the kind of place where you should go with appetizer, main, and dessert, and wine.  Don't skimp.  It's totally worth it.  And I'm cheap, but I'm saying this because I really believe they know what they're doing :)  Splurge and go the distance with them.  They'll hit a home run and your date will think so too. :)
Only bring 1 person btw.  It's cramped.  That detracts NOTHING from the quality of dishes they offer.

Would go again.
author: Crypto M.

description:
Heard good things from a few people so I was excited. Walked in. Got sat. Waited a while for food, but that's understandable because we for a glance at the line on the way in and it was very small. Banana beignets- tasted not much like banana. The scallop crudo- ew. Forced ourselves to eat it because we were starving. The scallops were way over powered by salt less slaw of apples, cabbage, citrus, and tomatoes! Yes tomatoes! C'mon....no respectable menu has tomatoes right now. And garnished with so much oil that I was kinda grossed out by my slippery greasy lips afterwards. Not to mention the over powering flavor of raw shallot or onion. Idk which it was because I couldn't actually see it. It just didn't work. Sorry. Pork n beans- that was ok. I give it a 61/2. Could've gotten more if it wasn't cold. And lastly- the tartar. Slightly underseasoned and almost half of my fingerling chips stuck together making them soggy/chewy/leathery chips. We didn't even finish it. Server asked how it was and I said it was just ok with a disappointed face. Not worth going Into detail because they probably thought we were just picky eaters and not actual SF chefs (which we are). O well. They took the tartar off the bill though so that's why they got two stars instead of one. Sorry Bouche, I tried.

Just in- I rembered I also ordered the spicy crawfish and it never came. I thought something was missing but couldn't remember what it was. But after reviewing the menu I remembered. Too bad.
author: mel l.

description:
Excellent service, good food. I liked the appetizers better than the main courses. Very romantic atmosphere. The place upstairs is tiny and I would recommend reservations! There's only 16 seats. Very small quaint location with good service.

Apps:
Scallop- delicious and wish they would make a main entree out of it.
Bacon fougasse- If you don't know what this is, it's bacon bits in french bread.
Crab mashed potatoes- delicious, complex, but heavy

Entree:
The snapper was well-seasoned and delicious. I would try other entrees if I return.
author: Kristina N.

description:
I spent a day in SF with my parents and decided to come here for dinner.  We made a 5:30 reservation using opentable.  They called us earlier in the day to make sure we were coming and of course, I said yes!

PARKING:
We parked in a parking structure right by Union Square.  Don't remember what it's called [Sutter Stockton Garage] but  Bouche was literally a block away from the structure.  So it worked out quite nicely!  I don't remember the rates but depending on which hour of the day you park, you pay a different amount for each hour you're there.  It ranges from $1-$4.

AMBIANCE:
This place is TINY! No wonder they made sure we were going to be on time for our reservations.  There's probably 25 seats total.  The main dining area is upstairs with 2-3 person tables.  And several seats downstairs by the kitchen.  I loved the feel of it. Very cozy, homey.  I loved all the decor, a nice antique look.  And the kitchen/line where they prep the food is pretty small and you can see everything going on.  It looked like all they had in the back was a dish pit.

SERVICE:
Heh, felt sorry for the servers who had to climb up and down the stairs, but they were very attentive and refilled our glasses when needed.  No complaints.

FOOD:
I'm guessing due to their small size and extremely tiny kitchen {if you can even call it that], it explains why their menu has very little selection.  But hey, I love it that way! Quality over quantity!

Sauteed Sweetbread, Porcini Cream, Chanterelles and Black Trumpet Mushroom Persillade

It looks like their dishes vary slightly than what's on their website.  It's small things though like the variety of mushroom they have on hand.  I believe online it says "Lobster Mushroom Persillade" but on the menu it was "Black Trumpet".  Just FYI.

It was my first time having sweetbreads WHICH is not actually bread.  If I tell you what it actually is you probably won't want to eat it [and now you're going to look it up if you don't know].  But it was delicious! The texture was lovely, crispy and soft on the inside.  Flavor was great and all the earthiness of the mushrooms complimented it well.  The only slightly negative thing I have to say was it was a bit too salty for me.  But overall, a great first try at sweetbreads and would love to eat it again!

Wild Greens, Caramelized Pear, Roquefort, Walnut and Endive Vinaigrette, Pepper Crust Bacon And Pickled Poached Egg

Despite it being a salad, it was amazing!  The greens were mostly arugula.  The pear added sweetness and the bacon added crunch and saltiness.  We were told to break the egg, mix it with the vinaigrette and eat it with the salad. The roquefort was actually in the sauce as well. It was a delicious amazing salad.  The richness of the egg yolk and cheese balanced out the spicy bite of the arugula.  The acidity of the vinaigrette cut through the richness.  It was well balanced and really delicious.  It was probably my favorite dish of the night. [A salad?? No way! Yeah I know, thought it wouldn't happen either]

Pan Seared Petrale Sole, Crispy Porcini Risotto, Espelette and Carrot Puree, Lobster Cream Sauce

The sole was lovely.  Cooked well,, nice and tender.  The risotto {more like an arancini in this case) was delicious as well, added some texture.  The puree was amazing.  Smooth and sweet bursting with lovely carrot flavor.  And the cream sauce tying it all together.  This was definitely my parents favorite dish.

Citrus and Honey Confit Lamb Shank, Ratatouille, Roasted Almonds and Pomegrante Couscous

I was a little disappointed with this dish.  The lamb shank was tasty as was the rataoutille.  But everything was SO HEAVY, it need some kind of acid to cut through the richness.  The pomegranates and the citrus in the couscous helped a tiny bit, but after finishing the dish, I just wanted to drink some lemon juice, straight.  It was also a touch too salty, though I guess the lack of salt in the couscous made up for that.

Tomahawk Pork Chop, Butter Beans, Walnut and Quince Marmalade Grape and Cognac Sauce

I didn't get to try everything on this plate together, but none of us REALLY liked this dish much.  The pork was a bit overcooked which of course meant dry.  The butter beans were alright.  I don't know, nothing really impressed me about this dish or left me wanting more.  

Overall, a great experience.  I know I left a bit of a sour note [pun intended] regarding the food but really overall most things were executed well.  Especially since it was my first time having sweetbreads and they were delicious! Definitely a great way to end the day!
author: Christopher C.

description:
I think i'm in love with this restaurant! Everything on their menu looked delicious especially their mashed potato. I forgot how the mashed potato dish was called on their menu but it was AMAZING! We ordered a bunch of appetizers: mashed potato with crab and cheese, Squash soup to share, sweetbread with wild mushrooms and another appetizer (I totally forgot what it was but it was DELICIOUS!) Bouche made me miss Paris :( Our waitress was great, I would give their overall service 5 stars out of 5!!!! Loved their selection of wine and the overall ambiance and THEY ARE OPEN TILL 1AM :D

I will definitely be back for more amazing French food!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Delicious butternut squash soup, definitely not large enough to share but an awesome start on a colder night. 
The squash and eggplant may sound like a miss, but the combination is to die for and leaves you surprisingly full. 
Being gluten free, there are usually few dessert options for me, but the custard here makes up for all past disappointment. With a salted crust and side of melted carmel, I would go back just for this!
And finally the wine list, I have no idea what I was looking at and bought the cheapest red; figured I would rather spend more on food.
author: Carolyn P.

description:
This place was super cute and romantic for a dinner date with my special man on our anniversary. We felt so French for the night! Great wine and nice food. Thanks guys.

Sarah
author: Sarah H.

description:
It's been a month but I'm going to leave a short review anyway.

I really enjoyed the ambiance of the restaurant even though it was really crowded since the restaurant is definitely on the smaller side. The service was great and the servers (maybe they were managers since 2 of them spoke with a French accent?) were very nice, patient and talkative.

Now to the food, I liked the food, a lot actually (mashed potatoes oh nom nom nom) but it wasn't anything to brag about considering the price range. But on the other hand I'm one of those people who have a strong preference for very limited dishes (usually cheap, greasy food at grimy restaurants) so I don't think I can be the judge of that. In addition, I didn't get to taste any of the wines they have to offer but I'm assuming that is also a highlight of the restaurant.

Either way, I really enjoyed my time there (may return in the future when I'm in the mood I suppose) and if you are not sure if you should try it out, I say go for it.
author: Mona H.

description: Food is incredible here! One star off for portion size because I always leave this place hungry...they don't give you bread if you don't say anything, so maybe it will help if you ask for it. A little pricy, but definitely worth coming.
author: Angelina M.

description: Small and cozy atmosphere, delicious food and friendly staff. I would definelty come here again. Great place to bring a date!
author: Via Fume C.

description:
The place is charming.
The food is a bit too strange to my taste.
I was expecting classic French food - it looked to me that they came up with an creative menu for the sake of being creative but not with great results.
author: Leslie P.

description:
This truly is as good as it gets.  Ambiance is incredibly romantic, service is casual yet impeccable and the FOOD!  The menu changes all the time, but I'm sure the fougasse (bacon bread) isn't going anywhere, and it's a must-have.  Other pieces of perfection include the sweetbreads or scallop for apps, and the snapper or pork chop for entrees.  The beet ice cream with goat cheese cake and the creme fraiche custard may very well be two of the best desserts I've ever tasted.

Pork chop could have been a wee bit more flavorful, and the scallop could have been a wee bit bigger (or plural).  But with a place like this, are we really going to go that picky?
author: Dave N.

description:
If you don't order the duck confit "balls", you are stupid. 

Seriously though, this restaurant inspired me to cancel my Italy trip for 2015 and schedule a trip to France. It totally turned on my taste for French cuisine. I couldn't be more pleased with the service and the food.

The bonus was that everything was reasonably priced. No reservations in giving it a 5 star review.
author: Patrick O.

description:
Recommend it and be proud of it !
Great over all experience. We followed other yelpers... Crab Mash, Lamb all very good. Great wine list and affordable. Bacon Fougasse should be more authentic but very tasty. We had a great night and will be back
Thanks
author: Christophe D.

description:
So yummy! I can't wait to go back here. My gf and I decided to have a romantic date night after a day at the spa. I love the quaint area they have set up. It's everything but pretentious, and the small upper level they have to dine in makes it homey.

We ordered the duck croquette, lamb, stuffed chicken and the mushrooms as a side dish. I LOVED my lamb. I'll love lambs from this moment on based on how good Bouche's lamb was! And for dessert (of course), we ordered the goat cheese cake. It came with was wad of beet ice cream that went perfectly with the cheesecake.

Service was on it and staff was friendly. The quality of food was the best I've had in a while!
author: Crystal C.

description: Nice atmosphere- small, cozy, dark French restaurant with a small menu and great wine selection. Tasty food and nice ambience. Great place to have dinner for two or with a small group- especially upstairs
author: Josh C.

description:
Gush gush gush.

I love that the dining room is like this secret little haven above the noisy crowded bar.

We tried almost everything on the menu. It was all fantastic.

Our waiter was very friendly, helpful, and personable. He helped us select great wines, and he was also multilingual, which was a great surprise since one of our guests only spoke Spanish.

Nothing but good things to say!
author: Lynae Z.

description: What a great place! We stumbled in here on accident and really lucked out. Awesome food, service, ambiance. I'd recommend it to everyone!
author: Sarah M.

description:
Nice little French place that serves great food. The kitchen is tiny and it's a bit cramped, but overall great experience. Food was pretty much on par with what I had in France (the 3-star Michelin restaurant I went to in Paris being the exception).

The portions are a little bigger than what you'd get in France, but not your huge American-size portions either, so you can get an appetizer, main course, and dessert without being absolutely stuffed.

All-in-all, I'd definitely go back again.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
MERVEILLEUX

This place is run by several friends from France.  It is small and great. Made reservation on open table and no wait. Place was full.  I had lamb and friend has the fish.  We both loved it.  It would make a great place for a date rather than with a business associate
author: JR H.

description:
Came here because the burritt closed their kitchen at 1030 and one of the servers recommended bouche since they serve til midnight.

Julie is amazing. She's very personable and gave us the best service in sf. We got the crab mashed potatoes, pork chop, wild salad and the scallop. Presentation was perfect. Only thing I'd do differently is ask for the food to come out seperately so I can enjoy the taste of each dish. Definitely coming back!
author: Madonna J.

description:
We heard about this restaurant for a while, finally got the opportunity to go.  
The ambiance was great, little place on Bush st,  but well organized and decorated. Very cool, cozy feeling. The space is a bit tight, but hey! it is San Francisco! I like the arrangement of the restaurant, very cleverly laid out. 

The wine list was not as complete for my personal taste, but they got some unique selection that other French restaurants may not have. The food...it was full of surprise and very original! We started with  bacon fougasse and duck confit, the duck confit was not what I expected, but it was delicious. I only wish it were not fried, it was a bit greasy for my personal taste. For the main course, we had chicken paupiette and red snapper. They were delicious, different style of presentation and cooking. The portions were perfect. For Americans or diners used to American styles, they might be on the smaller side. But the dishes were definitely quality!  

For desert, we had a goat cheesecake and beet ice cream. THAT WAS VERY unique and out of ordinary. The goat cheesecake was creamy and tasty, and beet compliments the taste in an ice cream format. Excellent idea! 

To me, what was offered here was not an authentic traditional French cuisine, but the new French cuisine with a twist. I like the creativity and elements of surprise.

A little suggestion: we were seated on the second floor, it might just have been a bit darker than what I'd like to it to be. I want my eyes to enjoy the beautiful presentation and food elements as much as my stomach!

Finally, service was excellent. Merci beaucoup!
author: Ann W.

description:
My Favorite french restaurant in the whole city.   Julie is a fantastic host and always accommodates people very well given such a little space.

One of my friend's whos lived in SF for a good 15 years said during dinner here once, that this place epitomizes the best of the cities restaurants.  For sure.

I love the combination of flavors they bring to dishes,  herbs,  mushrooms, cured bacony meats .. ohh man.    I'm a fan of the pork chop, the frisee salad, and other delectables that rotate on the menu.  Be sure to get a side of the country mushrooms - they are so yummy
author: Ben I.

description:
The restaurant is small quaint place. We want on a rainy day and it had a musky and gross smell. I got over it because I wanted to try the food. 

The wine menu was all in French ok I get it French restaurant. The waitress made some good suggestions and we moved on. 

The lobster bisque special was alright and I would not get it again. The bacon foguee basically bacon bread was not good. It was too greasy and made me nauseous.  I had the seared red snapper and it was good.  My husband had the lamb shanks it's decent.  The mashed potato with dinges crab was good. Overall food was decent but not to die for! 

Service was really good and I think it's this place's saving grace.
author: Vicky D.

description: Wow!!! By far the best French food I have had in SF. I had the Herbes De Provence Venison. So good. Absolutely delicious. The chief is personable. The services is lovely.
author: Amina A.

description:
This Nob Hill neighborhood spot is an absolute gem!  The small, intimate setting is the perfect; warm and inviting.  

The staff is absolutely rocks!  Melissa, the head chef, is a rock-star in the kitchen!  She consistently makes beautiful, French food with a modern, California-inspired twist.  With an ever-changing menu, there is always something new and exciting to try!

One of San Francisco's best kept secret, this is a place not to miss!
author: Skylar S.

description:
I am in San Francisco for a few days for work and fortuitously stumbled into Bouche. Bouche is tucked away on the side of Bush Street, with a somewhat nondescript exterior and a lovely interior that was intimate and quite charming. Three of us were seated in the upstairs area, which had maybe 6-8 tables or so. The table was a little crammed but cozy. 

My coworker and I split the charcuterie plate, which was tasty. I ordered the pan seared day boat scallop with tarragon polenta for my entree. For an appetizer, it was generously sized, with two perfectly cooked, tender scallops sitting on top of a bed of creamy polenta. I also got a side of the market greens - I was expecting a salad of some sort but was given green beans lightly fried in a tempura batter. They were addictively good. Overall we really enjoyed Bouche and will definitely be back the next time we are in town!
author: Mimi L.

description:
the perfect place for a low key dinner.  we had the bacon bread, scallops, lamb shank and dungeness crab mash potatoes.  the scallop and polenta was amazing.  bacon bread and dungeness crab mash was good.  the lamb shank was good but not noteworthy.  our order was enough to leave 2 people stuffed without room for dessert.  

the wine list was sufficient and place was cozy.  i plan on adding Bouche to my restaurant rotation!
author: Amy J.

description:
The food was excellent. The service was very attentive. We didn't have a reservation and we were seated at the window. My wife is pregnant and the host went out of his way to get us a table so she would be comfortable. 

Overall a great experience.
author: Fred A.

description:
Are you kidding me?  Bouche has to be the tiniest 5 Star restaurant I have ever been to.  The upstairs has maybe 8 tables each set for two people and there is literally no room for your handbag.  I actually like that about this place.  The lighting was very romantic and the rustic decor made you feel like you truly were in France (except for laundry mat across the street).  

My husband and I had no clue what to order so we had our server, Gael order for us.  This turned out to be a good decision.  The wine we had, Corbieres, was delicious.  We also had something called Panisses which he said was something the French ate everyday.  I think it was chickpea french fries in perfect cubes.  Really good.  I had the Flat Iron Steak and it was divine.
author: Michelle E.

description: Pleasant cozy and reasonably priced French place close to my neighborhood. Reminded me of a restaurant I once enjoyed in Paris near the Eiffel Tower! We ate an early dinner on a Friday night. Sat upstairs next to the window and enjoyed the cool breeze. Portions are French...not American! Enjoyed the yellowtail carpaccio as an appetizer. I ordered halibut and found it just ok. Hubby ordered the beef and it was yummy! The wait staff was friendly, efficient and helpful with our wine selection. BUT the best part of the meal...Chocolate mouse! Don't miss it! Worth a visit.
author: Mary B.

description: Amazing French Resturaunt not far from Union Square
author: Peter K.

description:
Disappointed that the highly-touted pork belly was not on the menu when the GF and I had dinner here this past weekend. However, it didn't really matter because the dishes we ended up getting were excellent anyway!

I made a reservation on Friday night about an hour before our actual reservation time (8:15 PM). Super win! We got there a little early, around 8. We were seated right away in the upstairs area. Ultra win!

Service was A+ great. The French-speaking waitstaff with their thick European accents really added to the overall flavor of Bouche. The interior is pretty small, but the ambience is great. They really use the dim lighting, dark wood, and metal decor to create a great, rustic atmosphere that really sets the tone for a great date night. To make the night even sweeter, the waiter realized that he didn't have enough wine to fill an entire glass for my GF. Instead of charging us half-price, or some small percentage, he gave us the wine on the house! Not to mention, all of our food was brought out in a timely manner, and our bread replenished without hesitation. Excellent service.

The food was amazing as well. I had the veal, which was accompanied by this amazingly, succulent, rich gravy with mushrooms. The veal was tender and easily cut with merely a fork. The GF got the kale-stuffed risotto which was crisped perfectly and accompanied with a pleasantly cool, minty salad and two complementary sauces (spicy and nutty). The portions were small, but that is to be expected from a higher-class restaurant such as Bouche. Just fill up on the free bread and butter if you must.

To top it off, we had the creme fraiche custard with some dessert wine, which was the happy ending to our happy meal. 

You will not go wrong with Bouche if you're looking for that perfect, intimate restaurant to spend with your loved one!
author: Dan K.

description:
Bouche is what every cafe aspires to be: low key, casual, good food, with good conversation to be had between strangers and friends, customers and staff. 

A good choice for any night out on the town.
author: Doug C.

description:
*4.5 stars*

I felt like I was reaching the end of my rope with Contemporary-American-French cuisine. Restaurant after restaurant, it just seemed like the same old dishes -- roasted chicken (or quail), braised short ribs, or grilled pork chop with some kind of tart fruit glaze. It got to the point where I started to never crave anything that was "Contemporary-American-French." In fact, without foie gras, I feel like French food (at least in SF) has become boring in general. Tasty, perhaps, but boring. That is until I came to Bouche. 

Now, there were some small misses here and there, but honestly, the food at Bouche breathes so much new creative life into the SF food scene that it's worth those small flaws to enjoy a meal that actually makes Contemporary French exciting again.

--------------
FOOD:

Scallops:
I loved the intricate and subtly sweet flavor to this dish. The dish is a cold dish, which kind of caught me off guard, but the scallops were insanely tender. 

Marinated Salmon:
This was one of my favorite dishes of the night. The salmon meshed perfectly with the crunchy (equivalent of a) bird's nest and the creme fraiche. I've never had anything like this before and it was an incredible first.

Lamb Shoulder:
I normally don't like lamb due to its sour gaminess, but the lamb shoulder is cooked to absolute perfection. It tastes like a very tender braised beef short rib, which is awesome for those who normally hate lamb. What really makes this dish, though, is the sauce -- a sweet marmalade with crunchy almonds-- that really brings out the flavor of the lamb shoulder. I could've done without the tangy sorbet-like carrot coriander puree, since there was so much sweetness in the marmalade already. Perhaps a more subtle puree, like turnip or potato, would complement the marmalade better.

Veal:
The veal had an amazing flavor, but it was a bit too well-done. Whatever flavors they used though, worked very well.

Creme Fraiche Panna Cotta:
This dessert was a bit too boring and tasteless for me, except those moments when all you have in your mouth is salt (not enjoyable either). The caramel sauce was a nice touch, but it just needed something else to really make this panna cotta memorable.

--------------

Bouche has an intimate, hidden atmosphere that really brings out a rustic, underground Paris ambiance. It's actually pretty cool. Kind of reminds me of the upstairs section of Gitane. 

Shane, our server, was on point. Our water was always filled, our wine glasses were never empty. 

All in all, what I love most about Bouche is that it really pushes the envelope when it comes to discovering wildly inventive flavors. Most of what I ate tonight brought flavors and textures that I've never had before, and it was incredible to experience. I'm impatiently looking forward to a return visit.
author: Roy C.

description:
