If you appreciate fine details, ambiance and delicious food, you MUST come here for dinner.

Located a few blocks away from Union Square, I normally have a prejudice against restaurants in this area for being tourist traps. Shiny but bad.

Bouche is the ultimate wake up call that prejudice is never good and you should always give places a chance.
Everything about the restaurant deserves 5 starts:

Design: The restaurant is full of magic, the attention to detail is amazing and between the beautiful lights, moldings design and decorations, you can feed your eyes on top of your stomach.
Ambiance: Great music in a perfect "I can still talk without yelling" volume, set the tone for a great conversation 
Service: Genuinely nice and friendly service, honestly, I would love to be friends with everyone who served or table
Food: Delicious. We tried multiple items and they were all delicious, hard to go wrong.

Will definitely pay another visit soon and try their brunch as well.

nJoy!
author: Assaf B.

description:
I've always wondered about this play hidden on top of the Stockton Street Tunnel and right next to Tunnel Top.  The place is pretty much tucked in as a French Hole in the Wall.  It's no where near family friendly but offers a great comforting homey ambiance for two people to have a nice dinner together in the Union Square area.

My friend and I shared a bottle of wine and indulged in a few dishes.  The smoked salmon on poached egg seems to be everyone's favorite, as it should be since it gives that salmon tartare type of feeling and is easily devoured if you're normally into that sort of stuff.

I had the pork belly which was a delicious dish but didn't offer any outstanding notes.  Generally, the meal was good, but the place itself is just what makes the meal.  It's a perfect place for a date using fresh tasty ingredients.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Food: 3
Decor: 3
Service: 4

Came here for dinner on a weekday night at 9pm.

1. Fougasse
~Okay. Basically just bread with bacon.

2. Duck Confit Croquants, Japanese and Watermelon Radishes, Cherry Sauce
~Pretty good. Croquants were excellent, and the radishes were an interesting complement.

3.Stuffed Chicken Paupiette, Brussels Sprouts Cream, Asparagus, Peach, Spinach, Sage Sausage and Bell Pepper Coulis
~Okay. Chicken was prepared well, but I found the combination of ingredients to be rather odd. I didn't think the bitterness of the asparagus and spinach complemented the sweetness or tartness of the rest of the dish very well.

Service was good.
author: David L.

description: This is a perfect little place! The filet sandwich was amazing and raspberry Bellini num num
author: Cassie M.

description:
Getting to bouche by accident, as it was late and hardly any other kitchen was still open we had a wonderful dinner. 
We chose the vegetarian dish and the pan seared fish. Both dishes were perfect in the amount and very tasty. But the best thing was the dessert: goat cheesecake with nuts and  beetroot icecream. Very special in the composition but close to perfection wrt dessert.
author: Johanna G.

description: Highly Recommended. My best friend and I stopped there by chance just walking by, we were early and snagged two seats at the side counter. It's a small place, counter spots downstairs, 8 tables upstairs. We shared the pork belly, the scallop carpaccio, and the salmon with brussels sprouts and bacon. Flavorful and delicious. Bouche is an authentic French nation and has a really elegant touch.
author: Michelle O.

description:
Good food but not totally French food.. 
I was disappointed not to see typical French dessert... Otherwise the place is nice, romantic... But I really preferred "La Folie"or "Chapeau"...
author: Cristelle M.

description: Excellent food, excellent wine, excellent service!! Highly recommend!! We had the steak dish and it was delicious!!! The sous chef was preparing the food in front of us and she didn't seem bothered that we were asking her lots of questions. Cute place!! Go there if you can and like to be more adventurous and have delicious French food!
author: Cherie T.

description: We very much enjoyed this experience. Service was excellent. Quite tiny and cramped but we didn't mind. Foie Gras was perfect. And so was the halibut. Nice sized portions. Highly recommend.
author: Jill D.

description: The place is very tiny and romantic-- and it feels authentically French. They sat us on time and had the table ready. The service was polite and the food was great. We ate the pork belly, chickpea fries, steak, swordfish, and squash. All delicious. The steak was a bit cold. The pear pies were the best dessert-- amazing! I would go again!
author: Katie M.

description: This place is amazing. The vibe made me feel like I was transported back to Paris. Voila. Au Revoir. There are actually French speaking people who work here. Very much appreciated. The actual restaurant itself is small, super cute, and cozy. The place has a nice ambience. If you sit at the bar, you can watch the chefs cook in front of you. It didn't get smelly or smoky from the cooking, which was nice. Every dish my fiance and I ordered was very good. We had the wild boar entree, the roasted veal entree, the wild mushroom medley as a side, and a panna cotta with salted caramel tres de leche for dessert. Each dish was unique and complex with an explosion of flavors. We enjoyed our meal very much. I am addicted to French food. This place was such a nice find after a day of drinking by the Ball Park & shopping in Union Square. It was a short walk from Union Square. It is a little place hidden above and by the Stockton Tunnel.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Decided to try again since they have a seasonal menu.  

Pros: Beef tartare was great but it was so dark I didn't even notice the pesto on the plate until after the dish was finished.  

Cons: Beers weren't cold.  Lobster bisque had a weird smoky taste which was overwhelming.  Had to ask for bread, twice (maybe three times).  Pork chop was mediocre (at best), for the price, I prefer NOPA.  The lamb was also meh, again for the price I would venture somewhere with better atmosphere, customer service, and preparation e.g. Kokkari.
author: Courtney C.

description:
We stopped by for a late night supper.  I found them with Yelp and am glad I did!

The space is tiny, but we were seated without a wait. The loft is intimate. The host/waiter was very attentive. 

The food? We each had an appetizer and a side. The Dungeness crab mashed potatoes were the best potato anything I think I've ever had. 

Every item was served quickly and prepared perfectly. We will definitely return on a future SF visit.
author: Ben D.

description:
Really 4 1/2 stars. 
French inspired, but not a cliche. Creative menu. Not a long list of choices, but what we had was quite good and the service was excellent.  Red snapper was excellent,
As was the Napoleon of squashes and eggplant. 
By the way, Google Maps gives incorrect driving directions. Bouche is located on Bush street. Ignore instructions to turn on Burritt street.
author: Steven T.

description:
"Oh Man, these guys are REALLY French." 

That was the first thing that my brother said as soon as we sat down. Can't blame him because one of the two waiters who served us had on an incredibly loud outfit. Plum colored bell bottoms and a matching patterned rayon/silk shirt. He had the craziest shoulder length hair too. And some kind of chin-strappy facial-scape. He was quite a site and I wish I were brave enough to take a picture. 

Between the 3 of us, we got to sample a good variety of their offerings. We even had two orders of the salmon; which, btw, wasn't hard because the portion was petite. It was also the best dish of the evening as it was minimally executed. It was like salmon tartar with thin crispy noodles. The pepper note really brought out the velvety texture of the poached egg.

My least favorite dish was the wild boar civet as it was tough and lacked flavor. Everything else kind of fell in between the salmon and boar. I also ordered the wild mushroom side dish, but it wasn't cleaned well; some of the mushrooms still had a bit of sand and I found a twig. We ended the night sharing the creme fraiche custard which I enjoyed because I like panna cotta. Even though it was heavy cream, it tasted light and refreshing.

The space is tiny, so do make a reservation. It is divided into lower level, which shares space with the kitchen, and a mezzanine level. We sat on top and I got a good view of the kitchen staff in action.

The ambiance is quaint and it's more fitted for an intimate get together with one other person. I recall coming here when it was Bar Crudo and thinking that same thought too. Service was attentive; the other waiter (sin loud outfit) kept our water/wine glasses replenished and cleared our plates in a timely manner. When it was time to pay our bill, he was very European about it and didn't rush us. I like the concept of French small plates and wish them success.
author: Beagle M.

description: Needed late night dining after flying into the city. What a find. Great wine and food. halibut and chicken breast were moist and delicious. Simple french style cooking. Can't wait to go back.
author: Linda T.

description:
Ok food is good, place very tiny...wine very expensive for not a great experience. 150$ for a Cote Rotie very average is quite disappointing.

Atmosphere typical french inside.
author: Alex P.

description:
Took my fiancée here on her birthday. I tell you their lamb special was Excellent, but their Roasted Veal Blade, Pommes Duchesse, Cipollini Onions and Crême Jus were dry and bland. 

As for desserts we tried their 'Tart of the Day', it was a chocolate and walnut tart; it was okay i guess, had better desserts. But their Creme Fraiche Custard was Excellent. 

Overall, the food was good. the ambiance was great, we had the window seat which was nice other than it was drafty. 

Good experience.
author: Jason H.

description:
I went here again on Tuesday night and got the same warm wonderful service....
Enjoyed every bite of dinner....especially the Salad:  Arugula Salad, Fava Bean Purée, English Peas, Spring Garlic, Cured Ham and Pickled Poached Egg
I don't believe I can ever go here and not order this for sure. I dream of this salad....
Oh and they have a new dessert...sweet, salty Creme Fraiche with a delicious caramel sauce you dip it in...crazy good!!!
author: Kim M.

description: wonderful small place. Late night dinner, 11 p.m.  with great wine and service. I would definitely go back! thanks!
author: Gustavo L.

description:
I came to this restaurant due to all the rave reviews but I left pretty disappointed.

To start off with the good points...

My friend really enjoyed the Salmon appetizer on the fried nest with poached egg. 

I liked the way the restaurant looked inside. It was cozy and I liked how the upstairs overlooked the kitchen.

The other dish he ordered was the veal which I thought was dry, bland, and not very good quality. Tasted more like overcooked stew beef. The BBQ flavor to it was also a bit strange. Instead of the veal coming out it one succulent piece, it was already precut to little chunks. Which I also think is a bit of the scam considering the price of the dish, the precut pieces made it seem like there was more food than was actually there.

I ordered the Duck Confit Croquant which were three meatballs made of duck. It was ok tasting but also very dry and a bit bland. I would have preferred Trader Joe's frozen turkey meatballs hands down. The cherry garnishings on it were good though.

I also ordered the Pasta Prawn pasta sea urchin app and that was probably the worst dish there. It consisted of a few chunks of sea urchin which WERE very good and creamy. However it also only had two baby clams, half a dry baked prawn with the shell still on it. I could barely scrape any meat out. And a little piece of toast totally drenched in olive oil. I think it was supposed ot have some lobster on it, but it didn't appear to have anything but a bunch of pesto like substance on there. 

Overall my meal ended up being about $100 and for someone that just came from statebird provisions and spent the same amount on an amazing 6-7 course meal and dessert for about the same price, I was MAJORLY MAJORLY disappointed by Bouche and would not recommend that anybody come here. Except maybe for the salmon dish.

I also tried their wine which I felt was more resiny tasting than other red wines (I forgot which one my friend ordered) and the waitress was not very friendly and acted a bit cold and annoyed.

Also their house bread is dry and bland.

Maybe I ordered the wrong dishes? I don't know?
author: Em F.

description: A cute neighbourhood French restaurant. Tried their dinner twice and I'm pretty satisfied. Good selection of wine and food. They use good ingredients. Service is always pleasant and I love the cozy atmosphere especially upstairs - almost feels like Paris. Their Salads is good, the crispy pork belly appetiser was nice.
author: Bomin K.

description:
We loved Bouche - so unique and refreshing!

Cute, cozy, casual bistro atmosphere. Very creative ingredient combinations, sauces, and beautiful plating. Each plate was like a little adventure through a few different focuses and tastes that you could recombine in endless combinations of flavor. 

Bouche also played with temperature and texture really well - things you expected to be hot might be cold (sous vide (?) poached egg, escargot), extremely hot, crunchy mushroom dish. This extends to the wine. I don't know how they do it in such a teeny place, but the red and white wines we had by the glass were all at the perfect temperature; something that is unfortunately not often the case at SF restaurants. The wine pairing suggested by our waiter were so perfect - he nailed all 3 suggestions. The wine list is excellent. 

We had the arugula salad, duck confit croquettes, a delicious prawn pappardelle with lovely bits of ikura and creme sauce, side of wild mushrooms, and the quail special (stuffed w/veal, red wine reduction, escargot salad). Everything was fantastic.
author: Lindsay M.

description: Wow, a slice of authentic, extraordinary-quality cooking. I had the the wild arugula salad to start with a poached egg and goat cheese dressing (the goat cheese dressing and the egg were separated from the greens- a joyful hands-on experience mixing it together on the plate).  Then I had Petrale Sole with croquettes.  Super delicious, small intimate ambience, great find.
author: Brad L.

description: I have been here 3 times now and the food is amazing, every time I have tried something new and its impressive the flavors that I discovered, just try everything. The sizes are a little smaller but you should be fine with an appetizer and entree.
author: Petar Z.

description:
Okay.  I have a theory about Bouche's 4.5 star average on Yelp, and I realize that sharing this theory is totally going to make me sound like a snobby SF foodie, but maybe that's what I am so here goes:  the vast majority of Bouche's glowing reviews are written by people from out of town who are not accustomed to really great food.  I am cringing as I say this, but I think it's true.  And admittedly, if Bouche existed in almost any other city in America, it would be very deserving of it's 4-5 star reviews.  
Unfortunately, Bouche is in San Francisco, and that means it has ALOT of expectations to live up to.  And sadly, these expectations were not met.  The food was fine.  Nothing terrible.  But nothing great either.  If you are hungry and would like a nice meal, this fits the bill.  It's easy walking distance from Union Square so it's very convenient for all the out of towners staying in hotels around there.  But seriously- if you check where people are yelping from, a lot of the glowing reviews are not from locals.  Maybe that means something, maybe it doesn't.  But there it is.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Bouche is a hidden gem. It sits atop the Stockton tunnel right next to the bar Tunnel Top. I almost walked past it because it fits so subtilely on the sidewalk. It's also a pretty small place. Bar and kitchen are on the bottom floor and a small seating area is upstairs with about 6-8 tables for parties between 2-4 people. It's a tight space but I think it's cozy for the atmosphere it's going for.

My party of 3 split the marinated salmon, poached egg, and crème fraîche appetizer and it was amazing. Crème fraîche on the bottom with a basket of fried what I can only describe as super skinny "noodles" and smoked salmon on top. When you break the basket, the poached egg is inside. It was a perfect combination of textures and it was so light in flavors. Great start to the meal. 

I ordered the slow cooked cod, eggplant caviar, tomato tempura, and manila clams dish. My cod was cooked perfectly. I enjoyed the caviar as well - strong olive flavor. The tomato tempura was interesting yet again, another nice combination of textures. I think it was a great plate where every individual element really came together.

My friends had the lamb dish and the pork belly dish and I was able to try a bite of each. Perfectly cooked meat and so well seasoned. 

The service was great as well! I will be coming back for sure, especially for that salmon appetizer.
author: Brittany L.

description:
Awesome!!! Can you say flavor? Lucky me I can walk here in 5 minutes. The menu changes because everything is fresh and delish. They have this cold corn soup that knocks my socks off every time. The wine is great the salmon and cod dishes great.
Cool ambience upstairs and downstairs good music. Authentic like a French cafe on the street. This place is great! Oh it closes late yopeeeeee!
author: Cecilia D.

description: Exquisite French food, incredibly nice and caring (French) staff and charming ambiance for outstanding dinner experiences. We have been going to Bouche for years and keep being amazed by the creativity, quality and authenticity of their menu.
author: V T.

description: We fell in love with this small restaurant. My husband and I dined here Thursday night. We requested a table upstairs and decided to do a sampler dinner by ordering several appetizers. The two of us loved the bacon fougasse--rustic bread with pieces of bacon in it. We also had the pork belly, scallop carpaccio, and 2 other dishes, all of them full of originality and flavor. My husband had the goat cheese tart which came with beet ice cream, it was truly amazing. I almost ate all of it! Awesome value and top notch service for a delightful French bistro fare.
author: Osvaldo R.

description: Conveniently located cozy place with delusions food and friendly staff. Grilled asparagus and Wagyu Top Sirloin highly recommended.
author: Serafima G.

description: Really great service. Good food. Great ambience!!! Excellent night out. Special kudos to our awesome server... Blond haired, blue eyed guy.
author: Nicole W.

description: Yum!!! We were taken here by some friends who have such great recommendations for San Fransisco. Cute two storey little restaurant ... Bar down stairs and small intimate restaurant upstairs. The food was so amazing - the flavours were so well thought of, there was nothing left on our plates. Highly recommended.
author: Josie C.

description: Back to bring my husband. Did not disappoint! The top sirloin was so scrumptious we ordered two!
author: Adriana R.

description: What a gem! Cozy bohemian ambience. Exquisite French cuisine served by well trained staff who know how to maneuver in tight places. We will definitely return when in SF.
author: Harrison L.

description:
Quaint cozy location, friendly service with a touch of authentic French experience. Probably one of the best French restaurants I have been lately. Lamb dish was perfectly cooked with right portion. Must visit when you are not in a hurry and experience relaxed dinner.

Tip - corkage few is $20 bucks, right next door there is a liquor store which has good French wine selection. Pick a cotes du rhone or meritage for 15 bucks, you won't be disappointed.
author: Karthik S.

description:
There are so many reasons I want to give this place 5 stars. This place is a mix of fancy pants French cuisine in a hole in the wall comfy setting (soft lighting, plenty of wood furniture, knick knacks for your eyes to wander over). In sum, this place should get you laid if you are not ugly.

Make a reservation. Our group of 3 got lucky that someone canceled and they were able to seat us. There are two floors with the upstairs area being more quiet and intimiate (has space for about 15 ppl). It can get kind of cramped but that adds to the experience. 

Do yourself a favor and order at least the smoked salmon that is pictured on the front page. It rests on a nest of crispy noodles and there is a poached egg hiding underneath. All of this is swimming in some kind of fancy tartar sauce (i'm sure I offended the chef by calling it that). The mix of complementing flavors made my head spin. Easily the best appetizer I've ever tasted.

The rest of the menu is full of savory flavorful goodness. I don't know what French cuisine is supposed to be like but I want to get more familiar with it as soon as I become a baller.

One appetizer, one entree, one side-dish and two glasses of wine cost us about $80 and was lightly filling. I hope to come back here soon.
author: Sam P.

description: Warm and romantic atmosphere, great food, and friendly staff make this place unforgettable.
author: P F.

description: The restaurant was really adorable and quaint. We enjoyed an amazing bottle of wine but the food did not deliver. They were out of bread which was very disappointing as it was a bacon flavored bread. Three of the four people in my party ordered the halibut, however, the portions varied severely in size between the three. Overall, the food was over priced and under delivered. The beer and wine were delicious, the atmosphere was enjoyable, but the food left our wallets empty and our bellies hungry.
author: Shar B.

description:
One of the best restaurants we've been to in any country.  The sardines and chestnut soup were perfect, highly recommend.  Entrees were not too big or small, good portion and all around fantastic.  Service was solid, noise was just under loud, and basically could not have had a better experience.  

We dined at one of the "better" French restaurants the next night, and it wasn't even close to Bouche and both are "California" inspired.  This should be the top of anyone's list in SF.  And when you see the kitchen, you'll have to say how truly remarkable it is they pulled off the level of food they do.
author: Scott S.

description: Cute little French bistro with very nice staffs.  Love the open kitchen yet no oily/stinky smells~. Will come back again to try the cheese plates.
author: Anna C.

description:
When I travel, I like to search Yelp! For best restaurants near me, and try them out.  So on this trip to San Francisco I found Bouche after dropping off my rental car nearby (who needs a rentL in SF anyway?).

The restaurant itself is very cool.  Small up front bar area with individual street views, and a back/upper room with larger tables.  I chose the bar are
Started with the cheese special - a Laguiole (sp?) - exceptional with the bread and accompaniments it came with.  Nice portion, maybe too much for 1 person, but who's complaining - it's cheese!

Followed with the main course - Sole with beets and squash purée,  with a side of Crab Mashed Potatoes.  WOW!  So good.

I skipped dessert - the food portions were generous enough to not leave me needing dessert.  And that's okay by me.

Overall this is a GREAT place.
author: Jeff Z.

description:
We must have come on an off day as out waiter was incredibly rude. He barely spoke a word to us, and just banged out entrees down on the table, never asked us how the food was. At the end, he just tossed the check on the table and literally did not say ANYTHING. I'm not sure if it was the way we looked or something we did (we were dressed appropriately, and hadn't said anything out of the ordinary), but I was very surprised, especially considering how highly this restaurant is rated. It was so incredibly awkward. When we left (it was still at least a half hour before closing and there were still other clients eating in the restaurant) we saw him sitting at the bar eating, so perhaps he was annoyed with us for interrupting his dinner.

The restaurant itself was cozy and sweet. I especially liked my seat as I could actually see down into the kitchen. I had the spaghetti squash which was okay. The temperature was a little cold. I've never had spaghetti squash before so perhaps I just don't like it. My fiancé had the salmon and admitted it was really very good and cooked perfectly.

However, the waiter made the whole experience so unpleasant we would not recommend this restaurant to anyone and will certainly never be back.
author: Mel V.

description:
We had a lovely date night here last week. Food was excellent! My favorite appetizer was beef tartare. And the pork chop was one of the best I've had! 

The place is tiny and tables are very limited. Reservations are highly recommended!
author: J S.

description:
Food was sooooooo GOOD. 

Salmon with poached egg was ridiculous.  Theres some fried crunchy somethings on there that complete the dish.  Nicely balanced, almost like a breakfast appetizer, but really really good.

Steelhead salmon was also great with the pesto and the cauliflower creme.  Probably the best cooked salmon I've ever had.  Also tried the lamb shoulder that came with this crazy carrot sauce that tasted strange by itself, but when mixed with the lamb the result was delicious.

On top of the great food, I couldn't believe the kitchen.  It was shoulder to shoulder with 4 cooks.  The kitchen was great to see.
author: Eric M.

description:
My honey and I went here on our first date :) 

I am not a big fan of French food, but this place was great. Especially dessert.
author: Mel B.

description:
Bouche - very deserving of five stars. 

Although very small, I believe 16 seats total upstairs, the closeness to others was not a problem as I could never hear the details of our neighbor's conversations. It wasn't loud at all but the hustle of the staff, bustle of the  street and more so, the exciting sounds coming from the kitchen, of which we had a bird's-eye view, seemed to just all merge into an ambient noise. Out table for two was at the stair entry and I thought this would be a problem but it wasn't because once again, I had a great view, this time of watching each of the well prepared dishes make their way up the stairs by one of the two French waiters. 

To be sure, the menu is limited: 8 appetizers, 4 entrees, 3 sides and 4 desserts with a wine list of maybe 70 bottles and 30 by the glass. But if you saw the space the chefs were cooking, you'd understand why. The kitchen space has room for two chefs and no room to squeeze by each other. The entire cooking process in its entirety is crafted in an area no larger than 60 square feet, which includes all equipment and room for the chefs. 

As a side, there are 4 bar seats on the cooking side of the downstairs which may have an up-front view of the chefs but I only noticed those seats on the way out. The view may be obstructed; not sure. There are also 16 other barstool seats downstairs; 12 face the wall under the stairwell and 4 face the view of the street. Again, I didn't notice these seats until leaving but now a crowd of about twenty had formed waiting for seats (half in the cramped entrance and half outside) and the three people sitting in the window had to be tremendously cramped. 

Still, overall, the food and service was great. We loved the chunk of cheese, duck was juicy, tasty and had a great texture and the chicken, rarely ordered in a restaurant by me, was even more juicy and flavorful.

But the star of the night was the crème fraîche with caramel and sea salt. Exquisite. And I don't like sweets. 

The person I was with who is well versed in fine dining said it was the best dessert she has ever had and I have to agree. 

Thank you very much Bouche. San Francisco remains our favorite city in the US.
author: Chris M.

description:
My friend rec'd this place for me to have dinner with my parents while visiting in San Francisco.  It was great - incredible food and the menu is perfect in that it's not too extensive but also not limited.  We ordered a wide variety - pork belly, scallops, eggplant, cod, steak, chickpea fries and risotto in tomatoes.  Of those dishes, I highly recommend the steak entree, the scallop appetizer and the pork belly.  I wasn't a huge fan of the cod, but it was still tasty.

The only reason I'm not giving this place 5 stars is that I arrived after my parents and the waitress told me my parents were sitting at a two person table, but that the adjoining table (to make it a table for four) was not ready yet.  That was perfectly fine, so my boyfriend and I went to drop off our bags at our friends house nearby and asked her if she could tell my parents that we would be right back.  She agreed, but then we later found that she didn't?  That was very confusing as it was her idea to tell them in the first place.  I'm sure she just forgot, but it was very odd.  Besides that, the service was excellent.  

Most important is that they serve the BEST DESSERT I have ever eaten.  Order the Creme Fraiche.  Save room for dessert.  Make room for dessert.  It was amazing.
author: Maegan H.

description: Had a magical evening at Bouche this evening. Everything about the dinner was magnificent. It all started with Mehdi hosting us and Alex serving us. Every request was fulfilled, including cutting up lots of bread so we could only get crust. We sampled most of the starters and absolutely loved the Pork Belly. Foei Gras was delicious as one would expect. The Hanger steak was one of the finest I have ever had. The Americano that I ordered to cap the dinner was equally wonderful. All in all, one of the finest dinner experiences in the city.
author: Ravi S.

description:
I asked my hotel concierge where this gem was located, and he actually wasn't sure.  As if we needed further proof concierges don't always know the best places in town.  

The staff is French, the atmosphere is rustic and charming... I could imagine us being in France.  The suggested wine, a 2010 Domaine Auchere Sancerre Rouge, fit the waitress' explanation to a T.  Very light, not too fruity, and lingers for a long time on the tongue.  What a delightful, almost musical pairing to our dish.  I'm buying a case when I get a chance.  We got a cheese plate to start, which came in a perfect portion size.  Each cheese... mmm mmm delicious.  

My entree was a pork loin with English peas, spring vegetables, and confit back fat consomme.  The waitress explained that the pork loin is slow cooked for 11 hours, and I could tell!!!  Incredibly tender.  And the broth that resulted was intoxicating and fragrant.  Man, that broth tasted good.  I'd have tipped the bowl up and slurped the broth down had I not been dining with 2 classy ladies.  

We finished up with some dessert.  The food was too good not to order more.  I got a berry/fennel salad with shortcake (more out of pure intrigue about the fennel).  It came in a long dish, with several components artfully arranged.  Great, great finish.  Impeccable marriage of flavors.  

Hands down one of the best places I've been to in San Francisco, and certainly gives Le Petit in Branford, CT a run for its money.
author: Jeff J.

description:
Bouche - I AM A FAN.

If you read my review for L'ardoise, you would know that I think that this (along with Parc Central and L'ardoise) is one of the top three French restaurants in the City at this price range.  Let me tell you how to decide amongst the three: if you want safe, go with Parc Central; if you are on a date, go to L'ardoise; and if you are entertaining a "foodie" friend (wth that means these days because half of them are just gluttons with terrible senses of taste), go to Bouche.

Here is why: Out of these three restaurants, and even amongst the higher priced and more well known ones, Bouche really is most avant garde with their dishes and pairings.  The best way I can describe some of their dishes is that they are deconstructed and then reconstructed.  Yes, we've all had food these days where the chefs break down the classic dishes into novel separate ingrediets - but the chefs at Bouche takes it a step further: they kind of put it back together into a dish that resembles the original dish but not really because it was deconstructed...

WTF are you talking about?  Try ordering their White Corn Soup if that is on the menu.  You will know what I am talking about when you get it.  It's poetic!  Try the marinated salmon - is that a cured salmon sandwich?  No, it was deconstructed and then reconstructed!  

My only critique: My guess is that the head chef is one of these revolutionary new chefs from France that is moving away from the Michelin star system...not only because he is willing to try, but because some of his/her dishes does lack a bit of polish (e.g., their lamb can be a bit more polished in the roasting, as both plates I've seen were overcooked).  However, give him another 5 years and I am sure you will see him written about.

Lastly, the staff here are wonderful.  Just absolutely wonderful.

Concluding thought: If you are in a long term relationship or are already married, come here instead of L'ardoise to change up the topic and pace.  You'll love it here.
author: Mark M.

description: My wife and I came up to SF for our 15th anniversary, after spending an amazing day exploring the city we love we decided to get a quick bite. After typing tapas into Yelp we decided upon Bouche. They were warm and welcoming and the service and food was wonderful. My favorite was the pork belly but everything was great including the skirt steak with potato au gratin. Thank you for giving another wonderful memory on a special day.
author: Mark L.

description: Tried this place last week with some colleagues and really liked it a lot. As other reviewers have indicated, it's a charming little spot - candlelit at night - that feels both comfortable and accessible. Very attentive (but not overweening) service, a nice small menu offering some really delicious French fare. The yellowtail carpaccio was delicious and the roasted chicken entree was tasty and very nicely prepared. Great wine list, too. So glad to have stumbled across this little gem.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
The service was amazing. 
The location is amazing. 
The ambiance is amazing. 
But the food was horrible. I ordered the pork ribs and belly. The belly was beyond edible because it was SO salty. Ribs are supposed to be tender and just melt in your mouth. The cut of meat I received was nothing but fat. There were maybe 2 bites that were not AS grisly. My boyfriend ordered a side of the grilled tomatos and pickled cucumber. Neither of us took more than a bite of this. It was served not hot - not cold, but warm (?maybe it's supposed to be like this?), and the tomatos looked as if they were BOILED instead of grilled. They were very mushy. The pickled cucumber didn't really compliment the tomatos either. But that might be just my personal taste. 
Other than the food, we would have had a great experience!
author: E L.

description:
this place just cant stop, wont stop with the level of amazingness-- its late and im leaving burritt room and stumble into bouche, starved, grab a seat at the counter w/my gal pal and have a 4 course meal past midnight... Um dream come true? 

This restaurant is soo charming, love the open kitchen, awesome service and staff, super delicious food - not in the typical French modern portion size either. And you should no doubt save (or make) room for dessert!! 

I've sent maybe 4+ different groups of people here this past year (including a couple real Frenchies) and they all loved it - like they actually thought it was the best restaurant recommendation they got. 

It's an easy favorite. Grab a seat at the bar of your solo or make a reso to be seated in the tiny seating area upstairs.
author: Shanna N.

description: Took a late flight into the city and was at a loss for where to eat at 12:30 am. Then, we stumbled across this hidden gem. The atmosphere is quaint- be prepared to sit in tight quarters with strangers- however it's very fitting and a welcoming situation, given the atmosphere. You know when you hear most of the customers speaking French to one another, it's going to be good stuff. The menu is brief, but every single item is made so carefully and with love. We ordered a seafood and meat dish, and both items were very delicate and had rich flavor. The creme fraiche dessert was out of this world!
author: Kristina N.

description:
Hidden gem of a place at the Top of the Tunnel. Totally unexpected in the tourist haven that is Union Square. That's what makes dining here such a delightful experience. Straying from my usual Yelp reviews, I'll start with the atmosphere bc that's what I love most about this place.

Atmosphere: It's a dim, cozy, intimate place. Sit at the bar to see all the action up close and personal. The kitchen is tiny tiny, so its really quite impressive. For a more romantic experience, sit upstairs near the window. You'll feel like you're dining in a small French bistro in Provence. 

Food: OK so it's not the best French food we've ever had, but it's still pretty good. The menu is small and manageable, which already a plus. So this is what we ate - 
-Green garlic soup - If you love garlic and creamy soups, this is your soup. Charred onions and garlicky croutons provide a nice crunch.
-Halibut with butter beans - Light and flakey fish with hearty white beans. A little too much citrus flavor for my taste but still tasty. 
-Asparagus pasta - Pasta was al dente, asparagus puree was yummy. Actual asparagus spears were overcooked though. 
-Duck confit - Nice and salty but the meat was a bit on the dry side. I'm used to fall off the bone juicy duck meat from duck confits.
-Sardines - Although the herby, vinegary, citrusy flavor was all there, I don't think I'm enough of a sardine connoisseur to appreciate the semi-raw almost rubbery texture of this particular dish. 
-Chickpea fries - Not recommended. Very dry, even with the BBQ sauce. Wait, BBQ sauce in a French restaurant? Exactly ;)

Service: Super friendly French hosts who make you feel like a regular right when step your foot in the door.

Pronunciation: Restaurant is pronounced "Booosh", like "Bush", the street it is on. ;)
author: Connie C.

description:
My nieces loved the "hot guys" with French accents, I loved the wine list and the desert.  Shows you how much 30 years of life will do to a person.  

Seriously good seasonal food.  Perfectly portioned and well though out.  Excellent presentation and great ambience. Intimate and rustic a perfect match to some wonderful french food.   The cheese plate is excellent with a perfect selection indulging a  bold stinky blue-  I love all manor of blue , the stinkier the better.  

Simple ingredients that let the  food truly speaks for itself. You could pay three times as much for food like this in other places.  This restaurant  is certainly worth a visit.  I will go out on a limb here and say this is among the best food I have had in San Fran.
author: Denise S.

description: OMG. The food is amazing.  Everything was so flavorful yet lite with amazing flavor.  I had the scallops and shrimp. I would show you with a picture but I ate it as fast as it came.  Champagne was excellent   Service good with a European flare.  Makes me want to go back to France.   Great price for this quality food.  I will be back for sure
author: Steve N.

description: I was taken here for lunch and it was a home run. Very quiet and intimate. We felt like our table was alone in a sea of nice music and aromatic European cooking. Lover the decor and the service was awesome
author: Nam P.

description:
Service 4 Stars
Ambiance 3 stars
Food 3 stars
Price 2.5 stars

Overall it was ok but not a memorable experience.  If you love french food you should try it for yourself and then you decide.
author: Din D.

description: Usually wouldn't give a restaurant 4 stars if the food is only good, versus great/mind blowing however the gorgeous decor and atmosphere of Bouche will have me back in no-time. Service was pretty decent with an interesting and fun wine/by the glass menu. Next time I'll likely eat at the bar and have a small bite + drink just so I can sit in that beautiful space again.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Quaint, charming, perfection. Love the ambiance, food and wine were delectable.
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
I ended with at Bouche the other night with a family friend/her friend and I must say, this place was quite a pleasant surprise for a cold, rainy night!

The ambiance is homey and comforting.  You can sit downstairs on stools (which is a bit problematic if you have more than 3 people in your group) or upstairs where there is additional seating.  The owner of the restaurant was our server-- although we were a difficult crowd to please, he brought us several wine tastings and laughed out our jokes.  Also, he's adorable ;)

We ordered a variety of dishes but I'll just highlight what stood out the most:
-Sardines, grapefruit, mint and marinated vegetables- an intricate assortment of flavors with delicious croutons.
-Marinated salmon, poached egg and creme fraiche- these 3 ingredients delightfully came together.

Overall, a wonderful experience with good company.

And PS, the kitchen is open till 1AM!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Bon, non et fantastique.

Went with friends for a Bastille Day celebration, expecting a lil fluff and fuss, and there wasn't any.  Pluses:  ample bar for micro bistro and very good service.  Minuses:  really hot upstairs seating and also a bit cramped, small menu albeit well rounded, very small portions and the food was just too salty from salade to dessert (they are into adding salt into everything).

I might go back, but with a plethora of great French restaurants in the area, I probably won't.

~Ms. Ali
author: A W.

description: A great surprise.  Fun staff. Small but thoughtful menu.  Very enjoyable and tasty food and fun casual atmosphere.  I would go back anytime and that is quite a complement for a city with so many great places to eat.
author: Peter E.

description: Second visit to Bouche last night hoping against hope it was as good as I remembered. It was! The food is all so delicately and intricately flavored. The chef is a genius. Go. You won't be disappointed.
author: Michelle C.

description:
This is what French Bistros should be like. 

The decor is adorable.

The food was tasty.

The wine was so good.

We were on time for our rez and waited an hour.  We didn't care though, the owner brought us complimentary champagne and we just hung out and chatted.

When we finally got seated it was a breeze.   

Worth repeat visits.
author: Mister G.

description: This restaurant is a hidden gem! Lovely interior is cool and cozy with an upstairs seating area. Service is so nice, our server Gael was awesome! Last but not least the food was to die for, I had the steak, which was cooked to perfection, very tender and melts in my mouth. Definitely recommend this place and will come back here the next time I'm in NorCal!
author: kat k.

description:
Overall a great food experience...

We sat downstairs by the counter - So it felt a little more informal.

The waitress was great help with recommendations - but be sure to include the pork Belly.
author: Johan H.

description:
My friend and I were looking for a place to eat late at night.  Thankfully a waiter from a nearby restaurant, with it's kitchen closed for the evening, pointed us to Bouche.  As soon as we walked in we knew we were someplace special because two guys sitting at the bar had just been served the marinated salmon on a nest of something crispy, a poached egg in it, and creme fraiche around the base.  We were impressed and so were the guys because they were taking a picture of the dish.  My friend and I ordered this salmon dish, a beet and duck confit salad, a sardine salad, and a lamb dish.  Every bite was perfection!  We kept staring at our plates and at each other like "Oh my god this is ammmaaazing"!  
   Go here now before everyone finds out about it and you can't be seated.  

I live in Seattle, but must return to San Francisco just for this restaurant!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
From my hands to the mouth. 

This great little French eatery is in such an unexpected place; at the top of the tunnel. It was so much fun finding it; you sort of feel like you are on the 'back roads' of the city, and yet it is right in the midst of all of the action. 

Bouche could never be called just a tapas bar, because it's food is substantial (no need for hoarding); however, it's menu is designed with a French style, so the dishes are intended to be shared. If you were walking by it and blinked, you'd miss it as it is very small in terms of space, even though it is a two-story. However, whatever it lacks in sheer size, it makes up for it in taste. 


We tried a number of different dishes (calamari, duck confit and beet salad, lamb, halibut, etc). All were memorable and delicious, but simple in the right ways. And the wine list had some great French selections at very affordable prices. 

The staff, a group of French guys of course, was so much fun, and very accommodating. We actually had to rush out for the theatre (ACT - 'scorched'), and the team there was fast and helpful; they didn't take it personally. 

It's probably worth noting that Bouche is open until 1 am. It's also probably worth noting that we'll definitely be going back.
author: Dahvie J.

description:
It was difficult to locate because of the tiny sign and the door.

However, the ambience inside was just luxurious and amazing. The waiters were super friendly. I had a monkfish which was $22. It was delicious. It was cooked to the perfect texture. My three other friends ordered pork belly. They all loved it. I am definitely going back.
author: Hee Jung R.

description:
Food: Savory (4), Dessert (ZERO!!!)
Ambiance: 3
Service: 2

Bouche is a fairly new addition to the SF restaurant scene, will most likely become a popular place. Ended up at Bouche after searching for a late dinner spot  walking distance from my friend's Nob Hill apartment.  Everything closes so early in SF so bonus points for a kitchen open so late. Full menu at the bar and drinks are a reasonable price.

Service was borderline nonexistent.  There was 1 waitress for the whole upstairs (either 7 or 8 tables). Only half the tables were occupied yet our waitress rarely checked up on us and was impossible to flag down.  We went through the entire bottle of water at our table without it ever once being refilled nor poured into our glasses. Bottle wasn't refilled until she took the dessert orders. Not acceptable.

My buddy and I started with 3 appetizers: Chilled Summer Squash Soup with Ricotta, Arugula Pasta with Asparagus and Morels, and Beef Carpaccio.  Flavors were complex so kept the plates interesting. We enjoyed the starters slightly more than the entrees.  For entrees, I ordered Pork Loin, English Peas, Spring Vegetables and Confit Back Fat Consomme and he ordered Lamb Shoulder, Onion and Almond Marmalade, Carrot and Coriander Puree. I preferred the lamb.

Now for the bad. Avoid both the Creme Fraiche Custard and the Tart of the Day: Lime and Nectarine Tart!  Trust me.  I'm normally very forgiving even with subpar desserts since I have such an insane sweet tooth, but dessert here was horrifying. Maybe it was overwhelmingly terrifying because it came so unexpected in juxtaposition with the great savory dishes but wow, the Creme Fraiche Custard tasted more like a flavorless pot de creme of...nothing. The Lime and Nectarine Tart was a disaster. Friend commented that nectarines tasted like canned fruit (ew) and the excuse for a tart crust was reminiscent of paper-thin cardboard. These "desserts" make Safeway's frozen desserts aisle taste like Johnny Iuzzini's creations at Jean George.

Solid California-French fare (especially for the location and price point), variety on the menu, and great late hours, but skip this place if you're looking for attentive service and dessert that's even remotely edible.
author: Shelley W.

description: This restaurant was recommended to us by staff at the Westin St. Frances. We arrived at 9:30 at night and were welcomed with a smile. We ordered the Hanger Steak and it was DELICIOUS!!! Would definitely go back again.
author: Bela S.

description: This place was amazing. We had the crepinette, cheese special, steak, and cod- all were absolutely delicious. The real winner was the dessert... Both the goat cheese cheesecake and creme fraiche custard were probably the best dessert dishes I've had at a restaurant, especially the former. A little tight inside, but coming from the northeast we didn't mind at all. Recommend getting reservations unless you come early... It was packed even on a Tuesday night by 7:30/8. Definitely must-go for locals and tourists alike!
author: Iris K.

description:
I really liked this restaurant. I am downgrading it just a little because the menu was somewhat limited. We only could choose between veal, steelhead trout, risotto, and pork. Since we don't like veal or pork and the risotto was kind of blah, it would have been really nice to have beef or some other more creative seafood dishes.

The entrees were just a little bit disappointing. The steelhead was somehow a bit bland and the sides were okay but not at the level of the appetizers. The risotto was frankly, just above average but not great.

The wines were absolutely terrific - all French of course. In particular, we had the Couly-Duteil chinon blanc which was totally gorgeous. The vaucluse was dry but very impressive too.

The mackerel appetizer was very good. We had a leek soup which was also very good but it was extremely creamy, so be aware if you don't like too much thick cream. The octopus was great. The wild mushrooms were outstanding and perhaps I would call them the best feature of the whole meal. The flavor of those muchrooms was unforgettable.

For several appetizers, two entrees, and wine, we spent $116 for two people.

The atmosphere is very cozy and small and personal. They keep it very dim so that you cannot read the menu but it is romantic. The "true French feel" is all there. I would give this place 4.5 because of the experience and very polite service but as the place is kind of small and limited in their menu items, we didn't enjoy the choices as much as we would have elsewhere with a more varied selection.
author: p v.

description: A very cute 2-level bistro. We ordered the scallop carpaccio, crispy pork belly, and the braised pork shoulder. The scallop carpaccio was fishy and I couldn't eat it, the crispy pork belly was alright - it seems they all taste the same to me - fatty! lol The braised pork shoulder was the winner of the night. :) Our server was very friendly and accommodating when I mistakenly ordered the wrong wine and he brought me the right one. :)
author: Win S.

description: Stayed at a hotel nearby. The restaurant was small and rustic. I liked the food and service was decent.
author: Ann L.

description:
Extraordinary.

This is a tiny, two-level postage stamp of a restaurant where the young staff create and craft innovative, well-composed, beautifully presented contemporary French food.  If you make reservations, you can be seated at the tables upstairs. If you walk in, you can set at the bar-style seats on the first level.  The best of these, in my opinion, are the seats that give you a view of the cooking. 

The menu is small, fresh and complemented by carefully chosen wines and beers. Both the servers and the kitchen staff know their food and can give you great guidance. I had a raw scallop appetizer that was like a taste of the sea, pretty to look at, garnished with edible flowers, and absolutely delicious. My duck was equally good.  You will have an excellent meal.
author: Fida C.

description:
BOUCHE. It is a small piece of heaven! The place is extremely tiny, so reservations are a must! I found this little gem after spending hours on yelp, trying to find a perfect little French place to take my fiance to for his birthday back in October.

We were seated almost immediately upstairs facing the window that leads outside. It was a hot Indian summer day so it was perfect with the intimate atmosphere and dimmed lights. The service was very attentive and helpful and we ended up choosing our entrees and appetizers as well as a bottle of wine pretty quickly. I would most definitely recommend getting the following:

- Marinated Salmon, Poached Egg And Creme Fraiche: it was heavenly! I've been to many French restaurants in the Bay Area, but this dish just blew me away!
- Octopus w/ Summer Squash Salad, Dandelion Salsa Verde & Sesame Crumbs: very nice appetizer and very tasty
- Pork Belly: my fiance said that he loved it, so I'll take his word for it

The desserts were not too memorable, but still delicious. Love this place! Already recommended it to few friends and definitely will come back here again.
author: Karina A.

description:
Came here last night with my girlfriend and 2 of our friends... 

Basically between 4 people you can try the entire menu. 

Not a single dish was memorable enough to say "WOW I want to come back to get this again!"

The veal was undercooked and very chewy. Not at all a good dish. Try the veal at Kokkari (now thats a Daaamn WOW!)

The pasta prawn sea urchin was gritty (clean the clams!) and the prawn was more decorative as it was almost an empty shell, the sea urchin was good and creamy. 

The steelhead was under seasoned and lacked flavor.

The chick peas fries were like deep fried and clumped up hummus... not good.

The boar ravioli was actually decent in comparison to everything else... but not worthy of coming back to have again.

Would not come back, expected more flavor and good food... got completely the opposite. 

Sure it's a nice ambiance and it's small and quaint, but this is a restaurant and I come for the FOOD!
author: Ilya Movshovich M.

description:
WOW! This is one of the cooolest little special hidden spots in SF!  The marinated smoked salmon on a poached egg with creme fraiche was like magic to my taste buds. RIDICULOUS awesome!!!
The other food was pretty good tooo...all interesting and uniquely delicious. Chickpea fries were interesting and tasty. Artichoke rice was VERY rich, but good in small bites.
We sat upstairs on a little loft and had amazing friendly service with excellent wine and food.  
Can't wait to make my way back to SF and come back here!
author: Emi G.

description: A quaint place with friendly staff and absolutely delicious food and wines. The pork belly appetizer was bomb delicious and so were pork shoulder and creme custard with caramel sauce!
author: Anji S.

description: I've never done review on Yelp before but the French waiter in bad shirt was very rude and made me do it.
author: Paul L.

description:
I really love this place.  I appreciate everything about it.  It's pushy host to the small plates, it's amazing, but the food takes the cake. 

I had the chicken dish, and I also tried the lamb shoulder.  The flavors where amazing, the white wine sauce and tarragon potatoes, and the tender lamb, and not too heavy. The calamari appetizer was perfect, just the right amount of citrus and I died when I tried the Crem Fraiche desert, so simple, done so right with the small details going a long way, with the added salt on top yum, I'm drooling right now.

Yes plates are on the smaller side but I would expect that for a french restaurant.  The wine list is great and the servers at super attentive and are all French, hehe.

The ambiance just does me in, I love how that the kitchen is right behind the small bar and the architecture details are just amazing.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who appreciates an authentic french experience in a little hidden gem of a place in SF.
author: Diana D.

description:
I am a little torn between 3 stars and 4. I remember commenting on good food and satisfaction with the restaurant as a whole when we were leaving, but now I can't seem to retain a single memorable dish in my head.  It may be that, despite our reservation, we seemed to have waited eons before our table was ready. So by then, I was so hungry and disoriented I couldn't tell what I was eating anymore. I was just stuffying myself and making "mmm" sound basically. 

The plates can be a little too chaotic for me.  The burrata salad and the octopus salads had very different components and yet their taste are similar, with a lot of tang.  The light is dim which is romantic, but it also meant that I couldn't tell what I was eating.  I wished those plates were a little simpler.

The highlight is the chilled corn soup. Rich and smooth. Beautiful texture and taste. 

My main dish, the often mentioned marinated salmon, tasted a lot like eggs benedicte. In a strange way, it was disappointing because I was not physically prepared to have "brunch" at this late hour.  And marinated salmon tasted no different from lox in my mouth. 

Similarly, the sardines which were raved in some professional review (can't remember which one), were a bit chewy and fishy. I  guess i had high expectations. 

On the other hand, the space is full of ambiance. There is no better way to enjoy summer in SF (or pretend there is a summer) then to sit on a small lofty space next to windows wide open. The lights are dim, street noises trickle in but not annoying.
author: Candice B.

description:
Great smaller, intimate place. I reserved ahead of time and we had a table upstairs, very nice!  Tables are quite close to each others, not the place to discuss your next startup idea ;-) this certainly adds to the French bistro experience.
The food was excellent, the aspargus starter awsome and the steak cooked to perfection.
author: JC R.

description: Delicious food and really great wine. Easy to book, but just the tiniest bit on the pricy side, so four stars.
author: Tim H.

description:
I waited 3 long months to find something really special in the SF dining scene. True, maybe I just wasn't looking hard enough. Regardless, the wait is over, and I'm happy to say that Bouche is my new favorite restaurant in Nob Hill and a strong contender for best in SF.

The space is about as intimate as it comes: ~10 seats downstairs around a tiny bar, and 8 tables upstairs. That's it.  The entire 3-man kitchen and the chefs making their frenchy-california magic are in full view. The owners and wait staff are all extremely French (which is to say, from France) which probably explains the excellent wine recommendations.

As for the food, the salmon app is wonderful: set atop a poached egg, super-thin crispy potatoes and creme fraiche, its as pretty to look at as to eat. We also loved our entrees: pork belly, monkfish and lamb shoulder. But its the chestnut soup which will likely haunt my dreams for years to come. If it were socially acceptable to lick a bowl in public I would have. Probably should have anyway. Will next time for sure.

It'd be hard to go wrong here.
author: Alex H.

description: The food here was amazing!! Don't believe the reviews that say otherwise. It is a quaint place to eat and I can't wait to go back!
author: Julia E.

description: Fantastic neighborhood gem.one of my absolute  favorites in this city. Authentic, farm to market french without the pretense.  Excellent service for a.very fair.price.  Do yourself a favor and find this.place.  make a reservatuon, it is tiny!
author: Tim S.

description: Delicious food, clever plating, and good music. We went in on a saturday night without a reservation and got space at the counter. The servers (with legit french accents) were knowledgable and give it that personal touch. I want a copy of the soundtrack.
author: Rob R.

description: So glad we came here.  Thank you Yelp community for the recommendation. Atmosphere is intimate and welcoming.  Menu selection is small, but as waiter said, they have a small kitchen and have focused on preparing a few things very well.  He was right.  Between the 4 of us we sampled much of the menu and everything was truly delicious.  Waiter was very helpful with wine selection after we confessed we knew nothing about French wines.  Save room for yummy desert.   All in all a great place for a lovely evening.
author: Rhonda f.

description:
I enjoyed my dining experience here, but was not blown away. And here is why: The service was slow on a friday night. I am all for a leisurely meal, but not for feeling ignored. Second, while the food was delicious, it was not as good as other french restaurants I have been to in the city. I ordered the marinated mackerel to start and had the steelhead as my main. Both were solid but neither were incredible.  

What I loved about the restaurant was the intimate ambiance and the great the wine selection. I guess I will have to come back sometime and give the restaurant another chance to blow me away.
author: Christy D.

description:
Warm, cozy, tasty, authentic. This is what I think of when I think of our dinner date at Bouche.

The setting is tiny and very crowded. 3 cooks stand side by side right behind the bartender and produce delicious-smelling concoctions. All seats are taken, and any would-be spare room is filled by people with a glass in hand, waiting for a seat. The upstairs (where I assume all reserved tables are) is dimly lit and people hunch over their delicious plates. The staff speak french with one another and occasionally with the diners.

I would definitely order again the chestnut soup (perfect for a cold wintery day, and topped in bacon foam - need I say more?) and the salmon with creme fraiche! Divine bites. My B said the lamb was fantastic!

Minor setbacks included a 20-minute wait (even with a reservation), wine pairings were simply the most expensive glasses of wine on the menu (which felt like a bit of a cheap shot), and the fact that one side we ordered never came..

However all in, this is a delicious, cozy experience - and we definitely hope to return on a less-crowded night.
author: Helen D.

description:
Cute two-storey tiny date place where the menu won't outshine your date. Small, easy to navigate menu. Straightforward satisfying food that people won't go gaga for, so it won't interfere with your conversation.

Note to restaurant: agreed with other reviewers that your scallops appetizer is extremely fishy and inedible. I had it the week of 1/31. I did really enjoy the salt cod brandade a lot, though. Thank you for a great evening.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Cute, intimate, very European, romantic.

Recommend - panisse, lamb, pork loin, roasted mushroom. I didn't try the salmon since I hate salmon, but my dinner companion tells me it was delicious. Their halibut was meh. Not as good as the other dishes we tried.

Haven't tried the desserts here but they sound so heavenly!

The servers all have an awesome French accent. Definitely date night worthy.

Make sure to get reservations, as the restaurant is really small.
author: Mary M.

description:
from the start to the end, everything was well done.

The service is good- not pushy, honest, very attentive but not annoying at all.

Food- we tried octopus salad, true cod and pork belly and shoulders.
Maybe they could've added more octopus (there was a lot of cucumber)
but everything tasted something out of this world good.

Definitely looking forward to the next visit.
author: Shine W.

description:
What an incredible, intimate dining experience. The dining tables are upstairs, overlooking the kitchen, and there is room for probably 20 seats total. With the good acoustics, cozy feel, and romantic lighting, it is has the perfect atmosphere for a date. 

Our food was great too. Our table shared the Fougasse as an appetizer. I had to Google the word-- it is just French for Foccacia bread. The assortment included bacon bread, olive bread, and walnut bread. 

I had the creamy risotto rice topped with crispy baked artichoke. It was perfect. Every dish that came out was plated artistically. 


Dessert-- The chef worked with the birthday girl's BF to arrange a special unique dessert for our table. It was a mixture of homemade ice creams, a chocolate torte, and quince. What a lovely touch. 

To top it off, we had a very helpful French waiter (haha its an oxymoron, right?) who guided us through wine selection and made the evening very enjoyable. 

Note: No reservations accepted.
author: Bailey M.

description:
stumbled on a hidden gem near nob hill 

had some time to spare before going to a show at the masonic. We hit a few closer spots on Bush St., but these places were so packed pretty early into the evening. 

One block over we stepped in to Bouche. The front area also appeared to be busy, but we were greeted right away by a woman at the bar, then a gentleman said he would take us when we inquired for a table for two. We were seated upstairs in a cottage-loft like dining room with an intimate table and charming ambiance. It felt like we were exactly where we should be. 

We appreciated the attentive service, wine suggestion, and quality of entrees. Working within such a small space, it seems to work for the team and looks like they have great comradery.
author: Sarah J.

description:
This is a very quaint little place and a good atmosphere for a date. They have less then ten tables upstairs with some counter top seating downstairs.

We ordered the Chestnut Soup, Squash Cannelloni, Roasted Berkshire Pork Belly, & Lamb Shoulder.

The chestnut soup packed a lot of flavor; It definitely maintained the nuttiness, yet had a creamy and smoothed texture. The squash cannelloni was very....weird. The textures didn't work for me and the flavors were a bit confusing (unfortunately we didn't even finish half the plate). The pork was really good as expected, but I can't help but feel guilty after eating it. Now the lamb dish was delicious; the meat was tender and worked well with the marmalade. The carrot puree was a bit weird, but since it was presented on its own it didn't interfere with my lamb.

Overall thoughts : When I walked in, I wasn't expecting this style of food. I was impressed (with exception to the cannelloni) and love the intimate setting. Definitely a good place for a date.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
My friend took me to Bouche last night for my birthday dinner.  Wow!  What a wonderful spot.  The service was terrific.  All of the staff were kind and inviting.
I had the mizuna salad to start, the seared veal blade, and the mushroom medley side and all were absolutely delicious.  
This restaurant is tiny and very romantic.  Next time I will bring a date.  
The Sutter Stockton garage is just down the street; very convenient for parking.  We arrived after 6pm and I was lucky to get a metered spot right in front of the restaurant.
author: Ellen F.

description: This was a very sub-par experience. The service was very slow. The chickpea fries were quite greasy. The albacore tartar was too fishy. The entrees were slightly better, but still not what one would expect from a highly rated French restaurant. The desert was the only positive dinning aspect. I also left hungry and had to have a second dinner.
author: O B.

description:
Delicious!  It was a perfect, small bistro.  Be aware that the salmon is very sweet and the taste nearly overwhelming (lots of creme fraiche).  But this was small and perfect.  

I loved the reasonably priced wine list.  If we can have a bottle under $60, that's a total win. The food was cheap for the city, with apps in the $10 and main's under $20, this was a great find.  The food was above average for french and I'd definitely go back.

Make sure you have a reservation and enjoy.
author: Jared H.

description:
I love everything about this place - -the intimate setting, the creative menu and the warm and personable staff! It felt like we were eating with family in a cozy, home!  Great for a romantic date or a small group. The staff was attentive and they made fabulous recommendations!  Their desserts are to die for, too! 5 stars! 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Brittany S.

description:
I checked out this new restaurant located in the old Bar Crudo space on Friday night.  Some of the highlights included:

Fougasse, Brown Butter Roasted Carrots, Chestnut Soup & Pan Seared Bass.

The Chef used to work at Coi, Alain Ducasse and Joel Robouchon.   That experience really shows in some of the unique things he's done with the menu.
author: Fred X.

description:
Wow, almost.  Very good food in this price range - well constructed dishes cooked perfectly.  An interesting variety of tastes in each menu item that work together to be something better than the individual parts.  Exactly the quality of food I expect at this price range.  Really a nice surprise since I'd almost given up on mid-price SF.  

Great atmosphere.  Feels like a hidden gem.  Space was cozy and a little cramped, but not too loud.  Good for a date, but not fancy by any means.

Waitress seemed a bit frazzled.  She was unnecessarily rude by mistake once, forgot a dessert, and brought me the wrong wine when I asked for a second glass.  But at least she wasn't constantly trying to be "engaging," which was nice.  And they were slammed, so I'll give her a break.

Dessert is not worth it.  The mousse in particular seemed like canned pudding.  The other was good, but not up to par with the rest of the meal.
author: Brian L.

description:
We were looking for nightcap close to our hotel and were rejected several times. Who knew so many places closed so early! Somebody suggested that we try Bouche and believe it or not, they were not closing at 11:00!!!!!

The guy that greeted us at the door was really nice when we said all we wanted was a bottle of wine and seated us upstairs anyway. Of course, that was where the fun started because at the next table, some d-bag had his chair slid way out and my GF could not get into her seat. Sensing our discomfort and having tried unsuccessfully to get the offending d-bag to move, we moved downstairs and enjoyed our bottle, along with some good banter.

The best part of sitting by the door was the people watching, and the wine was tasty. And hearing the d-bag say something obnoxious about the place to his date as they were leaving was pretty funny. I thought someone was going to smack him upside his gourd. And it would have been deserved. 

Oh ya, Bouche good!
author: James C.

description:
It would truly be a crime for me not to write a review for this magnificent restaurant.

I organized a birthday dinner here for my girlfriend and a handful of her close friends just a few days ago. While it was a bit stressful at first jumping in with no reservations, as long as you give the restaurant a call earlier the day of they'll do whatever they can to accommodate your party. I arrived early and was greeted by the restaurant's owner and a few members of the waiting staff - all French and all super friendly. They helped store my things and even helped me devise an elaborate dessert plate for the birthday girl (candle included!). Early on it became very clear to me that customers come first at Bouche.

Walking in, you will see a narrow hallway with the open kitchen to your left and a stairwell on the right. There are dining tables on the first floor, but I highly recommend requesting seats on the second as you have a fantastic view of both the kitchen below and Bush Street just outside. The place sports dim lighting, plays soft music in the background, and caters to intimate dinners. Seriously, fantastic ambiance top to bottom.

The food speaks for itself at Bouche (as it should at all restaurants). Everything from presentation to taste was top-notch. Upon the main courses' arrival, the table conversation went from lively to "mmmm" and "ooooo" as we each bit into our respective dishes. I personally went with the lamb shoulder and nearly died of happiness after taking my first bite into the incredibly tender, juicy mouthful. Before I knew it, I was finished and sad. Thankfully, dessert followed, of which none was too sweet. Overall, I was pleasantly surprised with the culinary experience, as I had no expectations coming in.

In short, this restaurant has it all. Do not flake on an opportunity to eat here - you will regret it.
author: Jonathan T.

description: The food was tasty enough, good presentation, and very cozy. However, the mood didn't feel very comfortable. The waiters were friendly but not particularly warm. We also made a reservation for 9pm and unfortunately we had to wait an extra 15 minutes for the table to free up.
author: Justin F.

description: I loved this place!  The fool is delicious, the presentation is fantastic.  Very cozy atmosphere. It gets crowded a bit, but I am not complaining, since everyone wants to get a taste of an amazing meal!
author: Julie K.

description: Hand Cut Beef Tenderloin Tartar was so good.
author: Vien C.

description: Fantastic! So charming and intimate and delicious. Salmon was cooked perfectly and the creme fraiche was amazing.
author: Leslie W.

description: Delicious food and great service, one of the best French restaurant in the City!
author: C T.

description:
So, the thing that struck me when I first entered Bouche was an odor. I have a strong sniffer and I notice smells. It wasn't food..it was almost sewer-esque. Honestly, I almost walked out but then we were greeted in such a nice manner and there were 2 bar stools available where we could watch the chefs work. So, I stayed. And, the smell didn't bother me after a few minutes. 

The restaurant has a quirky feel to it. The staff was very friendly and attentive. We ordered the cheese plate which resembled a Georgia O'Keefe painting with all the bright colors and textures. It came with 3 different cheeses, greens, quince puree, grapes and all sorts of other things. It was both beautiful and delicious. The cheese portions were generous. 

For entrees, BF had the bass and I opted for calamari with mushrooms. Both dishes were delicious. The calamari was spicy and had great texture. I feel like the dish had more mushrooms than calamari tho and that kinda disappointed me. The calamari was little tiny pieces. BF enjoyed his giant portion of fish with a delicious lemony white bean puree accompanied by whole beans making for a nice texture. 

Overall, it was a good experience. The food was well prepared. It was great to watch the 4 chefs work hand in hand in the tiny kitchen. They had some nice beer and wine selections. Not an extensive selection but nicely varied.
author: Theresa H.

description: I brought a friend here for their birthday and had an amazing time. Delicious food, good wine, and super pleasant staff!
author: Dustin D.

description:
I was a bit let down with the overall experience here. Six of us came in around 11p.m. last Thursday. We ordered 4 starters, 4 main courses and 3 sides. Of all the dishes, we all agreed the polenta w/comte and chestnut soup was delicious, the lamb good and everything else just okay. The Panisse were burnt, giving them an acrid flavor. The sardine and grapefruit appetizer seemed disjointed, and the potato salad was clever yet didn't overly impress. Our server seemed like he was just there to collect money from us, as he didn't engage in conversation or know much about any of the dishes. Our drinks also took a while to arrive. 

On the flip side I do like the intimate setting on Bush street, and it's great to watch the cooks do their thing in the tiny kitchen. I'd return for the chestnut soup, and hopefully some of the dishes taste as good as they sound next time!
author: Anthony R.

description: The ambiance was great.   The wait staff gave good recommendations.    The only complaint we had the food was not hot.... It was warm.
author: Seth T.

description:
french place.  open real late.  menu has all the great sounding ingredients.  turned out standard.  scallop app was actually a bit salty.  
Mix Squash Soup, Goat Cheese and Chive Cream, Bacon Croutons -- this was nice.
Wild Greens, Caramelized Pear, Roquefort, Walnut and Endive Vinaigrette, Pepper Crust Bacon And Pickled Poached Egg -- all those extra little ingredients didn't hold up to the wild greens much.
Tomahawk Pork Chop, Butter Beans, Walnut and Quince Marmalade Grape and Cognac Sauce, definitely sweet edge to the butter beans with the grapes mixed in.
overall, not enough pull or satisfaction to draw a return visit.
author: Rob C.

description:
Had a seafood starter trio, all of which were excellent.  An octopus and Buddha Hand cold starter was generous and with all the freshness that both principal ingredients should have.  Crunchy baby octopus and thinly sliced citrus were perfect together.  Marinated mackerel and beet salad  with a heavenly light goat cheese mousse were excellent together.  The pine nuts were either too few or just not flavorful enough to add anything to this dish except crunch.  The final was a house smoked salmon served as a rosette on a poached egg with a creme fraiche.  It all melted together in your mouth as a delicious harmony of yolk, cream, and fish smokiness.

The restaurant is VERY small and people are VERY noisy.  It is somewhat difficult to have a real conversation, and any kind of intimacy.  But perhaps that is not what you might come to this restaurant for?
author: Shelly D.

description:
We had a wonderful meal here and we were seated at the bar right where you walk in, which is proof that good food and a wonderful restaurant can really shine through even when the seating isn't exactly what you want. We weren't sure on wine so when we ordered one that we didn't like, our waitress let us try a few more till we found a bottle we liked. She did not make us feel at all like we were putting her out by opening three different bottles of wine, she was very helpful and we got a great one! 

We started our meal with the chickpea fries which were awesome, I really appreciate when restaurants do something different. I had the kale stuffed risotto and my husband had the seared stealhead. Both were very flavorful and delicious. Overall we had a really nice meal here and I would definitely come back.
author: Rachel W.

description: Heard about this place, and thought I would give it a try. It is SO hard to find a decent place to eat in this area, really! I loved how the ambiance took me back to my favorite brasseries of Paris or my favorite bar-cafe in New Orleans. Nothing pretentious, dark, old appearing, charming! The food was very good and well made, but somewhat predictable offerings for this city.  The waiter was helpful and chose a wonderful California (yes, here at a French restaurant the waiter actually suggested a CA wine!) chardonnay to go with the salmon that I ordered (and the salmon was cooked to perfection!). One star off for rather slow service (took about 20 minutes before our order was taken, although one could say that this makes this that more of an authentic French restaurant).
