I could most certainly return, although a little pricey.
author: 和子

description: Came here for a girls night out. Really cute and small place. I would not recommend to parties more than 3. It's good for a romantic dinner. Food is delicious and well prepared. Strongly recommend their duck breast!
author: Coco S.

description:
This is what a restaurant should be...scrupulously clean, exquisitely detailed yet simple, quiet and dignified service with amazing food.

The rose we ordered was like liquid silk.
The two brunch items - veal burger and smoked trout - were worthy of the gods.
Both items were possibly the best I have ever had in my life.
I can still taste the zucchini cakes that the trout was accompanied by - it was that good.
author: Yo M.

description: Very good, unique hole-in-the-wall type restaurant.  The chocolate ganache is 100% required if it's available the night you are there!
author: J C.

description:
I admit, I don't usually go for Sardines, but these appetizers were great. They were only bested by the cheese and jam plate, I would have been happy to walk out the door after the first course.

Pork shoulder main course was probably the least note worthy, paying hommage to the first and last, not detracting from the 2nd.

The Crème Fraîche was also terrific, a must try.

Price was fantastic for such a great meal.
author: Richard S.

description: This restaurant is fantastic.  My fiancé and I went to Bouche when we were in San Francisco for the weekend (we live in Chicago) and I found the restaurant on Yelp and decided to give it a try.  The food was great, and the restaurant was adorable.  The majority of the tables are upstairs, there are maybe 10 tables up there, it's very intimate.  We had a scallop appetizer which was both beautiful to look at and delicious to eat, and then for our main course I got the duck and my fiancé had the steak... it was so good.  We also got dessert and had a bottle of red wine (we just got what the server recommended, the wine list was in French).  I would definitely advise that you get reservations because of the size of the restaurant, but would definitely recommend this place to anyone and everyone who loves a unique atmosphere and experience.
author: Jessy S.

description:
The food is good, but I am not sure why it was so freezing in the dining room. Everyone else seems suffering with coat or jacket on through out the whole night, and one girl even ate with her gloves.
There is basically just one waiter taking care of everything, who implied  several times that she is from France,  and she KNOWs the wine list, but reluctantly to explain anything. Service is slow.
author: Ting R.

description:
Actual rate is 2 and a half stars. It really is in between "I've experienced better to A-OK" This place is intimately small and fairly priced. Came in with bf on 10:30pm reservation Saturday night and the host was very welcoming. 

Ordered two appetizers: Sardines and Trumpet mushroom salad (appetizers took way too long to come out, more than half hour), two entrees: True Cod and Pork Belly. Unfortunately my cod dish fell completely flat, it seriously lacked seasoning (had to sprinkle their table salt multiple times and still wasn't enough), pork belly dish was good, different flavors came through. I want to give them the benefit of the doubt I was the one unlucky person that had a badly executed cod but there were few things that didn't make up for it, for instance, our server didn't check up on us to see how things were going, otherwise I would of gotten a chance to change my dish.Tableware/dishes didn't correlate, felt confusing like they're meant for Asian fusion and service was so-so. 

This place is somewhat good but not great. Would I come here again? Maybe I'd like to give it another go but order the salmon like other yelpers raved about, but this place wouldn't be my first choice. 

Quick tip: Nice ambiance for a date but honestly the food ok.
author: Johanna P.

description:
My first experience at Bouche a week ago was fantabulous!  Starting from the grilled calamari, light dressed (almost no sauce), but very flavorful!  The other starter/side dish we ordered was brussel sprouts.  It's almost like the brussel sprout chips at Marlowe's.  Some slightly over-baked/fried.  Still delicious except a few burned spots.  

For main entrees. we had salmon and halibut, both delicious!!  The wines we picked/recommended by our waiter paired  well with our food as well! 

We didn't try their dessert this time.  We already made plans to go to the Seasons lounge for dessert.  I will definitely go back to Bouche again.  I highly recommend this restaurant!  

It's not a big restaurant, might not be ideal for big party unless you reserve the entir second floor.
author: Gina W.

description: Unexpected! Only a few blocks from work and didn't know it existed.  If you can get a table upstairs, you can enjoy some great food in a super nice atmosphere. Staff are super friendly and service is great.  Loved the food. Had the venison and pan seared salmon. Both are great dishes.
author: Pejman P.

description: I travel around over half the week every week. I get to try a lot of nice restaurants around the country. Hands-down this was the best food I've had in a very long time. I kept ordering different things expected not to be as good as the last but I was very happily surprise that the next test was always as good or better than the last. I had great service and I am and will be recommending this little French restaurant to everyone I know in the area.
author: Daniel E.

description:
This is a *very* tight little establishment and it was completely packed even on a Monday night, so I would definitely recommend reservations. 

I always resist comparisons to European establishments, but this place was filled with Europeans to the extent that in not speaking a word of French, i felt a bit out of place, especially in such tight quarters. However, the staff was both gracious and beautiful, and the food was delicioius. 

The convivial (to use a word evoked by the woman next to me at the bar) atmosphere was perfect in generating a feeling of warmth and conversation among people. You just couldn't help talking to each other and it proved a charming and enjoyable evening, if a little bit unexpectedly so. If this was a local neighborhood place for me (and it's not, as I live in Philadelphia), I daresay I'd be popping by at least once a week. 

I had the cheese plate with their Rose wine from Provence. Lovely. And I followed with the sardines marinated in grapefruit juice. I would have liked more sardines, I have to say but the dish was well constructed, very fresh, and had lots of flavor. I did get to try a bite of the salmon, which was decadent, really, sitting atop a nest of filo ribbons that enclosed a poached egg, but absolutely luscious. She also had the pork belly which was rich beyond measure and basically consisted of pork and potatoes, good hearty food, which would be perfect after walking five miles in foggy mist, I would think! 

I would definitely go back or recommend this place. A great little experience :-)
author: Sarah P.

description:
Went here on a Saturday night for dinner with a friend of ours.  The setting is very quaint and it felt like we were stepping into an old Parisian bistro.  Great ambiance and despite be very close quarters, it was easy to carry on a conversation.  I had the lamb shank, which was terrific.  The others had an octopus salad, which fell flat, lacking even one note, and the true cod, which was quite delish!  The $16 glass of wine was very good, if just slightly warmer than it should've been.  We shared the tart of the day, but I can't recall what it was, just remember it was too liquidy.

I will definitely be back, but will look very critically for consistency, as we had either home runs or strike outs.
author: Kevin M.

description: Small but very welcoming.  Menu is small but everything we ordered was very good. Only French wines and a bit pricey but will certainly return when we are in the area!
author: Bill R.

description: Love the location (next to my favorite Tunnel Top) and I have come twice, which means it marries atmosphere and food well.  It is inventive, and the service is warm. I guess I expect a few more seasonal changes (or daily changes) at a restaurant like this.  We sampled pretty broadly, and it was all good.
author: Laurel B.

description:
I thought I did the research. Came here with a group of friends. I asked for dishes on Yelp review pics. None of them was available. The answer was they changed the chef, now they have a new menu. 

OK we tried two appetizers and every main course on the menu:

Appetizer:
* Wild Greens, Caramelized Pear, Roquefort, Walnut and Endive Vinaigrette, Pepper Crust Bacon And Pickled Poached Egg
* Sautéed Sweetbread, Porcini Cream, Crimini and Maitake Mushroom Persillade

Main:
* Utternut Squash and Eggplant Napoléon, Cauliflower Velouté, White Truffle Vinaigrette
* Pan Seared Petrale Sole, Crispy Porcini Risotto, Espelette and Carrot Purée, Lobster Cream Sauce
* Citrus and Honey Confit Lamb Shank, Ratatouille, Roasted Almonds and Pomegrante Couscous
* Marinated Flat Iron Steak, Summer Squash And Potato Gratin, Shaved Asparagus, Red Corn

The two appetizers are OK. I don't eat lamb, so cannot comment it. The steak is great! The veggies and fish are so so. The veggies are too rich.

Before came here, I also checked its website. The pics look so pretty and appetizing. The food we ordered look nothing like that. 

Damage: $45 ppl
author: Emmy P.

description:
This place is by far the best french food I've had in the bay area.  I had the lamb shoulder and couldn't be more pleased.  The tenderness and rich flavors was magnificent. 

I would recommend sitting at the counter downstairs looking out the front window because the upstairs looked a little cramped.
author: Tim G.

description:
This tiny restaurant is a gem!  My boyfriend and I live down the street from Bouche, and we pass by it everyday.  We finally decided to try it, and we're both so glad we did.

To start, we had the brown butter roasted carrots and the sauteed calamari with mushrooms and citrus.  This is a great combination, because the sweetness of the carrots perfectly complemented the savory flavor of the calamari.  Both appetizers had simple ingredients but very complex flavors. These were my favorite! 

For our main course and side dishes, we had the herb crusted halibut, steak (which was the special that evening), mashed potatoes, and roasted brussel sprouts.  The fish was light and fluffy.  The steak was well-seasoned and perfectly cooked.  The brussel sprouts were good; however, it didn't stand out amongst the incredible dishes we had.  But, the best thing on their menu was the mashed potatoes.  To quote my boyfriend, "It is the best mashed potatoes I've ever had!"  He couldn't stop talking about it.  It was creamy, buttery and rich.  Simply put, it was heavenly!

Though the restaurant is really small, it has great ambiance.  The service was wonderful.  Our waiter was attentive but did not hover over us.  Portion sizes are small, but it's what you would expect in an authentic French restaurant. The prices are actually quite reasonable, especially if you compare it to other French restaurants in the city that offer the same quality of food. 

Definitely give Bouche a try. You won't be disappointed!
author: Khristine A.

description:
And we thought hey let's try a fancy small romantic french restaurant for dinner? Our hotel was just around the corner from this restaurant. We made reservations for 8pm. When we got there it is a small cozy french restaurant with a second floor. We dined on the 2nd floor where you can see the chefs whipping up your fine french cuisine. As  mentioned by other yelpers, their menu is very limited. We ordered the poached egg/smoked salmon and the cod along with the bread with olives baked inside of it. I guess you can say we are not used to small portions lol so we ended up picking up some sushi a couple hours later.

 Back to the food, since I am not a very picky eater I actually liked the poached egg with the salmon. The  creamy sauce went really well with the smoked salmon with the poached egg. I was not a fan of the cod all that much. Although, i did like the wine the waitress recommended. After dinner we decided to skip dessert so I can't really say all that much about it. 

Overall, this small place does have a romantic french bistro ambiance, but you need to be a hard core foodie to actually love and appreciate the small portion of food that is being presented. Come here to satisfy your taste palette, but unfortunately not your stomach. :)
author: Lynners C.

description: The best authentic French restaurant in Downtown SF. Very personal high-class service!
author: Jacob I.

description:
Just ate here this past Saturday and was really pleased with the quality and preparation of the food. I think the French influence really comes across in the perfect balance of portion and flavors in every dish. No ingredient seems superfluous or overpowering and each dish seems really well thought out.


-Great wine suggestions from the server for each pairing
- The cheese plate was paired with just the right amount of olives,figs,tomato jam and sliced pear to create a perfect balance
-Octopus salad was beautifully presented and was super fresh.
-Marinated salmon provided the perfect amount of savory/crunchy ratio
-The Creme Fraiche Desert was ZOMG!!!! 
-And the best espresso I've ever had!!

My only complaint was that the tables are a little close together for my taste. We were about 8 inches apart and I was forced to listen to two people that worked in the "Tanning Bed Industry" talk about their "work" during dinner.
author: Kathy K.

description: I took a client here for dinner, and it was near perfect. We were seated right away in the upstairs room. My only critique is that this place is quite small, so I was basically touching backs with the patron sitting at the table behind me. We had the fougasse to start, which is nothing particularly special, but it's bacon baked into bread, so you have to get it! The sommelier recommend a nice pinot noir, and didn't annoyingly point to the most expensive bottle, which I appreciated. I had the braised pork shoulder, and it was perfect. For dessert, I had the creme fraiche custard, and it was intensely sweet, but still good overall.
author: Benjamin A.

description:
Delicious! The house smoked salmon on egg was by far our favorite. The artichoke rice with cream sauce was nice, very rich and creamy. The chickpea fries were perfectly fried.

The space is awesome, the staff super friendly.
author: Ameer N.

description: Excellent service and wine suggestions. The restaurant has a fairly small footprint, and space is at a premium. This only increases the ambiance and charm. Food was simply but well presented. I would definitely come here again.
author: Rudy S.

description:
Quite lovely for dinner.  We didn't have a reservation but were more than happy to sit at the bar, at the window that faces the street.

The chestnut soup was fantastic.  It was rich and had such great depth of flavor with out being over the top.  I had the monkfish which was very good and my bf ha the lamb.  We didn't share since we each enjoyed our meals so much.

The recommended wine was perfect.  It kind of felt like we were in a cozy, rustic French bistro but I was just as happy being in beautiful San Francisco.
author: Caroline M.

description: Quaint and romantic and reminds you of being in France.  The workers are French and adds to the experience.  The cuisine is so Delish and I savored every bite.  I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a great food and a fair price.
author: Vu T.

description: You must try the crab mashed potatoes!! Best ever!! This place is very comfy and charming. Will be back next time we're in town.
author: Chris B.

description:
We came to this restaurant for a special occasion.  Our reservation got lost somehow, but the host accommodated us, and that I really appreciated.  We were placed upstairs and ordered our drinks and appetizers.  Soon after we arrived, a large party turned up at the table next to us.  We ordered our entrees and waited patiently for more than an hour, while the large party (who arrived after us) had their meals served to them.  We waited 20 minutes more before I finally asked our waitress about the delay.  She told us that they are very busy, and there were other orders in front of us (like the large party who ordered AFTER us, just par example) and then she went on to yell in my face 'and kitchen only has two burners!'  When the food finally did arrive, it was mediocre.  
My bf suspected the waitress was probably bumping the large order in front of us because she would take a bigger tip sooner.  I don't know if that was the case or not, but I do hope we won't be spending $250 on an experience like this again any time soon.
author: Leslie F.

description: I never write these, but after the AMAZING meal here, I had to! The braised pork over polenta was amazing! To top it off, créme frîache custard as dessert was... You guessed it... Amazing. We're coming back ASAP. - Steven G
author: Steven C.

description:
The food is great, the service its slow but is worth the waiting. The veal was awesome and the salmon apetizer too. The rissotto was breaded and was not so great, just ok.
Be sure to order the tart of the day..
author: Alejandra I.

description: Excellent food, cozy environment, very knowledgable and friendly staff. Would recommend to anyone.
author: Michael M.

description: This place is a gem.  The cuisine is truly French.  I love the ambiance of the restaurant.  It's rustic and really small.  The staff was terrific--attentive without being imposing and was able to provide some great recommendations.  The portions are just right the wine list is extensive for both by the glass or the bottle.  Definitely worth a visit if you are into French cuisine.
author: Shirley H.

description: Came here for our 4-year anniversary.  The host/owner was very accommodating.  The space is small and intimate.  The staff is super knowledgable and is more than happy to suggest items if you are uncertain what to eat or drink.  I would visit this place every time I go to SF.
author: Chris S.

description: this place is very small, we had to wait 20 minutes after our original reservation time in the bar area. The food is not spectacular, it's okay. the lamb shank was tender soft and flavorful.
author: ittai s.

description: We went there on a Thursday night and it was very busy! We made a last minute reservation on Yelp, but still had to wait quite a while, the waitress was friendly and apologetic, they offered us a complimentary cheese plate while we waited which was really lovely and delicious. My husband had several different beers all which were quite yummy. Once we were seated, I ordered the lamb shank and my husband ordered the skirt steak. We both had red french wine which was good. My lamb shank was AMAZING. The best I've ever eaten, the meat was so tender. My husband loved his meal too. We received a complimentary mash potato also, which was very kind of the staff. I don't think they thought we would wait as long as we did but I can tell you it was well worth the wait!
author: Jem K.

description:
Really really good food. A right combo of solid French with Calif creativity. Very friendly service. A gem!
(the only minor drawback: it's tiny, the tables are tiny, and set close to each other. thus it's noisy and hard to maintain a conversation. thus, a bit suboptimal for a biz dinner but must be great for casual or date)
author: Sergei B.

description: I came here with my good friend tonight, and it was a very nice French bistro (10 tables max in the entire restaurant).  The cuisine is not as traditionally French as you may expect; I ordered the salmon with poached egg which was very good (only thing to note is that the portion was quite small -- I wasn't quite full after this dish), and the ambiance is lovely.  Worth checking out, but may want to check out other places for more traditional French fare.
author: Mel G.

description: Lackluster service and mediocre food, I had hoped that Bouche would be a great venue for a romantic Valentine's Day dinner with my sweetheart but we were both very disappointed.
author: Peter H.

description:
Good Food , good service!!
Very very small place but intimate. Short menu but  tasty. I wouldn't recommended dungeness crab mash potatoes if you are on a diet because...it's too rich and very creamy...The red snapper and the Tomahawk pork chop are just perfect. Good wine recommendation for food pairing. Must try the desert - tart of the day. Not a place for kid. Overall, we like it....
author: Ttt C.

description: Great addition to Union Square. There are very few quality late night spots and this is definitely a go to. The staff is always very knowledgable, and the kitchen is working it with that tiny space. All of the plateware is handmade by the owners wife, amazing.
author: Darla M.

description: I'm not a big French foodie but my client was and we were very impressed. Wonderful local vibe and amazing menu with great French wines to match up. We enjoyed sweet breads, petrale sole, lamb and then salad with cheese plate for dessert.
author: Rob M.

description: what a find. ate here last night before a show. small restaurant...we ate in the somewhat cramped upstairs dining room. everything we had was delicious. starters were the salad and stuffed calamari, followed by the hanger steak and salmon. nice reasonably priced wine list. very good service. not cheap-the bill including wine about $200. this was by far one of the best dining experiences we have had in s.f., and we would come back again in a heartbeat. highly recommended!
author: Joseph B.

description:
I went by myself for a birthday dinner so I could do some serious eating and analysis. Verdict: DEELIshhhhhhhhhh! I had the tar tar (delightful start), lamb shank (home sweet home), side of crab-mashed ( yes, I said crab-mashed which were spiritually moving), and because my mama didn't raise no calorie-counters, I finished with Creme fraiche custard. Whammo! Home run! It's your birthday! It's your birthday!

Run don't walk.
author: Andrea B.

description:
Bouche is tiny, a bit dreary, dark, and has poor service.  Not a winning formula for a restaurant.  But Bouche also has real talent in the kitchen.  That kind of makes up for the requested bread that never came and the haphazard way that the food came to the table.

Green garlic soup with charred onions was a stunner.  The charred onions by themselves give the place a star.  Wonderful.

Sardines aren't really my thing.  But they do them nicely enough here.  The meaty fish were nicely complemented by marinated vegetables.   Another good plate of food.

Lamb shoulder came with an almond marmalade and a dollop of chick pea puree.  The lamb was tasty and not too fatty nor too lean.  The almond marmalade was just what the lamb needed, a slightly sweet but not too sweet something to set it off.

A nice glass of wine and bingo a good meal!  The venue is so small that that may be hard to fix, but the service could well be up-graded a bit.  Since the place is new, practice may make perfect.
author: David D.

description: Very small intimate bistro just above union square on bush at Stockton. Brought my kids which is not their forte but they were very accommodating. Our waiter went nx store to get us a Dr Pepper!  Started with arugula salad which was great. For entrees we had red snapper, lamb shoulder, and eggplant.  All amazing. Then a glass of Sauternes and a tart.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Two sources referred us here, the concierge at Hotel Nikko, and the very kind maitre d' from Jeanne D'Arc (then renovating) just up the street.  We were not disappointed.

In fact, we were thrilled, and took the trouble to thank both our referrals.  Bouche is crowded, vivid, attentive, savvy.  We let our waiter pick our wines, we picked two entrees, and we devoured every last crumb, savored every last drop.  The matchup was perfect.

I watched the staff assemble salads for others, and noted how as many greens were tossed aside as were allowed onto the plates ... the attention to quality was fantastic, but we already knew that, we'd just savored four superb tastes.

I have no trouble with awarding five stars.  For our one night in The City in months, we were excited and thrilled with this find.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
I'm seriously struggling to figure out what makes this place rate so highly!  I'm really guessing it was just an off, very late, late night (we came at around 11:00pm on a Friday night). Still, the food just left so much to be desired.  It's romantic-ish, we were on the top floor and as said in other reviews, what the chefs pull off in their tiny kitchen spaces is pretty cool.  If you go to the bathroom, you see a tiny little broom closet off to the side where one of the chefs was going at it.  I first thought it was a broom in a closet who was fairly animated, but no ... it was a chef.  And he was cooking some mean smelling shizzle.  But the food that came to us was pretty bland, not all that tasty, and just very fair (at best).  And for the price, you'd expect something more than that.  We had the lamb shoulder, and the crusted ?tilapia fish.  The fish was rather rubbery, had several bones, and was not very flavorful.  And the lamb shoulder definitely could have been seasoned stronger.

I was really surprised at how I didn't enjoy the food.  The waiter was very charming, and put up with me and my wife on our cell phones the entire meal (definitely a restaurant fail move, but a pseudo-medical emergency was being actively managed while we ate)...  

If you want to give Bouche a shot, definitely go at a more normal eating time, try again, and hope for the best.  Just didn't do it for us.
author: Nikhil P.

description: Wow.   Stumbled across this.  Ok.  The guy was so nice helping me choose the right wine.  They were so friendly and inviting.  Small menu (4 items) and I choose the snapper never having snapper. Wow. It melt in my mouth.  So nice.  So inviting. Really cool place. Please go here - you will NOT be disappointed.  It was so cool watching the people in the kitchen too.    Will come back for sure.  It was a very young type of place too.
author: Robert P.

description: Excellent service ...cozy french vibe ...amaZing meal!!!
author: Joey D.

description:
Went there of Thursday night, restaurant came highly recommended from a friend.   Ordered the sweetbread and a glass of wine - so to be fair, I didn't really get to do a thorough sampling of the menu - and maybe this review is a little premature... but my sweetbread dish (it was fairly humorous to hear the handsome and charming chef describe what a sweetbread is... ) was prohibitively salty which was a pity because the mushrooms that came with the veal guts were beautiful and didn't need much. The wine was very good and the gentleman who took my order was very patient in helping me select it. 

Pros: Handsome, helpful, charming staff. Cute decor, although slightly cramped space.


Cons: everything on the menu was quite rich, and my food happened to have so much salt in it that I wondered if the veal and mushrooms were ancillary (as in would you like some sweetbread with your salt?)

That said, I would go back here to give this place another try to see if my experience was just a fluke.
author: R H.

description:
The food:
Tasty - very creamy, but I say the portions aren't generous, especially for the price.  If you're not too hungry, this is OK.  If you need carbs, you will be spending a little more money.  I had the salmon featured as the picture.  For $15 I had meagre two slices of salmon and the rest was creme fraiche.  The salmon was good but I had to order more food.  I would say, appetizer instead.  My friends had better servings but again, if you are starving, I would say you need to order more.
author: Z C.

description:
I came here for a goodbye brunch with a couple of friends.
The slow roasted pork is amazing! This is a very intimate and classy brunch atmosphere so wouldn't recommend if you were looking to grab a quick, casual bite.

There are so many good brunch places in the city though that this wouldn't be my top pick to come back, hence the dock in 1 star. I would like to try their dinner here though. 

Service is great. The only complaint I had here during our service was that there was an extremely large and obnoxious party seated behind us. If this unfortunate circumstance happens, you can barely hear the person talking next to you. Of course, this is of no fault of the restaurant and I'm not docking 1-star because of this but just letting you know how cozy of a place this is.
author: Aggie Z.

description:
I took my wife here for her birthday this year and we had a great time.   Rustic setting, we dined upstairs with the windows open with a welcome breeze on a very warm July night. 

We had theater tickets for 8pm and a reservation for 6:30, and they had no problem getting us in and through without feeling rushed. Great wine selection if you like French wine, and the food was excellent. I chose a salmon entree that was amazing considering it was a very warm evening: sushi grade salmon on a bed of a poached egg and creme fraiche with lightly fried strings of either onion or potato...excellent. Started the night with a glass of champagne and had a glass of the M. Chapoutier with my entree. My wife had the herb crusted halibut that was great as well. We also tried an appetizer of "Pannisse" that was fried chickpeas (puree) - a bit like mozzarella sticks, but much, much better, and the side we ordered with our entrees was a creamy polenta with Comte. Great meal, for about $100 for two. Would go many times again.
author: Kevin M.

description:
What is it that makes a restaurant more than its parts?  While I am not wise enough to provide the answer to this question, I am smart enough to know it when I see it, and this exemplifies one of my favorite destinations, Bouche. 

The staff is French, but I don't mean it in the oft-cliche sense of the word. From the owner, Guillaume, to the dishwasher there is a warmth and joy and a sense of teamwork. From the tiniest kitchen you could imagine emerge the most meticulous, magnificent and on-point dishes. The chef has a deft hand and almost all preparations exceed expectations. Yes, a dish that may be your favorite might not be on the menu the next time you come in (unless like me your favorite is the house cured salmon with a poached egg in a potato birds nest), but this just just means that you should expand your mind and find a new favorite for the evening. Come prepared to experiment and you will not be disappointed. 

Seating is cramped, but in a way that encourages instant comaraderie between you and the couple next to you. A sensible wine selection includes reasonably priced offerings by the glass and bottle, as well as the essential splurge bottle. Beers on tap are excellent if you need something other than wine. 

A slice of France without the attitude or the plane ticket - a wonderful adventure every time you enter the door.
author: Steven B.

description:
A cozy french bistro admist the hustle of union square with great food & fantastic staff.  The 3 of us diners had a reservation & were seated at the bar (per my opentable request)..I want to see the chefs make my food if i'm gonna eat it!

We ordered a great sampling of food & walked out happy campers. The fougasse was OMG, warm bread with bacon (or ham??) baked into the bread. It reminded me of chinese bakeries that sell/serve ham & scallion buns except this is way better because the pieces of bacon were bigger & just heavenly (5 pieces in an order, make sure u order 2 if more than 3 ppl in your group).

I had the must try arugula salad w/poached egg. As suggested, mix it all up together..you get this fantastic creamy yolk wrapped with the peppery arugula & cured ham, fava bean puree w/the fried spring onion. I swear, poached egg in a salad takes things to a whole other spectrum..silky goodness.

We tried the english pea soup- a creamy, hammy based soup with some small potato chunks that was piping HOT (a good thing!!). We liked the soup as it wasn't just creamy but with the ham & potato, it gave texture. OOHH, fougasse dipped in soup..ahhh, tasty..

Entrees-we ordered the Lamb loin, medium rare & the stuffed chicken. Both entrees were delicious. The lamb loin was good but next time, i personally might order it Medium (medium rare was just a bit too rare IMO but it wasn't my own entree this time around). I loved the haricot verts & summer squash salad that the lamb loin sat on..perfect summer veggies for the weird warm day SF experienced. Now, I rarely order chicken at a restaurant w/the fear of DRY chicken but the chef recommended it & i went with it. Finally, a chicken that wasn't dry & it was perfectly seasoned, paired well with the poached(?) half peach. It also came w/brussel sprouts cream which I thought was creamed spinach until i looked at the menu again..who knew? it was a nice take on that little cabbage! 

We also tried the polenta & comte side dish--yum, I can eat this all the time. The polenta texture & creaminess was perfect with the slight cheddary nutty comte cheese mixed in. 
Chef also sent out a complimentary dish of the wild mushrooms medley which I was eyeing on the menu but I thought spicy apple sauce would be weird. The spicy apple sauce definitely toned the woody-ness of the mushrooms. These really were wild mushrooms & definitely had the strong funghi, woody, umami flavor but with the apple sauce (which i thought was odd at first), i can see why it goes together. It had that interesting sweet/savory balance, not really spicy at all as noted. 

We shared the creme fraiche custard w/sea salt & the caramel creme(was it creme? it definitely was caramel flavored) dessert. That was really good too, a creamy, not overly sweet dessert but at this point we were stuffed beyond belief. Of course, we still finished every bite of the dessert. 

Portions are not big by american standards but I prefer it that way. You can order different dishes to share, taste, eat & still be stuffed. All the food had such different tastes, flavor profiles, textures that it's just amazing to think it came from that small kitchen. I cannot wait to try the smoked salmon next time w/fougasse!!!

Also, they had a great selection of french wines by the glass or bottle & interesting microbrews. We enjoyed our glasses of Neri Rose wine, it was slightly dry & refreshingly chilled
Super close walking distance to Sutter Stockton garage (a huge plus in my book). Service was attentive & friendly, food was yummy & it had that really cozy bistro feel which i really enjoyed. I will come back again..even at midnite! Score for late nite 'fancy food' dining!!

**make a reservation! it is a small place.
author: Yolanda L.

description: Nice place, well below par French food in SF. Look to Cocette, Cafe Claude if in the 'hood
author: Calvin G.

description: I love this place,I was there yesterday and the food is tasty and the ingredients awesome!!!I loved the cheese selection!
author: Jennifer H.

description: It was a very nice face lift for Swell. Beautiful decor, walls seemed to be unfinished.
author: Jonathan C.

description: If you're looking for a nicer place with a friendly staff, this is a great spot to check out. It had a really nice updated but old world vibe. I was visiting from out of town, saw this place nearby on Yelp and would have missed it otherwise. It's a small place with an authentically French staff, almost all of whom greeted us with a smile and a friendly word or two. The waitress was very helpful in discussing the various wines and the food was really quite delicious.
author: Brian Y.

description:
Ambience is good but you will most likely be seated at a narrow bar in a row which does not make for good conversation or a lingering dinner. They do have upstairs tables but few and they probably require reservations. When one pays these prices and when the food is this long to come out and when the service is fairly inattentive, I want comfort for the time I am there. The bar seating does not offer such comfort.
The quality of the food and cooking is average at best although it is nice to experience something different for a change. 
My stuffed chicken breast was actually thigh but it did work better than a breast would have for the flavors. The sausage in the stuffing was not crumbled up enough so that I actually had large fried pieces that had to be cut in order to eat. The restaurant was not busy so this was just carelessness.
My son said that his small meal was not an entree but rather a salad with a garnish of lamb. The lamb was cooked perfectly though it was the size of one lamb chop.
 The trout appetizer on the potatoes was quite a pleasant surprise but make sure to get all the different parts of it in your bite for the experience to really count.
 My husband's halibut was fine but again quite small portions. 
We had appetizers and entrees and left hungry after sharing a wonderful pannacotta. When we got home we continued to be hungry despite spending $140 on the dinner for 3, not counting alcohol. At home we had snacks to fill us up which is not the way one wants to wrap up their pricey French restaurant experience.
I eat out alot and this is overpriced for the fare, for the quality, for the portions, for the ambience and comfort.

Did our waitress really have a French accent or was it affected or enhanced? I believe some of the accents were real but, hmmm.
author: Mag D.

description:
Food:
We ordered the pork belly, lamb shoulder, and roasted tomato/pickled cucumber side for dinner and the creme fraîche custard for dessert. All were very delicious. My wife was in heaven. Both the lamb and the pork belly were fantastic, which made the tomato and cucumber side a great foil. The custard came as two perfect, small components (an elegant simple custard and a tiny dish of salted caramel). In typical French fashion it was quite rich, so we were glad we shared it.

Service:
We arrived at early dinner time, mid week without a reservation, so we were expecting to be turned away. They were quite accommodating and offered to seat us at the bar along the wall, which we gladly accepted. Besides having to sit on a backless barstool for a couple of hours, this was entirely fine.

The server was friendly, funny, and gave good suggestions about the menu options. The meal courses came out with good time spacing. At the end of the meal we did not feel rushed, and left with a smile.

Ambiance:
For a small space it felt cozy without being cramped. Everyone, staff and guests alike, seemed to speak French. The music was pleasant and part of the background, not part of the feature. And the kitchen is open, so if you are seated in the right spot you can watch the cooks and chef at work.

Overall:
I hesitate to give 5 stars, because that tends to mean everything was/is perfect. It's not. But our experience was excellent and for the price point you will be challenged to do better. We will return, and recommend this place highly.
author: Aaron H.

description: Near a parking garage, always nice in the city. Great use of space with lovely cozy atmosphere. Went here for 15 year wedding anniversary, very good find. Enjoyed the cheese and the bone marrow appetizers. For the main course, probably the best duck I've ever had, tender and delightful. My husband had the steak, done perfectly. Waiter helped us with the wine selection as we are not familiar with french wines (Sonoma County folks), happy with his recommendation. Dessert, a chocolate tart and some champagne. No complaints, good place to go.
author: Denise R.

description: Excellent,  we wanted to find a place like this in Paris! Scallop appetizer was wonderful, pork chop, lamb chop and brussels sprouts were excellent.  Banana tart was just so so. If you like French cuisine, give it a try.
author: Daryl M.

description: My husband and and I had dinner in the small upstairs dining area of this little bistro. The food was excellent. We had two appetizers -the asparagus and the sweetbreads. The sweetbreads were really yummy. We had beef for our main course - it was perfectly cooked and tender. Our dessert was the caramelized pineapple - also excellent. So why the 2 star review? It is because our waiter was so condescending, arrogant, aloof and unwelcoming that we will not return. For one example, when we asked for a recommendation of wines to pair - he simply pointed at an entry on the wine list with a slight look of bemused disgust on his face. No description, no discussion, no words at all - just a jabbing finger. We were never treated like this on one of our several trips to France!
author: Diane S.

description: This place is overrated. Still good, but not worth the price. If I'm going to be spend $28 on a small entree, I want it to be excellent. That was not the case. The atmosphere was the real plus here, a great place for a date. It definitely had that kind of pretentious feel, but that made for fun conversations.
author: Evan N.

description:
Value adjusted rating.  Food was pretty good, but not as imaginative as I had hoped.  The atmosphere was cute, kind of an upgraded chez maman.

produce was clearly fresh.  
not a huge fan of the bacon bread
++ to the beet IC and goat cheese cake - highlight of evening

http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2012/12/11/bouche-chef-shuffle-michel-rethore-replaces-nico-borzee/
author: M K.

description:
3.5 stars for me!
A quaint, tiny little place literally on top of the Stockton Tunnel.  I remember climbing those urine scented stairs in my youth from Stockton St. below to get to the top, where there really wasn't much to see.
It's conveniently located next to the parking garage which is dirt cheap for parking after 6pm (a buck an hour!!).  
There are few seats in the downstairs located to the right of the front door, but it's counter seating.  We went upstairs to the "dining" area which had 18 chairs, a bit more crowded than the usual 14 they normally seat, according to the waiter asst.  who made sure I knew he was "French" because his English was limited.  Our waiter spoke perfect English.

We tried 2 glasses of French wine (red and white) recommended by the waiter, pricey per glass but very, very good:  GL Beaupre $14 and GL El Moli $14.
Meal:
1. Arugula Salad, $9.  Hubby liked the dish a great deal. I remember nuts and pomegranate seeds in it.
2. Mackerel salad, $12.  Not many pieces of mackerel in it, considering it's mackerel season.  It was good.
3. Steelhead entree, $22.  The waiter warned me that it was raw. Gently seared on the outside, it came in a rounded chunk of fish, definitely raw inside.  It was just OK for me. I love sushi but this didn't appeal to me too much, then again, I don't like seared ahi that much either.
4. Duck breast, $26, about 6 slices of duck, very tender. Hubby enjoyed it.
5. Side of polenta, $6.  Nice amt of cheese and creamy.  This dish I would order again.
6. Americano coffee, $3.50.  (don't expect a lot)
7. Tarte (tart of the day).  The folks next to us had it and said it was choc.  I didn't taste any choc but thought it was fig or something.  I think the waiter told us it had choc, $8.
8. Mousse, $9.  A lge tablespoon of white choc mousse, another of cream, and a 3rd scoop of a berrylike substance.  Meh.
Room temp bread comes to the table with cold butter only if you ask for it.
Overall, I would come back because it's really a gem in the neighborhood but I might try something else instead.
author: Ry T.

description: Very very very satisfied with their customer service and the food was amazing!! Portions were a little bit on the smaller side but the taste makes up for it. I will definetely be back to try other dishes
author: Chris L.

description: Wow awesome food the pork loin with fava beans and the marinated salmon with poached egg
author: Art R.

description: We went for a birthday and had an amazing experience. The food is always delicious, (goat cheese cheese cake with beats ice cream is to die for!) the service was great, they took care of us through out the evening. To make it even better, the environment is warm, welcoming with a rustic feel. Coming from Montreal, it definitely reminded me of a cozy European town.
author: Jon M.

description: Great place! We had a wonderful dinner for 5 and perfect french experience. We started with  the charcuterie which was well worth it and delicious. There were 4 entres to choose from and we tried them all. Everyone shared some of each and they were fabulous. Drinks and deserts were superb. Ambiance was tres authentique.
author: david m.

description: The food was creative and delicious.  Our waiter, who may have been the owner, was extremely nice and had really great suggestions about the menu and what we'd like.  The -1 star is because it is extremely cramped and hot. They have 3 fans in the loft area, which is the only table seating, and my husband was still sweating during the meal.  It was also very easy to listen to the conversation going on next to me.  Like I said, amazing food, great staff, awful seating.  I might squeeze in there again for the goat cheese cake.
author: Sarai J.

description: Came here with my girlfriend, who has an unhealthy obsession with all things French.  The space was cozy and the wait staff had heavy French accents.  For appetizers we got the fougasse and duck confit croquants.  The croquants were good, but not memorable.  I had no idea what fougasse was, but Wikipedia told me it was some sort of French bread.  Only when the bread came to the table did we realize that it was scattered with BACON, which is awesome, obviously.  For the entree I got the special for the night, which was chicken stuffed with brussel sprouts and cheese.  It was absolutely delicious.  Juicy, tender, and extremely flavorful.  After the entrees, we got the creme fraiche custard.  It consisted of a small bowl of custard and a small plate of caramel.  The combination of the creamy custard, sweet caramel, and sprinkles of salt made for a very satisfying dessert.  Overall, Bouche was an excellent experience.
author: Simon L.

description: Had a great meal here while on a business trip.  I was alone and they sat me in a nice spot upstairs.  Service was excellent (great recommendation on the wine!)  Food was excellent.  Would definitely come back.
author: T C.

description: This place is worth a reservation or wait. Helpful wait staff and you can't go wrong with any selection. Sweetbreads were absolutely amazing, along with the steak tartare, scallops and salad. I will return.
author: Jared M.

description: Cozy place.  Romantic ambiance.  Tasty food.  Tables are a little closer than I like, but I guess that's most cafe in the city.  Bar area is very
author: Dan K.

description: Unpretentious, good food, cozy. Can't ask for much more. The pork chops and duck were cooked to perfection. Great place for a date.
author: Eddie H.

description: Loved it!! Small gem of a restaurant unexpectedly located just off Union Square. Reservations are definitely recommended as there are so few tables. There is some seating in the bar area downstairs, but all other parties are seated upstairs. Ambiance is cozy and stylish without being stuffy. The entire waitstaff seems to have thick French accents, which helps add to the personality of this place. The food is what truly makes this restaurant exceptional, however. Highlights of our meal include the chorizo and pistachio-crusted halibut as well as the creme fresh custard... mind-blowing. Definitely a little pricey, but totally worth the experience.
author: Laura F.

description: No question about it the food is really wonderful and deserves five stars.  While the hostess seemed friendly and welcoming I think our waiter may have had too many tables and we felt really rushed.  This was a special birthday celebration so we really wanted to have more than a quick meal and it just didn't seem possible.  I'd go back anytime for a quick glass of wine and appetizer in the bar, but not for a quiet relaxing dinner.
author: Lori B.

description: It is a bitch walking up Powell then down Bush but the fact that it is open till 1am?  5 stars for a nocturnal like me.  And to enjoy good, well prepared dishes with a glass of wine and finish off with dessert at this hour?  5 stars.  I had the wagyu sirloin served with fingerling potatoes, a glass of dry white wine from a large selection, and chose the creme fraiche with dulce de leche to finish.  Everything was excellent and I would give it 4 stars.  Portions are small, which is typical in most French restaurants, but prices are still reasonable. 3 stars for that.  Ambience is very cozy there's the bar downstairs, and dining upstairs, linens are crisp and ironed, and atmosphere is quite casual, with well dressed patrons mixing up with casually dressed drop ins like me.  The menu is pretty small, some of those listed by others are not on it so I surmised the operation is more like a typical bistro where the choices depend on what's available for the day. I get that, having sampled bistros in Paris.  The service is fine, for a lone diner, I can't complain about not getting enough attention as opposed to those who seem to be regulars. 4 stars.  Overall excellent experience.
author: Soc G.

description:
Went here for the first time last, turned out to be the perfect place for first class French Bistro food without any of the stereotypical French dishes..duck confit starter was excellent as were the sardines........I ordered a side dish of braised spring onions and horseradish to complement my Lamb shoulder which was cooked to perfection.
Excellent wine list of French only wines, The Chateau De Beaupres at $13 a glass was excellent......will definitely be going back but this time will start the evening off at the Tunnel Top bar next door for a cocktail
author: Michael G.

description: Fantastic ambience and excellent food.  If you like pork belly or lamb shoulders or ridiculously good bread (fougasse), you'll be pleasantly surprised.  Very small space so come prepared with a reservation and an empty stomach.
author: E L.

description: Some of the dishes was ok...stuff chicken for Saturday menu is not so great, for two pieces of chicken was undercook and cost $26.Service is good...not much choice on the menu.
author: Angkana P.

description:
We have been here after 10 PM when almost all places where closed. Bouche met us with friendly stuff, quite atmosphere, great interiors and tasty duck and lamb
Very french place, and I almost forgot that we were in San Francisco
author: Mila H.

description: I had read that they have garlic soup and noticed that it is located a few blocks from my job so decided to check it out. I showed up about 10 minutes before they opened (I saw garlic soup and got so excited that I didn't even think to see what time they opened!), I was seated immediately and got a wonderful wine recommendation to pair with the soup. All that staff was super friendly, which is a huge relief when you are dining alone. I had the garlic soup and polenta, both were absolutely fantastic!!! This will be a regular spot for me from now on!
author: Crystal P.

description: Two dishes were great, one was so so, and the wait for food was quite long due to a mistake in the kitchen. Cost was ~120 for two, high for the food quality, but decor was spectacular, and location quite quaint, so 4 stars it is.
author: Nick L.

description: wow! incredible food.  Tiny little french restaurant located near Union Square. Had the snapper which was cooked to perfection and extremely fresh.
author: C R.

description: Excellent food and drinks although I go way more often for the later. The servers are super friendly and is determined to help you find that glass of wine. Had food here several times, excellent experience. Always see plenty of people sitting by the window and having a relaxing time. Glad it is in the neighborhood.
author: Guang H.

description: We had a wonderful Father's Day dinner. The beet salad was to die for and the pork belly appetizer was delicious. For the main course we had the Oregon coho salmon which was cooked to perfection. The waiters recommendation of the wine went perfectly with our entire dinner.  Oh yes, and the dessert, strawberries and whipped cream (shared) capped off a perfect dinner. The service was impeccable.
author: Dennis H.

description: Maybe I am just another uninformed tourist in SF (and husband certainly is, wink!) but, in the end this little place suited us well. We had no reservation, so we came early and were seated at the Chef's Bar. The "show" was as good as the food. The deft prep in this airplane cockpit sized kitchen was fairly mesmerizing. We twice noticed the chef halt the "sous chef" from serving a dish while a tiny correction was made. Also, each time they needed to touch something (for instance a quail egg) that could possibly contaminate, they pulled on a pair of clean kitchen gloves. The plates were simple and delicious and fairly well priced. My husband is a "reverse" food snob. A whiff of anything francophilian and the place is already down a star in the door. In the end, he was in love with his beef dish and I can't stop thinking about the Creme Fraiche Custard. Poor reviews are more fun and snarky to write, but this time.. Food alone, I would have given it a 4.5 but....they were just what we needed, when we needed it. Include the fact that they established themselves near my hotel... I'll happily do five stars.
author: Susan S.

description:
We were going to a Saturday matinee and wanted a new place to dine within walking distance of San Francisco's theatre district (Union Square). We also wanted a place where we could linger with the friends who were joining us for dinner.

I had never heard of Bouche, but it sounded like the perfect spot. Our reservation was right at 5:30, when they open.

The upstairs dining room is small, with dim lighting. Our first courses were served promptly: English Pea Soup with a Croque Monsieur Bite, the Mache Salad with a Pickled Poached Egg, and, for my husband, the Crab Mashed Potatoes which is a side dish.

Our waiter didn't realize that the Crab Mashed dish was meant to be a first course and so we had to ask for it.

Then, we had an over an hour wait for our main courses. Each dish is prepared to order in a tiny kitchen downstairs. But, since we were among the first in this tiny place, this was not acceptable, particularly because our server never indicated that there were any "problems" with getting our meals to us.  After we complained, they explained that our food had been served to another table!!! 

But, when we did get our food, it was wonderful: Marinated Flank Steak, Pan Seared Rock Cod, and a special meat dish for the day.

The food is outstanding, but, be prepared for a leisurely meal, possibly a bit too leisurely. Come here for outstanding French food. Don't come before you are going to theatre, as you will be stressed wondering if you will be there a curtain time; save it for after a matinee, or just a night out of dining.

I highly advise going early to assure getting seated when you arrive. When we left, people were lined up on the sidewalk waiting for a table.
author: Beverly D.

description: On a Friday night, called 10 minutes before arrival and was able to get seats at the counter, which was quite nice. Service was a little slow, but very friendly. Great wine list, almost all French and reasonably priced. Got a nice Cotes du Rhone that fit the meal perfectly. The potato leek cream soup was fabulous; light but full of flavor. The lamb shank  was perfect, not quite fall-off-the-bone, with just enough bite to really hold the flavor of the meat when paired with the sauce. Polenta, browned pearl onions were a, great complement to the plate. I will definitely come back! The best meal we had in 5 days in SF.
author: Fred K.

description: The most amazing meal! Every single part was delicious- appetizers, main course, dessert, and wine! The staff was great. I was surprised at how small the place was, but it didn't feel overcrowded. Overall, a fantastic restaurant and atmosphere. Can't wait to go back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Andrea L.

description: Excellent restaurant. Every dish on the table tasted wonderful. If you're French you get brownie points.
author: Varun B.

description:
Order the Citrus and Honey Confit Lamb Shank!!  The cod was delicious, too, but the lamb was perfect. My wife and I came here for her birthday, and the staff was very kind and friendly. I was honestly surprised to hear that others had bad experiences with the service here. 

True, it's a very small place, and you will be sitting inches from strangers. However, it's nothing different from many urban restaurants, and it does not change the fact that these folks know how to put a dish together. I don't know that much about French cuisine, but the server made excellent suggestions for appetizers, entrees, and wines. Thanks, Bouche, for an excellent evening!
author: Alex W.

description: The food is incredible, great staff, very friendly and knowledgeable. The goat milk cheesecake with beet sorbet is amazing and a must have.
author: Jonathan C.

description: The food was good and we managed to get a place for 2 without booking on New Year's Eve! The price was reasonable for French food, the only thing I would say is that the seating is quite cramped and it can get really loud!! But overall it's good
author: Vanessa W.

description: I have to say that this place might be one of the cutest places in SF. It's small and quaint, and very French ;). The servers are so sweet and the food is very good. We had the potato salad with gribiche sauce, radishes, and apples, the lamb shoulder with onion and almond marmalade, and the creme fraiche custard. Everything was so good! The lamb was so savory and tender, the spices in the salad were delicious, and the creme fraiche custard was perfect. I can't even say how adorable this place is and it's open late!
author: Sheeva G.

description: Both food and service were wonderful!  My husband and ate there our last night in San Francisco.  I had the sole and he had the pork chop, a side of the crab mashed potatoes and followed by the custard and chocolate banana tart.  One of the best meals while we were in the city.
author: J N.

description: Love Love love this place.  It's cute, cozy and romantic.  Very limited seating, it has a nice upstairs area but also very small. Make reservations for sure.  Not a good place for big parties but if you're looking for  a nice dinner with your honey i would suggest this place.  I came here on my birthday, since I live so close I've been wanting to check  this place out  for a while.  The food was delicious and the decor inside is nice.. when you walk in and see a cute little wooden pig sign hung in the restaurant you know it's going to be good.  I suggest everyone to try out this place.  Afterwards, go grab a drink at tunnel top.
author: Joanne W.

description: The food was off and on for me. The apps i had were duck confit and Cured Sea Trout were both good. I have seem reviews on the duck confit say its dry, but when i had it the inside was moisten and outside was crunchy. My girlfriend had the Stuffed Chicken Paupiette an she loved it. I had Grilled Lamb Loin it was ok just because the seasoning on it wasnt even on it some part were under season. The dessert was great had the tart and the Creme Fraiche Custard for my girlfriend to love the Creme Fraiche Custard must mean it good she doesnt like anything that has caramel in it.
author: Stephen F.

description:
All of our entries arrived COLD.
What a turn off...
Not even once the waiter came by offering any assistance. I am very easy going, not demanding or demeaning so I do admit my feelings were hurt.
-Filling water glasses well, that's all I could say... 
I asked about something and the French guy told me his English isn't that good and he can't answer my very easy question. He never even tried...
It supposed to be a very important dinner to me, but it was NEVER acknowledged like it was supposed 2 be by the staff that got heads up. 
Why did you ask at the beginning but not acknowledge the very important occasion I mentioned? 
What a disappointment all together: 
cold food, tiny portions of aforementioned food. Bull shit. 
 Since it was supposed to be a special occasion I felt very ashamed taking my guest to that place. 
Sadly, I won't be coming back. 
Big. Big turn off.
author: Ania M.

description: Thought we'd try this place out based on the outstanding Yelp reviews.  Ok it's confirmed...this place is OUTSTANDING.  We came here to celebrate and found the place very reminiscent of places we ate at during our trip to France.  Basically, it has more of a home-y French feel as opposed to fancy shmancy French.  We loved it.  We had a great duck confit appetizer dish, wife got stuffed chicken and I got the chorizo/pistachio crusted halibut.  They were delicious.  To end the night, wife got the peach pie and I got the goat cheese cake with beet ice cream - wait what?  Sounds so weird...but oh soooo good...
author: Francis S.

description: Nice little setting for couples. Good food. Attentive wait staff.  We will be back.
author: Marc D.

description:
Obviously one more reason to hate SF. This kind of crappy restaurant won't even survive in Manhattan, somehow it gets 4 stars in SF... f me...

First, the food is sooo salty. The saltiest i ever had.

Secondly, the marinated salmon on top of the porched egg is no longer offered. I only went there because i saw the pic and thought it looked delish...

Thirdly, can the waiter pretend some enthusiasm. The vibe i got the entire time was, oh no, not another asian chick customer... they seemed more enthusiastic to others... f me

Fourth, the bread was cold, the butter was frozen.

Fifth, i was asked to move a seat so a couple could sit down next to me on the left and immediately make out.  Then when ppl on my right left in next 3 mins, the couple on my left moved to my right, couple seats further... so basically, i moved so they could sit down and make out...
author: B C.

description: Lovely, intimate restaurant that is a bit of a surprise amidst its less-than-charming surroundings. The staff was very courteous and attentive. The dishes were delicious. Given the prices, this is definitely a "special occasion" joint. We went all out with appetizers, main courses, desserts and champagne, but if it wasn't a special occasion, we'd probably be much more conservative.
author: Dennis K.

description:
Had dinner here last night (my first visit to San Fran).... although having just revisited my original hometown of NYC --where I believe has the best restaurants in the world-- I was pleasantly surprised to find many restaurants of equal quality here. Although I'm not big on writing reviews, I believe that it's nice to give credit when credit's due.
Besides fantastic food, this place stood out to me, because if you had blindfolded me before I entered, I would swear that I was in a restaurant in the French countryside. Small, quaint, charming and romantic comes to mind. We ate upstairs in a loft with its' exposed beams. The servers (could well be the owners) wear street clothes, making you feel as though you're dining in their country villa. Flavors were authentic with fresh ingredients. I also appreciate the fact that the corkage charge on an expensive bottle of French wine I brought in, was waived (it was our anniversary).
When in S.F., put this one on your short list.
Robert D. Anthony
author: Robert D.

description: I've always wanted to try this little spot every time I stay in SF. I made reservations (I recommend) early for a 6:15 seating and we were ushered upstairs to our table. Upstairs is cozy with about 8 tables. Open windows, very cozy ambiance to me. We were handed a wine list and a food menu. I felt the wine was priced reasonably (I'm not familiar with French wines) and the food menu was simple and had 4 choices of each category. We started with the bacon bread. OMG! If you love fresh baked bread and bacon imagine them fused together! That was fun! We ordered a salad (we split) and the pork belly with cauliflower (another split). The confit pork belly was a bit oily to me but it is a pork belly so i believe that is normal. The salad was light and quite tasty and fresh!  Ordered petrale sole white fish (I wasn't a fan it tasted a bit slimy to me) also the wagyu top sirloin cooked to perfection! Ended with chocolate mousse with pecans. Service was excellent. When we left the downstairs counter seating was PACKED! I am glad we had a table upstairs because it is a whole other feeling from downstairs.
author: Diane A.

description:
Pros: One of the best restaurants that I have been, few tables.
Cons: Few courses on menu.
author: Rafael V.

description:
One of the main reasons I came to this restaurant was because of all this fuss over the Pork Belly dish. I sat down in their cute little rustic place one Friday evening and to my horror, didn't see Pork Belly on the menu. Apparently, their menu changes, so if you're coming here for the Pork Belly, call in ahead!

To somewhat compensate for the lack of Pork Belly, we got the Fougasse which supposedly had bits of bacon in it. No idea why everyone thinks it's the best bread ever. It just tasted like cold, dry, dusty bread and didn't even come with any olive oil! :( We also got the potato soup, salmon with egg, and roasted veal. The salmon was probably the best dish as the crunchiness at the bottom was perfect with the salmon and the yolk smeared all over it. Everything else was just okay.

Bouche's ambience is definitely a plus though. Upstairs, it's charming with the dim lighting and soft music. Good place for a date. Downstairs, it feels more like a bar so it's better for drinking with your friends.
author: Kate Y.

description: I love Bouche! My boyfriend and I went this evening and had one of the most amazing meals we have ever had! We split everything we ordered, starting with the arugula salad and squash soup. I will have dreams about that soup! For the main course we got the red snapper (which was AMAZING) as well as the crab mashed potatoes. The overall vibe of the restaurant makes you feel as if you are among friends. I highly recommend this to anyone I know!
author: Heidi K.

description: We dinned here on our anniversary and the food was amazing and the portions were perfect! I highly recomend them.
author: Laura D.

description: Excellent French restaurant hidden in SF that all should check out. The ambiance is very cool: dim lights, old world decor, dishes made out of clay (which add a different but good flavor to the exquisite food), and excellent chefs. My opening salvo consisted of a creamy chestnut soup  with buttered croutons and a hint of pork, followed by a pork dish made in three different ways on top of a potato purée with a jam of some delicious sort on the side. The wine pairing was excellent and done at the recommendation of the staff. Oh, and all of this great food was enjoyed while watching the chefs perform their magic at the bar which oversees the small kitchen! Definitely a place I will bring my lovely bride to very soon :)
author: CJ M.

description:
My wife and I arrived a half hour before our reservation, but were seated immediately. Most dining room seating is up a flight of stairs, but the atmosphere is cozy and quaint. Service was excellent. The menu is quite limited, but with a good variety of choices. Portions are ample and satisfying. The quality of the food is fresh and very tasty. 

Would definitely return for another special occasion.
author: Vic S.

description:
Came relatively early on a Monday night.  Reservations definitely needed, as it is a very small place.  It only seats about 20 people upstairs at tables, and maybe another 15 at the downstairs bar.

Ambiance is the highlight here.  Open kitchen, dim cozy room, loud chatter.

The food was also good, but was overpriced and came in small portions.  Dessert was probably the worst.  $9 for a chocolate mousse, but it was literally one spoonful of chocolate, and one spoonful of whipped cream.

Maybe folks in SF are not big eaters and are happy with paying $14 for three pieces of fish, but there are better meals to be had elsewhere.
author: Jay C.

description: Great small restaurant where the chefs cook your meal to perfection (Halibut - perfect, Chicken Stuffed with Kale - perfect, Sardine Salad - perfect.  No over serving over salting - really focused on the taste of great fresh food.  The wine list matched perfectly.  A great experience: start to finish
author: Russell Z.

description: Excellent food!  Woke up this morning wanting to go back tonight!  A must when in San Francisco.  The ambiance was cozy and our waiter was helpful and fun.  This is my first post in yelp.  Usually my husband does the posting, but it was so good I had to post this morning.
author: Margie H.

description: I've been here a few times and it's a cute an unique little restaurant (so it gets a bit crowded) with authentic french flavors. However, this is not very "traditional" french food- it's more french fusion than bistro, which I prefer. Prices are a little steep ($120 for dinner and a glass of one for 2) but it makes for a lovely date spot. The staff was attentive and helpful.
author: Brooke G.

description: My family and I recently had dinner at Bouche, a tiny, but atmospheric restaurant just above the Stockton tunnel on Geary.  The kitchen is minuscule and yet it is amazing what great food it turns out to a full restaurant, with eager patrons also waiting for tables.  The wine list was very fairly priced, very diverse, and all French.  I had a rich yet balanced veggie dish - an eggplant napoleon with butternut squash.  My father is a sweetbreads fan, and has years of 'experience' sampling various preparations of this sort of acquired taste ;)   He gave an enthusiastic thumb up to this dish.  The staff was extremely friendly about any menu questions and were at the ready to offer wine advice.  I would not hesitate to return to Bouche.  It doesn't hurt that parking is super easy at the Sutter Stockton garage, either.  Sante' :)
author: Carol O.

description:
Bouche on Bush.

Absolutely awesome.
Cute quaint place just perfect for my kind of first dates.
Food was divine - especially the polenta and lamb.
The host was really nice - he made some great suggestions.
Just keep in mind the place is really small.
Can't wait to go back.
author: Neil B.

description: Good thing I am alone this place is crowded. This far wine n cheese delicious! Looking forward to desert, where is my handsome French waiter?
author: Xiouping C.

description: Very high-end french restaurant, it was a tiny place. The food was good but not great. The wild boar has very strong flavor. A touch disappointing because of the price.
author: Mona L.

description: I love Bouche.  They always have interesting food choices and I love grabbing a book and taking in a meal with a window seat.  Seating is limited so reservations are a great idea.
author: Michelle G.

description: Absolutely charming restaurant. The peach bellini and blue berry bellini; both made from puréed fruit are both refreshing and delicious!
author: Mark W.

description: I ate there last week, and I get that it's a particularly cold SF winter. However, it was so cold in the dining area that my food got cold really fast and I wasn't able to linger over it and enjoy it. Let me assure you, I'm a fast eater in general anyway so my version of "lingering" is probably a normal person's average rate of eating. Everything was cold before I finished. It was very disappointing because the food was delicious, and I wanted to enjoy every last bit, but things aren't as good cold.   I had a pretty dress on and I couldn't take off my heavy winter coat the entire time.  I wouldn't complain, except that we paid approximately 105 each for dinner, which isn't cheap, and I expect a restaurant in that price range to shell out for some heating. They could have even put a space heater indoors.
author: Shelly H.

description: This place was an awesome find for late night dining.  The food is pretty heavy since it is French.  You definitely won't leave hungry since you will probably consume 5 sticks of butter.  nom nom.  The salmon app was good.  I believe I had monk fish cheek or something.  We also had the lamb shoulder.  Good prices on bottled wines.
author: Fatty A.

description: YUM! Chestnut soup and smoked salmon on a kunefe with creme fraiche are so delicious! I am coming back for those!
author: Patricia L.

description: Wonderful romantic tiny restaurant.  Everything was delicious. Service was attentive without being overbearing. The pork belly was amazing.
author: r h.

description: Service excellent, food sublime, a delightful dining experience!
author: Florence B.

description:
it looks like i've found my favorite french place in the city.. which i will be a regular customer.

i just loved everything about this place.. the sardine dish was heavenly. if their dessert were also as good, i would give them 5 stars. 

for entrees we had pork loin and lamb shoulder.. they were great!
author: Sung C.

description: We weren't seated until 20 min AFTER our reservation time, then finally got appetizers 45 min. We almost left, but am so glad we stayed. The food and the ambiance were incredible! Felt like we were in Paris. The staff barely speaks English. The check came in 20 seconds! Will go back again when we have time to linger.
author: Michelle L.

description: My girlfriend and I had a really nice time at Bouche. The service is great and the ambience is cozy/unassuming almost like a dive bar (unfortunately it includes the alarming smells)! The veal was one of the best I have ever had and my girlfriend really enjoyed the salmon appetizer.
author: Ms. C.

description: awesome little bistro, great decor.  the garlic soup was the best part - I would go back just for that, although the other food is tasty, too.
author: Linus W.

description:
I recently returned to Gitane and was disappointed. This was one of my favorite places to take visitors. The alley entrance has that SF vibe and the multi-story space is gorgeous.

But they have changed the menu: the portions have shrunk, the prices gave risen and the food is just OK.

I want my Gitane back.
author: JM N.

description: From the chilled corn soup starter to the salmon main course and rasberry tart dessert, everything was delicious!  The best meal that I've had in a long time.
author: Andrew W.

description: My 2nd time to Bouche and it's another great experience. Ambiance, service and, most importantly, the food could not be better. I travel often and this is one of the best French restaurants around.
author: Don I.

description:
great service
the chesnut soup is to die for!  I will come back here just for that.

Ordered the Sardines with grapefruit - fresh strong taste that you have to get accustomed to.  Also ordered the Pork Belly and Shrimp ravioli - both good with abundant olive oil. 
 
nice french place
author: Mei L.

description: I love this place. It is a must stop for me ever time I'm in SF. Amazing food and great wine list. Very comfortable bar scene too.
author: Brenna H.

description: A very tiny but cosy French restaurant. Great service but more importantly: great food. If you want to experience the European/French kitchen, do yourself a favor and visit this place...
author: Maarten D.

description: Excellent duck and arugula salad! Nice atmosphere. Wine was great, but pricey! You need reservation for this place.
author: Daniel K.

description:
I love fine dining but wanted to keep my birthday low-key this year, so Bouche was the perfect dinner spot for my bf and me.

The restaurant is tiny and the few non-bar tables are cramped together (I literally had my chest on the table because I had to scoot my chair all the way in for the bigger man sitting behind me), but the whole space is very romantic and European.

Service was polite but a bit slow as there were only 1 or 2 waitresses servicing the entire lofted area and they had to climb up and down the stairs from the kitchen.

We shared the fougasse (bacon bread), lamb shoulder, and roasted pork belly + confit pork shoulder.  Honestly I couldn't even really see what I was eating because it was so dark at our table, but if you like lamb or pork then you'll like those dishes.  The bread was not as amazing as it sounds but good for filling up.

Overall a great place for a quality, intimate French dinner.
author: S L.

description:
thank you bouche and the great staff . 
really impressed by the decor and atmosphere . 
the menu shows the talent of the chef and his team .
the price are amazing as well 
overall the best new restaurant in sf now !!!
author: germain m.

description: Rich flavors. If you end up downstairs it's elbow to elbow. I like the short menu approach. We had the Veal and Steelhead. Preferred the Veal. The Steelhead was surprisingly raw (would've been good to know that ahead of time).
author: Nelson C.

description: One of the most intimate, delicious, and elegant dates of my life. Went with a new friend, now boyfriend almost a year ago, and this was our best dinner to date. We both got a stuffed chicken dish with potatoes. Perfect portions, great wine, lovely ambiance and lighting with the bar side seating. He definitely sold me with this choice :D
author: Carrie H.

description:
A very cool and charming restaurant but the food was a bit disappointing.  I probably ordered wrong.  

The sardines were too fishy for me.  I ate less than a 1/4 but the waiter didn't inquire if anything was wrong and just took away my plate after asking me if I was done.  The roasted pork belly and confit pork shoulder were decent but I've had better.  Don't know how to pinpoint it but the roasted pork belly lacked flavor.  

While the food could be better, I did enjoy the overall experience.
author: Keith S.

description:
I came here randomly with by boyfriend on Saturday, the experience was really good! We order the tuna with grape fruit.. as an appetizer. 
My boyfriend order the seabass, and I had the salmon for main course. Everything was amazing!
Def. come back to try other items on the menu. 
Environment: small, cozy. Super nice and helpful staff.
author: Hien P.

description: I tried this place last night for the first time and it was beyond amazing! From the delicious cheese selection, to the lamb shoulder, monkfish, salmon down to to the grapefruit/pear tart and wine, it was nothing short of perfect!!
author: Meher S.

description: Tiny restaurant, but I feel like it only adds to it's charm. I came here on a first date and I think it was an awesome choice (made by him). We had a scallop carpaccio starter and it was delicious!  I got the steelhead for my main course and loved it.  My only complaint is that they don't serve you bread unless you ask for it and we totally forgot.  So ask for the bread! It looked really good.
author: Julie T.

description:
