Small space, dimmed lights, open kitchen, moderate noise level...the decor reminded me of walking into a mix between Anthropologie & Urban Outfitters. I would think it would be a great experience especially since I was sharing it with my girlfriends, but Bouche fell short of the 'great' aspect of that experience. 

I came here last night with my 3 GFs for our annual Christmas gift exchange. No need for reservations which was nice and, where we were seated (upstairs), made for a more private setting for us. We wanted to sit at a table by the window because we didn't want to be crowded up next to another table of 3; unfortunately, the host told us to move to the table next to the table of 3 because he wanted to save those tables for couples who were going to come in later that night. Needless to say, my friends and I struggled to be comfortable at the table we were at, the guy next to us wouldn't move his chair because he thought he needed all the space for his skinny tush and what really topped off my sundae was the fact that no other couples or groups of people came in. The only thing that saved dinner was the dessert; these delectable items need to be recognized! We ordered the Milk Chocolate & Caramelized Hazelnut ($7) & Creme Fraiche Custard ($7) and both were a hit! 

Overall: Food was pricey, portions were small (we went back down to Westfield to munch on a large order of fries and had large tapioca drinks afterwards), food was barely lukewarm upon arrival to the table, dessert was great, service was average.
author: Carol L.

description: Unbelievable food. Don't miss the green garlic soup.
author: A Z.

description: Totally delicious - make sure you get the salmon and eggs! Lamb was also amazing.
author: Jay W.

description: Excellent french fare. The appetizers like the smoked salmon was top notch. Followed that up with some lamb and steelhead which was you melt in your mouth goodness. We ordered a side of polenta which was lapped up in seconds.. The perils of  going to a french restaurant I tell ya !
author: Nihal S.

description: Bouche, is authentic.  Great French food, a wonderful staff, and charming decor (I love the Pig Weather Vane on the bar.  This was my second awesome meal here and I'm already planning another.
author: Nicolas T.

description:
Bouche is a very small restaurant near Union Square and very easy to find. 
I went on a Monday for a 8:30pm reservation and street parking was plentiful.
The place is tiny but intimate and well managed. I would make a reservation at least by the morning of, since the less than 20 tables makes walk-ins difficult. 
You can see the kitchen from the first or second floor seating areas.
Bouche had the best salmon dish I think I've ever had in my entire life. The salmon on poached egg dish was absolutely phenomenal. The food portions were good for the price. This place isn't crazy expensive which is great so you can drink and get dessert too. The service was very good as well. All the waiters seem like Frenchmen who could speak French at any moment. They were courteous and quick. I just can't wait to come back and get exactly what I got the first time. This will always be my go to dinner spot just for that amazing salmon dish.
author: Helen J.

description: What a lovely little spot, with a lovely owner, with lovely food.  One of those intimate SF gems.  Make a reservation for a table upstairs and enjoy what makes San Francisco, San Francisco.  Nice restaurants in SF aren't about being fancy and putting on a tie, they are about damn good food at affordable prices executed in a 4 star manner.  I felt what I had was very good, but that the kitchen perhaps still needs a bit of work, but they aren't far off.  And with a caring owner holding the reigns, I am sure they will get there if they haven't already.  I wish them the best.
author: D B.

description:
Slooo o oo o               o    o            w ... ... zzz ..     ...

The food here is good, 4 stars good. Portions are very small though. I was still hungry when I left and I am a tiny person!
Incredibly noisy, maybe because we were seated next to a large group of drunk women.
The main problem is that it took about an hour between appetizers and entrees, and since we didn't get any bread, that was a painfully long wait when you are hungry.
Service was friendly and attentive.

Would I come back? Probably not.
author: Maggie X.

description: We had a great time at Bouche and will return on our next SF visit.  The service was attentive and the food was delicious.  We were 30 minutes late for our reservations (one in our party went to a wrong address), but we were accommodated when we finally all got there.  We ordered way too much food, but it was lovely.  The best part for me was the fig ice cream they make from freshly harvested figs.  I had never seen it on any menu before and it was just to die for.  It was not overly sweet and you could really taste the fig.
author: Sophie M.

description: Excellent French food, friendly staff and very intimate setting. Their kitchen stays open later than other restaurants around. The wine suggestion by the serving staff was really good.
author: Henry D.

description: I've been to this restaurant twice, with two different people.  Both times it was great.  The food is very nicely presented and the staff is very friendly and fun.  A wonderful choice for a dinner date.
author: Nitzan M.

description: These guys can cook!  Especially given the super tiny area they call a kitchen.  Modernized french cuisine with a light hand.  Food is top notch but the place didn't have any air-conditioning the night I went and the place was hot hot hot... didn't put me in a good mood for dinner but the food surprised and changed my mind.
author: Dennis Y.

description: A very good little small plate French restaurant. The lamb was amazing. Everything was good, and the style of food  was sort of rustic French. Not heavy on sauces, but big on flavor and ingredients, well balanced. Service was good.
author: Chris B.

description: This is an awesome quaint restaurant and bar.  We visited Guillaume, handsome and friendly, restaurant owner who greeted us at the bar, took our drink order, and then escorted us upstairs to our table. The ambience is delightful with homemade pottery, fashionable lighting, and great soft friendly colors. The chef and wait staff are as friendly and prompt. I felt as if I was in a gourmet restaurant and visiting and eating in the south of France at the same time. I will definitely go back for the sea bass, pork loin, beef cheeks, and chestnut soup. The dessert was delicious!  And presentation of all was fantastic. A five star restaurant so close to SF's attractions including Union Square and Chinatown.
author: T D.

description: Excellent Food!  Authentic French.  Servers spoke French too.  Restaurant is a little cramped, but ambiance is cozy.  Not too noisy but not too quiet either.  Pricing was very good for this level of food.
author: Kristine W.

description: We had a wonderful dinner at Bouche, after a busy evening of holiday shopping. I made reservations for four but my sons surprised us and we asked to bump it up to six. Despite being very busy, they squeezed us all in and were very welcoming. When you enter the restaurant, you are in a busy bar area; however, the upstairs is a cozy, charming dining room. We all enjoyed the food: we ordered the butternut squash soup and spinach salad to start - both were delicious, fresh and flavorful. And the bacon bread was tasty. For entrees, we had the swordfish, pork and hanger steak - all were perfectly prepared with good flavor. The pork was very different - thinly cut yet very moist and tasty but if you want a big juicy, slab of pork this is not it. Loved the marinated hanger steak - great flavor! And the swordfish was perfectly prepared. For dessert, we had the pear pie and cheese plate. The pear was outstanding! The service was excellent and the wine recommendations were perfect. We will be back!
author: Laurine G.

description: Absolutely incredible. Amazing wine selection, and the food was unbelivable. Would suggest this place for any occasion, can't go wrong.
author: Jonathan H.

description: What a great little place. Our waiter was very warm, the ambiance quaint and our dishes were very good. The polenta was honestly amazing (it is mixed with some sort of cheese). The Red Wine Beef Cheek Stew was tender and paired with a wonderful sauce. We will be back - was a great night out.
author: Brooke S.

description: Charming french guys everywhere.  Darling loft dining area where typical americans will feel squashed and claustrophobic.  I had trouble deciphering the menu,  e.g. egg salad is a green salad with a poached egg on top (well, I should have known that) but the desserts were totally under described.  Pork was the best main dish on the menu.   The bread with bacon was the most oversold.  Cold bread with congealed bacon bits do not appeal.
author: Poppy C.

description: Superbe. Fantastique. As a native San Franciscan I've enjoyed a lifetime of well conceived, well prepared, outstanding food--and Bouche served some of the best dishes I've had in a long time. The Duck Confit Croquants may be the best starter I've eaten-- it is a wholesome portion, and delicious. The Pork Chop entree is cooked perfectly, lovely flavors, also a satisfying portion. We expected dessert to just be the usual, nothing special -- pot de creme with fleur de sel and a chocolate mousse-- but the quality, textures, flavors were sublime. The fact that they're open until one am is great, especially if you're going to a show, concert, or drinks beforehand.
author: Emily S.

description:
I went here with a friend for dinner on a weekday evening. We were seated at the bar. The ambiance is pretty nice, rustic in a trendy kind of way. The place is tiny though, so I probably wouldnt come with a larger group and without a reservation. 

The food was honestly mediocre. I really wanted to like this place after hearing such great things about it (all the reviews below and it got written up in SF eater). My friend and I got the bacon studded bread (Fougasse?) and the cheese plate to start. The bacon studded bread was ok. It was pretty heavy on the salt, and overall it tasted like a dense, kinda doughy roll with a random bit of bacon every now and then. The cheese plate was good, but that being said, its a cheese plate. 

I ordered the monkfish tail, which came with a small side of fried shallots and roasted leeks. The fish was cooked well, but overall the dish was disappointing: the fish was bland and too oily as were the "roasted" leeks. My friend got the marinated salmon with a poached egg, which was also just OK. It came in a giant nest of some sort of fried crispy 

Maybe my expectations were too high, but I think that restaurants like this serve up a lot of pretension without following through. Particularly if portions are haute-cuisine sized (read: not very big), then I think it isn't unreasonable to expect interesting, flavorful dishes rather than mediocre flavor combination that rely on nice ingredients and fancy names.
author: E V.

description: My friend had the lamb and said it was the best meal he had during our week in San Francisco.  My wife had the sardine and grapefruit salad.  The sardines were large and firm; very impressive to a guy from the Midwest.  If they have the lemon tart, order it.  It will be the best thing you ever put into your mouth!
author: Lee B.

description:
"Did you microwave my food?"

"No, this sticky shit on top is because of the butter."

Butter? In a pan sauce? so unusual! :P Any chef that will look that, will laugh like crazy! Thank you, i enjoy that! :-)

Also, is good some times to wear a hat, right?
author: Dimitris P.

description:
Wow! I could almost leave it at that; that good!  My wife and I sat at the bar (as we often prefer for real exposure to the staff and crowd watching!) and worked our way through 6 dishes (all small plate style). Guilliame paired our food with a lovely rose' followed by a crisp semillon blend. Perfect.  Each dish, from the open salvo of Brown Butter Carrots to the seared calimari with mushrooms, was better than the last!  Fantastic progression of flavors. 

Simply put, an amazing addition to the tastes of our fair city!


Btw, reviewers complaints on portion size; Who couldn't grasp small plates concept from the "bouche" as in "amuse- bouche"???  Really?
author: Cr G.

description: I was in town for work and got together with my friends at this very comfy casual french homestyle restaurant. The ambience is great, the lighting exactly as I like it, dimly lit yellow with dark grey shadows. The barn wood tables added to the elegance of the country farm decor. The food was extremely limited however the offerings were amazing and there was not one thing to be disliked. Catered toward meat eaters but for pescetarians there is a fish and many fabulous veggies and polenta. I'd go back!
author: Monika S.

description: The service are great, the inside is good. But the green bean is not cooked well. I and my friend are bean positing.
author: Ping W.

description: Tasty well seasoned food.....great ambiance.......friendly prompt service......price point spot on.......need I say more?
author: David S.

description: Bouche did make us feel like we were in France. The food was good, but a little bit on a heavy side considering that it was very hot up there on the 2nd floor. The lighting was very dim, space small but cozy. The menu was not big, about 5 main dishes, which to me is an indication of good and fresh food. Wine list was very good, but pricy. The flair was definitely French: we were served by French servers with polite but very reserved attitude.
author: Dubravka M.

description: So planned in advance for my birthday dinner here, after reading how it such an amazing authentic french bistro I couldn't wait for my steak tartare or at least steak frites. No they offer non of the real authentic french bistro cuisine herre, not even french fries! They have chick pea breaded fries? Disgusting and dry. So for my starter I ordered the lamp crepes, dry and tasteless. Main course the steak, but it came with some sort of corn succotash, yuck. And I could barely find the one scalloped potatoe in the meal. From there we left. Truly disappointing , on top of it service is extremely slow - don't be fooled by the great decor!
author: Jill S.

description: Excellent!!!  What a great restaurant. All of our food from appetizers to desert was fantastic.  We had the cheese appetizer, wine, the brussel sprouts, duck, flat iron steak, cream fraiche and tart of the day.  To us the stand outs were the bread ( truly authentic), the wine ( recommended by our waiter after hearing our preferences), the brussel sprouts, the steak, and the cream fraiche.  Our waiter was knowledgeable and helpful, engaging without being too pushy.  All of the food was excellent and satisfied our French cravings and with a true French waiter and small cozy setting we felt we were transported out of San Fran and over to France itself.  We recommend this restaurant to anyone traveling to the area because of the wonderful food, service,  and atmoshphere and we will absolutely go back again.
author: Karla C.

description: I've been here four times over the past few months, and for good reason. The upstairs dining room is tiny and dark and cozy, which is a great atmosphere for dining and catching up with a friend or two. Particularly if you and your friends are short and slim, since the ceiling is low and the chairs are petite. The food is simple and delicious California French (fresh ingredients without the heavy sauces associated with French fare). The service is good (not overly friendly or chatty, but definitely customer-oriented). The bar area is nice, though small and fills up quickly. Prices are decent for the quality of food.
author: Kely G.

description: Food is pretty good, so is the ambiance, but come on, what's with the attitude? I am French and I can easily take pissy staff... The hostess there should not work in the service industry. Customers are only looking for French quality food, not basic French-like service.
author: Davy C.

description:
Excellent food and convenient location. The only reason for the 3 vs 5 stars -

1. Wine list includes no California wines. French is great, I concede, but really? Not even one local wine! That means no decent value and little familiarity for the average customer

2. Prices are high for what you get.

3. Small and low ceiling. This is a great place for a date, but think again if you are a dining party larger than 4.

The couple next to us was French, for what it is worth, so this is authentic Nouveau French. Just know you need to bring more $ than you would think for a "moderately priced" restaurant.

Also, are the owners of this building Yelpers? This is the 2nd restaurant in three years at this address to come highly yelped at the same price point :) The last one was Bar Crudo, which was also, I admit very good. it was a little pricey too.
author: Alex S.

description: Lamb with honey and walnut glaze w a side of carrot foam , ridic juicy. Falls apart in your mouth,the meat is that damn tender!
author: Jimmy M.

description: Read reviews on yelp and decided to try this place. But after actually trying it for myself I would give it zero stars if I could. Horrible food, horrible service. To keep it simple...shit on a plate sold by a French dude with bad service.
author: R S.

description: If you're into French food, you will probably love this place. The atmosphere was totally swanky and romantic... but it smelled like canned cat food. The menu was very limited so we ordered a salad and a cheese plate. I think the waitress was quite annoyed with us. However, with what little we ordered it was still pricey. The wine was delicious but not worth the overall experience. Unless you are a fan of unique, smelly French food, I would definitely dine at one of the many other great restaurants San Francisco has to offer.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Deliberate but not overbearing ambiance, good service (we were at the bar), creative and delicate dishes. A few of the starters were a bit uninteresting despite sounding more so, but the creamy rice with roasted artichoke hit the bullseye for us all. 

The wine selection was a bit light but we came up with a Cote de Roussillon crowd pleaser for about $45. The dessert we split, blueberry tart with Grand Marinier creme, was quite good, not a knockout but at least not over sugary. Overall, definitely a place I'd recommend and return to. Reservations recommend if you don't like sitting at the bar.

Note: The southern French boys running the place have a certain southern French charm reserved for the fairer gender.
author: Emptor D.

description: Anniversary trip to Frisco. Was in the mood for some fine French Cuisine. We found it.  Very small and intimate dining area upstairs with a nice view of the city street below.  Only about 3 people working at a time, so service can be a little slow. However, the food and the wine were excellent. The waiter has some good recommendations if, like us, you are unfamiliar with French wine.   Do make reservations due to the limited amount of dining space. Dress is casual.
author: Aaron K.

description: Wonderful dinner in the cozy upstairs dining room.  Arugula salad was divine- one of the best salads ever!!   Main courses were strong and goat cheesecake was interesting.
author: Bill U.

description: This place is amazing! This is an intimate place, so if you want a quiet booth in the corner, it's not for you. If you do want amazing cuisine served with an amazingly priced wine list served by great wait staff, then make this your next date destination. I'm still dreaming about the Pork Confit and Pork Belly dish. Chef Borzee has made this menu my destination every time I travel to SF. Make a reservation as the word is getting out. There is no shortage of amazing places in SF and this shot straight to the top of my favorites list. Whatever it is they were trying to do, they nailed it.
author: T C.

description: I had a great time visiting the city. Bouch has an amazing new menu !  Great wait staff and they are open late for dinner. You got to try the PORK BELLY appetizer it's insanely good.
author: Aaron M.

description: This place is really small.  I would recommend sitting at the bar and watching the chef cook.  The food preparation area is so narrow and small and it's art to see the 2 chefs maneuver back there.  The food is excellent as well.
author: T. C.

description: Excellent restaurant! One of the best I've been to in a while. The place is cute. It's a wine bar downstairs and a restaurant upstairs. The restaurant area is tiny so it's not good for big groups but great for a date. It's rustic and charming. The food was absolutely amazing! I ordered the fish and my friend ordered the lamb. Both were beyond words so incredible. We also ordered the seasonal greens which that day were brussels sprouts, and who knew brussels sprouts could be so delicious, we loved them. Can't say enough good things about this place.
author: Efrat S.

description:
Space is crowded and dark enough that we had a hard time seeing what we were eating.
Food was acceptable. I had the garlic soup (actually the best thing we tasted) and the pork which was moist but otherwise uninteresting. My partner had the calamari (too much citrus) and the halibut (tolerable but nothing to rave about). 
Bead was totally ordinary although the butter was good. 
We had mid-range wines by the glass and they were OK too. 
Dessert was a rum cake with pistachio nut butter and apricots. Also had some herbs on it. The cake was good but there was too much other stuff.
So overall, just OK. Glad I tried it- I'm French and I'm always on the look-out for good French places- it but wouldn't go back.
author: Francoise F.

description: Sit at the window and hearing the staff and ambiance you would think you're in France except the Chinese laundry I was looking at across the street.  Late night is when I went and i was enamored with my dishes I picked.  First was the Duck Confit Croquants, Japanese and Watermelon Radishes, Cherry Sauce, I equate them to falafal balls filled with duck confit nirvana.  Probably not doing it justice but that was my first impression when it came to my table.  The radish with the cherry sauce was an excellent combination with the Croquants.  Next was the Grilled Lamb Loin, Summer Squash and Harricot Vert Salad, Tomato and Mint Relish, Black Olive Vinaigrette.  A summer non-guilt dish with a base of cool temperature fresh vegetables with the Lamb Loin comfortably warm on top.  I would order the same again without hesitation.  The wines are all french so I had the waiter suggest, great choices!
author: Toby N.

description: Loved this place. The atmosphere is quaint and intimate, the food was incredible, and the service was quick and friendly. A very romantic spot to bring a date. Table reservations are upstairs overlooking the kitchen and the street below, there are maybe 10 tables total, so it's not too boisterous and maintains the french bistro feeling. We had the duck confit appetizer, the lamb, the sole, and the goat cheese cake, all amazing. Highly recommend!
author: Abigail L.

description:
- great food
- great price
-authentic French
-excellent wine selection
-very friendly service
-open till late
author: Nick S.

description: Top notch service. Nice small main and desert menu selection. Good wine (and beer) selection. Cool upstairs dining. Very small so be sure to make reservations.
author: G. B.

description:
this was one of the best restaurants I've ever been. it is what we are all looking for: small, magically comforting and romantic in a simple, down to earth way, exceptional, charismatic and warm service by the stylish young french staff, and the food was transporting, creative, and delicious. 

we sat upstairs by the charming window. we had mushrooms with apple sauce, a salad with a pickled egg as the dressing, and perfect scallops. from beginning to end, it was a beautiful, special experience.

take a first date here. or someone you love.
author: frank s.

description: This is a wonderfully cozy and rustic french place that is very well executed.  From the wood tables to the small kitchen... it is clearly a gem in SF.  Get the lamb, halibut, and octopus.  homemade orange/chestnut tart is glorious as well.
author: Twin C.

description: Was finally able to stop in for a late dinner after hearing some great things about this tiny spot. Have eaten meals from every incarnation of this location and will say, hands down, the best of them all. Went w/ the green garlic soup, smoked salmon and sous vide lamb. Every dish was well balanced and full of flavor.  Was very impressed w/ the preparation and technique delivered from such a small kitchen, (the Chef was the only person working at the time). I didn't want to eat so fast but couldn't help myself, would have been a crime to let the dishes sit and temp.
author: I D.

description: We were so glad Yelp steered us to Bouche! Charming ambiance (wall moldings decoupaged with vintage newspapers a cute touch)! Good service - we had everything we wanted at all times (there seemed to be a tag team of friendly Frenchmen serving us, but it worked well). Good selection of wines, and our server had the requisite knowledge to suggest excellent pairings. The menu is not large, but is varied enough to offer something to suit most tastes - except maybe vegan. For starters my husband and I shared the exceptionally tasty salad of wild greens, Roquefort and poached egg. Not sure what about it was surprising, but somehow it was. In a good way. After that husband had something he enthusiastically praised involving lamb, but I was so absorbed with my eggplant Napoleon at that point, I wasn't paying that much attention. Really nice balance of flavors. This sort of dish can be so easily ruined - boring, or greasy, or any number of other flaws, all of which this chef adroitly avoided. Super yummy. We should have tried a dessert. Maybe next time!
author: amanda m.

description: Bouche is the delightful small French Bistro located at 603 Bush/Stockton. The small place used to house Bar Crudo/Swell has now been spruced up a bit with dim lighting and barn tables which adds to the rustic and intimate ambiance. The limited menu is centered on small plates and it is well executed French-Californian Seasonal fare by Nicolas Borzee (COI and Le Louis XV in Monaco).  We shared the green garlic soup, the sautéed calamaris, which were citrusy/light and crispy as well as the duck confit with beets and walnuts. For mains, the house marinated salmon/poached /crème fresh goodness is a must try and the lamb shoulder was cooked perfectly. The service is friendly and they offer a good selection of wine and beer as well as unique deserts.  They're open for dinner Monday- Saturday from 5:30p.m. till 1a.m. check them out!
author: Sofie Z.

description:
What a beautiful small and cozy restaurant. It feels very hip and European and the food and service were outstanding. My dining partner and I both had the lamb shoulder and it was heavenly! Our server suggested the creme fraiche custard for dessert and it was amazing, too: a delicious balance of sweet, salty and creamy. Accompanied by a glass of the Baron de Seillac brut rosé, dinner was sublime.
I will definitely be back since Bouche is also in my neighborhood.
author: Jane C.

description: Went for husband's birthday, as noted on reservation. Ordered two glasses of champagne, only one arrived. We shared the cheese special, which was one slice of cheese, some walnuts, raisins and bread. A little pricey at $10. Ordered wine, which was corked. The waiter quickly replaced it, but couldn't he have detected the strong musty smell before he served it? Lovely salad with greens, pear and walnuts and poached egg dressing. Petrale sole was delicious, as others have agreed, though the carrot puree and lobster sauce were very sweet. Great goat cheesecake, but the beet ice cream was a little strange. Usually when a birthday is noted, at least a candle is stuck in the dessert, but not here. As we left, the hostess wished my husband a happy birthday. Yes, it's quaint and charming, but not as special as we expected.
author: Anne G.

description: Cute little French bistro off of Union Square! Everyone that works there is French. The food is amazing, service is great! Takes a little while for food to come up (from downstairs) after ordering.
author: L W.

description: I love this environment, so romantic for a small cozy place. the food is excellent but you have to have a lot of time to seat there over an hour for the food ready. way toooooooooo SLOW. but the food is great. i don't find myself to come back if they are this slow again.
author: Travis T.

description: I love the food here. The wait still takes time even if you have reservations. The staff is not as welcoming and smiley until you sit down. They are pretty reserved. I have been here 3 times by now and will come back for the food.
author: Tatyana D.

description: We had a great dinner last week.  This is an excellent romantic get-a-way.  The food was excellent, the service outstanding and the wine recommendations were perfect.  We had great conversations with others nearby and will go back when in the area again.  Thanks for a great evening.
author: Keeley K.

description:
I've never written a Yelp review before but was blown away by this restaurant and wanted to share my experience. 
This place is just GREAT!!!!!! The owner did a really good job remodeling. Amazing place to bring a date, so romantic...
The food is delectable, especially the lamb. The chestnut soup and the salmon were delicious...everything is good to share.
Most of the wine is French and varies in price range. I would definitely go back for dinner or just to grab a drink and apps.
author: Ben Z.

description: Woohooo it was good. I had a juiciest red snapper ever and my husband enjoyed the best lamb shank. Definitely delicious food.
author: Sadbera R.

description: Food was great. Service was als. I didn't realize how small it was. It definitely felt like we were on top of the other diners (or the other way around maybe). However, our server was very gracious and had great recommendations.
author: Marilyn S.

description: We walked in last night and sat in the bar. Charming staff, great wine, delicious food. We ordered 2 apps (sweetbreads and scallop-- both terrific) and dessert. The goat cheesecake had the most perfectly creamy texture and the beet ice cream was earthy and unusual without being weird. Wish we lived in the city so we could come here more often. Highly recommend.
author: Laura H.

description: Nice and cozy place, tasty food, excellent selection of French wines. However, it is a very small restaurant and making reservation is a must, if you want to have a table
author: Alex L.

description: The food and atmosphere here were fantastic.  My wife and I loved the food, the service, and ambience at this restaurant.  They're very friendly and helpful, and we had a great time.
author: Raza A.

description: My boyfriend and I went here prior to a show in SF - we were looking for a fancy, romantic dinner spot near the theater. The service has a slightly pretentious feel and was a little slower than we'd hoped (we barely made it to the show on time), but the food was excellent. In order of increasing deliciousness: cheese plate (yummy but nothing special), squash cannelloni (rich, unusual flavor mix with cauliflower and horseradish), and the lamb shoulder (incredibly tender and flavorful). It was also the perfect fancy date spot - there are only ~8 tables upstairs, and the candles, french accents, and quiet atmosphere make for a romantic, cozy scene.
author: Emily H.

description: A great space and delicious food. It is very quaint with maybe only 1 4-top. The food took a while to come out, but the conversation was nice and the waiter brought us some fougasse to pass the time. Duck confit and pork loin were both very good.
author: H P.

description:
I had heard so many positive things about Bouche, so i was really excited when i finally had the chance to eat here. all i can say is, i want to like it, the potential is definitely there. our meal started off with the wine list. the list only has the name of the wine, so we asked the server if he could explain the wines, as in what type of grape, if its dry, sweet, acidic, etc. his response? "these are the red, these are the white, and these are the bubbles." well duh. it says that on the menu. when asked to get into a little more detail, he seemed to get a little flustered, so we told him our specific preferences and crossed our fingers. the wine was good, but i still don't even know what exactly i drank. 
on to the food: while the presentation was well presented, i felt the flavors were really unmemorable. we had the beef carpaccio to start, we felt the meat tasted like it was either sitting out in the pick up window too long, or was just old.(keep in mind, at the time the restaurant was only about half full)  we also had the sardines, probably the best dish of the night, but i couldn't tell you what the set was. i know there was some grapefruit segments, that's what i can remember. for our entrees, we had the salmon (raw dish) with a poached egg and i think it was halibut or bass dish? i honestly can't remember. both dishes were just 'meh' to us. once again, i felt like the food was in the window too long, unless it was supposed to be warm, not hot. 
towards the end of our meal, a couple sits next to us (we were upstairs with open windows, the space is small and it was a hot day, so the breeze made it just right), and the woman in the party closes all the windows, without even asking. woman, it's a beautiful warm sunny day in san francisco, and you want it to be stuffy?? apparently so. when i turned to the table, i politely said that my partner and i actually enjoyed the cool breeze the open window was offering, and asked if i could just crack the window closest to us for some fresh air. the woman, looking stunned, paused, looked at her partner, shrugged, and said "i guess so." immediately, the man went up to the server and asked to change tables. if you wanted a warm seat, you should have stayed away from the window! now you have made the upstairs 7 table dining room stuffy and sweaty. with such an underwhelming experience, the cherry on top was really the obvious inconsideration of this couple who didn't even have the decency to ask the neighboring tables if they could close ALL of the windows.
my partner and i paid the bill, still a little hungry, a little annoyed, and thinking we could have gone to claudine for a more fulfilling, cheaper dinner.
author: Rebecca Q.

description: Fantastic food, nice ambiance, friendly staff.  Can't wait to go back.  Merci.
author: Marc L.

description: This restaurant is THE BEST FIND in a long time. What exquisite food and charming atmosphere. I was rendered almost speechless at how divine the food was. I was amazed that there was no sauce/dressing on the sardines I ordered as the dish was so incredibly flavorful. The fish must've jumped directly onto the plate. The lamb was a perfect and new combination of flavors - a beautiful blend of sweet and savory. I don't know what they did to that sunchoke soup but it too was simply incredible. I can't wait to return. We also loved how unpretentious this place was. And cozy.
author: Audrey W.

description: Bouche is absolutely amazing! The decor is unique, rustic, and beautiful - even down to the plates. The food was art - beautifully presented and delicious. I especially loved the carrots, chestnut soup, and salmon. We tried 3 desserts - all were full of flavor and left my mouth watering. The wine selection was super yummy  - I usually don't care for wine, but had two glasses of the red that our waiter suggested. I love that there is an open kitchen and you can watch the chef artfully prepare the food. The low lighting sets a romantic mood. Our service was perfect. I went with a group of four and we shared each plate, which was a great way to try so many delectable menu items. I've already been to Bouche twice and I will definitely be visiting again!
author: Katy D.

description: great food, open till late night, good ambiance.
author: Paiyu G.

description: Our food was good, but the weather inside the restaurant was unbearable. It would go from 90 degrees and then they would open the door in November. I broke out in a sweat a couple of times.
author: Lindsey H.

description: The menu is small, but the food is inventive and delicious.  Bouche is small, and I would say intimate.  Upstairs is nice, with windows overlooking the street.  Nice antique bulbs in the wall sconces and in general a nifty "squatting in a building where time stopped in 1905" kind of look.
author: Joris M.

description: Great staff, outstanding wine and fare. Wonderful French style interior.
author: David E.

description: Great dinner, great wine. 4 stars instead of 5 because the plates are a little small for a dinner entree and because we had made a reservation for a table but ended up sitting at the bar a half hour after our reservation time because they book spots very close together and the people at our table stayed longer than they had budgeted. But the staff was great, very knowledgeable about the wine and very apologetic about the table (it actually didn't bother us much at all). Overall a very nice dinner.
author: Alice A.

description: Great food. It makes you feel like you are back in Paris. The seating area is small and the menu is limited - but the food is great. They did not have a green salad on the menu - but when I asked for one they created it just for me. Service was excellent. The cheese plate was original and delicious and the pork was full of flavor and melted in your mouth. We will definitely go back.
author: Gail P.

description: I've now enjoyed two dinners at Bouche, both amazing. You feel like you've stepped into Paris, wonderful lighting, a unique and charming space. Both from the bar and upper dining area you can see the open kitchen, which is great fun. The staff is knowledgeable and friendly -- and very French. And the food is sublime. I especially recommend the chestnut soup (wonderfully rich, and it comes with delicious little vegetable crisps) and the red wine beef cheek stew (so delicate and tender!). If you request the (free) bread, you won't be disappointed, it's fresh baked. The wines are also a treat, though the pours are on the short side. I'll definitely be going back -- I'm always looking for a new favorite spot in the city, and Bouche has become one!
author: E D.

description: Made reservations for 8, arrived on time and still had to wait a half hour because they did not hold a table. Server was alright but not very personable. Food is where it kills me, how do people rate this high? Confit croquants were dry and had the weirdest ingredients that would have masked any subtle duck flavors(horseradish like flavor for one). Tartar could have been more nicely balanced with salt, mush less basil and with something other than partially soggy plantain chips...and that was the my favorite. Why would a french restaurant take it upon themselves to change a classic tartar recipe, which works, to an Italian failure with basil and parmigiano? The lamb dish was where it fell flat, they marinated the shank and then cooked it for 6 hours? It was hard to tell this was lamb vs dry stew beef. The plate was ugly and quite small, french is supposed to be complex yet simple in the preparation used. Getting the most out of the technique vs the amount of ingredients, these guys seem to be serving up poor contemporary American with a french wine list. I should have stayed in, my french cooking is worlds above theirs...maybe I should open a restaurant.
author: Michael W.

description: Food was excellent.  Loved the atmosphere. Has the rustic French look in decor and it is tight and small so it has the crowded feel but in a good way. I will be telling people to go here. Both fish and lamb shoulder were cooked to a very nice tenderness and paired well with the recommended wine. Loved it!
author: Tasha O.

description: What a little gem. Perfect for a casual dinner with great food, ambiance, service, and wine. Yes I can see how people say the portions are small, but don't expect bigger at a French restaurant. This is pretty standard. We had the soup, calamari (tangy and tender), white fish, and poached salmon (absolute favorite). We had the hazelnut dessert which was amazing. You can tell the owner cares about your experience. And that's all that truly matters--besides the food. We've had a few great experiences here and I'm sure we'll be back.
author: Rana K.

description: Tiny little place on Bush Street above the Stockton tunnel.  Great pork belly and lamb shoulder. The side of polenta was delicious and the cheese plate was only lacking some sort of toast or cracker to eat it with.  We loved the custard dessert and left full and content.  The staff was very friendly and attentive.  Lovely atmosphere felt like we were in an intimate European restaurant.  About 8 small tables upstairs.  Unisex bathroom is off the dishwashing station.
author: Nancy H.

description: I love this place! Feels more like Paris than any other French restaurant in the city. The prices are reasonable and the food is delish as were the red wines we had - such delicious red wines! We had to wait a while for our table in the cramped bustling downstairs, but our wine and the atmosphere made the time pass pleasantly. We had the corn soup and mushrooms for appetizers - both were good, although the corn soup is quite sweet, prob not the best choice if you are in a savoury mood. Then we had the pork belly and the salmon. I especially loved the pork belly, and I enjoyed the salmon as well even though I am not usually a fan of smoked salmon. At the end of the night we noticed that they forgot to charge us for our wines downstairs and when we informed the staff, the manager thanked us for our honesty and said it was on the house! To top it all off, the staff were very hardworking and friendly, and I also enjoyed the music they had playing in the restaurant. I'm leaving Sf soon, and I'm so sad I didn't discover this place until now. I will try to go several more times before I leave!
author: Anji C.

description: Finally!! A sophisticated restaurant open past 9p in the city!  In fact, they serve until 1 am.  The vibe at this place is warm and inviting, the food is superbly prepared in the tiniest of kitchens. We love marveling at the chefs' execution almost as much as eating their offerings. The owner and servers are knowledgeable about the Alsacian cuisine and the creativity in every dish is impressive.  Ignore previous paid reviewers who criticized the over ambitious combinations of favors. That is actually the genius of the fare here.  There is nothing to lose in trying this reasonably priced, inventive and just plain fabulous place!
author: Neira F.

description: Excellent, same tiny vibe as Bar Crudo, and I love the food. The size is what makes its charm. Good wine selection. Go for the duck.
author: sinclair w.

description: Great little place with excellent food and service. Came her by accident and did not regret it. We love french food and this place did not disappoint. Great place for a romantic dinner and good food. Do not miss it!
author: Vacation Addicted G.

description: Tiny piece of heaven. Loved every dish, and that of my friend's plate. Will definitely be back.
author: Rosalia M.

description: Great French wines, quaint atmosphere and very good food (I had the chestnut soup and lamb shoulder). And for a surprisingly reasonable price!
author: Thomas K.

description: Great place for a glass of wine and a small bite.  We stopped by early evening on 1/24/12.  I had the duck confit salad and my partner had the chestnut soup.  Both were yummy and comforting on a cold evening.  We allowed our waiter to pair the wine with our order.  Outstanding pairings, great wine, good value.
author: Marie J.

description: Went to Bouche last night for dinner and was blown away. Everything we ordered was delicious and you can't beat the ambiance. An added bonus is the fabulous and handsome owners and staff. Will definitely be back!
author: C C.

description: I found the upstairs dining room of Bouche recently on a Friday night to be anything but luxurious and cozy. It felt overly dark (the women at the table next to us had brought their own flash lights) and verging on oppressive considering how small the space is. And, there was not a single adornment on the walls...no artwork, no memorabilia, nothing except for the scones which gave off hardly any light. All in all, the upstairs ambience was like sitting in a dimly lit cave. The aroma from the kitchen directly below us was lovely but the noise coming up to our table of dishes clattering and pots being flung into the sink was jarring and overly invasive. The lamb shoulder is exceptionally delicious. It would be helpful if the waiters pointed out that it is JUST the lamb with a teaspoon of sweet potato puree. I would have welcomed the opportunity to order a couple of sides but alas it was too late by the time our main courses arrived.
author: Alison R.
